translation: Seal: trading station of Šalatiwar.
From Imdī-ilum to Luzina and Puzur-Ištar:
To the representatives Aššur-imittī, Imdī-ilum, and Buṣia from Idnāya.
Ilī-uṣranni brings you 10 minas refined silver.
Weigh it out to the one you recorded as my guarantor.
Innaya s. Amura gave Kurara s. Abu-šalim 5 minas refined silver as an ebuṭṭum loan.
He will go and Innāya will not be considered equal with his investors in the tablet of his ebuṭṭum loan in the city.
Witnesses: Šū-Laban s. Dān-ilī, Bazia s. Ilī-Kurub.
Šamaš-bāni and Aššur-mālik owe Šāt-Adad 1 mina refined silver.
They will pay six weeks from the of Ikūn-piā.
If they do not pay, they will add interest at the colony rate.
From Šalim-aḫum to Pūšu-kēn and Dān-Aššur:

112 kutānum textiles, 18 minas hand tin, four black donkeys and their gear, 1 shekels silver for a textile  of saitim, the wage of the drivers satisfied-Idī-Suen brings all this to you (pl.) under my seal.
After these textiles, I will send you as much tin as I can ship, and my instructions will come to you.
I handed over 56 shekels silver, the price of 4 kutānum textiles, at accountings for 20 minas for the account of Innāya s. Elālī.
Innāya s. Ammurāya is my witness.
Separately, I paid him 14 shekels silver, the price of 1 textile.
In total, Innāya s. Elāli owes 1 mina 10 shekels.
Ḫalitka s. a-ra-wa-an- owes Lamassī 4 1/2 shekels silver within 3 months.
Month: Maḫur-ilī
Year: the year after Šū-Niraḫ
Witnesses: Aššur-lamassī, Uzuwa, Inar, Ḫappi-aḫšu
Kunaniya owes Lā-qēpum 1 mina 1 1/2 shekels silver (and) 4 minas fine ḫaburabayyum copper in pieces.
He will pay 5 months from the ḫamuštum week of Ikūnum and Puzur-Aššur.
If he does not pay at the fulfillment of the term, he will add 1 1/2 shekels per mina per month as interest.
Witnesses: Ennum-Aššur, Būr-Ištar.
To Pūšu-kēn, Innāya, and Kiliya from Šū-Kūbum:

My dear brothers, my share from my m. both to accountings and for cash, all that my partners have deposited, you also have deposited and deposit that which is appropriate for accountings for accountings.
Take that which can be taken as cash as cash in silver and send it to me.
My dear brothers, my share from my m. should be deposited together with that of my partners so that no one drinks water off my back.
Take heed of my instructions.
I also am a man of favors.
Wherever needed, I will do a favor for you.
From Šalim-aḫum to Pūšu-kēn:
Your tablet came up and concerning the roughly 4 talents tin which Dān-Aššur left in Kanesh you did not write anything.
You wrote.
While he had arrived, I did not sell anything whatsoever.
From Šalim-aḫum to Pūšu-kēn:
My message has come once or twice to you.
I said, "Give Enna-Suen s. Šū-Ištar his tablet and send all of his property so that the representative of Enna-Suen can give me the tablet with my seal."
As for you there, you have not given him the tablet and he has come here and ... of whatever of my son
They made huge promises ????
Now, if he says, "In the presence of ....
He does not want to take a legal representative.
... two witnesses which ...
From Alāhum and Aššur-idī to Aššur-nādā and Šū-Aššur;
(specifically) to Aššur-nādā:
the same day that you hear the letter Šū-Aššur shall give you 1 talent of tin under the seal of the City, and you must pay him 10 minas of refined silver promptly.
Why is it that you say:
"You have seized my silver"?
Have I removed any of your silver in this way?
Deduct it from the merchandise transported by Ennam-BēIum.
But you yourself, have you not sent the 15 minas that you promised me from Abum to where it  pleased you?
As to the silver transported by Izimea and Hinnaya, their terms are overdue.
Send the silver as soon as possible.

With respect to the certified tablet with the testimony of Lā-qēp and Aššur-imittī son of Amur-ilī, before he leaves you must show him the tablet with his testimony and his seal with one of the travellers as witness, and then erase the words on the tablet.
Please, take Alāhum's tin and scatter it among colleagues and friends and pay him his silver.
To Aššur-nādā and Iddin-Suen from Ilī-ālum:
Previously, before you sent me your goods, I wrote to you, (saying): "Do not send any goods to me!"
CHECK TRANSLATION: You drive them verily yourself, so that I do not clear any of my own things.
As your goods arrived, I cleared copper worth 10 or 15 minas of silver for Aššur-taklāku, and  kept it back on account of your goods.
Further, I shall make at least 20 talents of copper or more for you.
I
Also, x minas [you received] from my outstanding claims and thus opened my eyes.
You must write to me soon about Šarmama and his partners.
His son is dead.
We were unable to go to him.
You will write to me later.
During the sikkātum it is not feasible for us to live up to the promises with respect to your outstanding claims.
The accounting concerning Abum-ilī's enterprise has not taken place.
I asked Turaya, who said: "I balanced 12 shekels of silver for Iddin-Suen."
Twice I have written to you.
Within 3 months after they have paid the balance (and) the price of the textiles has been received, Abum-ilum must pay the balance to you.
If he does not pay, he must add interest for me.
Why has he not paid in accordance with his contract?
Indeed, Iddin-Suen will receive 12 shekels from Turaya.
Your 5 talents of copper Šalim-beli has brought into Burušhaddum.
From Šalim-aḫum to Pūšu-kēn:
Regarding Ilabrat-bāni about whome you wrote me, you said, "He requested for management 'ina tašimtim.'"
(You sent) your message by express...with the express!?
Why did you give him anything to manage?
What favor has he done for me for all the silver I make him here?
Kulumaya owes Aššur-mutabbil 12 minas refined silver.
He will pay in Kanesh 15 weeks from the month of Teʾinātum eponymate of Enna-Suen .
If he does not pay the silver in Kanesh at the fulfillment of his term, he will add interest at the colony rate.
To Amur-Ištar and Pūšu-kēn from Kuzallum:
Amur-Aššur brings you 1 mina 37 1/2 shekels silver belonging to Ḫinnaya under my seal, the price of the gold which the colony office lent out.
There, if you need the textiles of Ḫinnaya for smuggling, pay out the silver.
If Ḫinnaya dictated that his goods should be dispatched here, do not in any way send them to me.
Šū-Suen s. Awarnaḫuš owes 1/2 mina silver to Ikūnum
From the ḫamuštum of A-né-nim and Lālim he has 6 weeks to pay.
If he does not pay the word of the colony will be added in interest.
Witness: Ili-ašranni s. Aššur-ṭāb
Pūšu-kēn sold 1 black textile for 8 1/2 shekels and 2 tiles for 14 shekels each, when Innāya went to the.
2 minas 44 1/3 shekels silver and 7 shekels gold owed by Itūr-ilī.
Puzur-Anna gave 1/2 mina refined silver as the beulātum of Šū-Ištar.
He will pay 2 minas silver.
Aššur-ṭab owes the merchant 15 minas clear tin.
He will pay 16 ḫamuštum weeks from the ḫamuštum of Imdilim and Šamaš-bāni, month of Maḫur-ilī, eponymate after Iddin-abim s. Narbitum.
If he does not pay (on time), he will add (interest) at the rate of 1 1/2 shekels per mina per month.
Witnesses: Aḫu-waqar, Irama-Aššūr
Lamassītum owes Šāt-Ea 12 shekels silver.
After the ḫamuštum-period of Amurru-bāni and Šalim-Aššur, she will add x shekels per (mina) per month.
Witnesses: Kura, Ikuppim
From Elamma to Aššur-nādā, Iddin-abum and Aššur-lamassā:
(specifically) to Aššur-lamassī:
My tin which you brought up here from the City, send me word about where you entrusted it on commission;
also, write the names of your witnesses in the letter.
Then you yourself should write a note about your witnesses, with their names, so that when they convene you can there remind those to whom you entrusted (goods) about the names of your witnesses.
Send me word about who was not and who was present.
To Šēzur from Kunaniya:
My dear brother and god, who questioned you?
To Aššur-nādā from Ša-ša-aḫ-šu-šar:
Since you had left they have received 2/3 mina 5 shekels of silver and given that to Uṣur-ša-Aššur son of Aššur-malik.
Uṣur-ša-Aššur has taken 3 kutānu-textiles and deposited them in the port office.
They received 12 shekels of silver from Šarapunuwa and gave that to me.
The house of Kutubiš brought 4 sacks of barley;
I received it here and 1 1/2 sack will be for myself.
The house of Ka'uba brought 3 sacks of wheat.
However, they did not give me anything.
15 shekels of silver from Tarhunu, they owe the rest of the silver;
thereof they have given me 8 1/4 shekels of silver.
However, they did not give me anything (else), and 5 shekels remain owed by Tarhunu.
Also, it was they who took the rest of the silver.
They have received nothing from your outstanding claims.
Make Uṣur-ša-Aššur pay attention to your orders.
The term (for repayment) is overdue by three months.
Even firewood he did not buy for me, so I myself have bought it.
From Habi we have received 1 2/3 mina 5 shekels of silver;
Uṣur-ša-Aššur has taken it.
2/3 mina we got from Haluli;
also, Uṣur-ša-Aššur <has received> 5 shekels of silver.
To Ikuppia, Ennam-Aššur and Sumi Abiya from Aššur-Nada;
to Ennam-Aššur and Sumi-Abiya:
I entrusted to you 16 half-packs of each 1 talent (and) 7 top-packs of 30 minas, apart from those belonging to Puzur-Ištar, plus 6 black donkeys.
Thereof I sent with you 1 talent 25 minas of copper, that 1 received from Úsur-ša-Aššur, to Ikuppia.
1 talent 12 minas of copper belonging to Ennam-Aššur;
1 talent 20 minas which I balanced with you on behalf of Puzur-Ištar---
the rest of the copper: 15 1/2 talents 3 minas.
Thereof 5 1/2 talents 3 minas of copper belong to the tamkārum.
When the sale has been carried out the tamkārum will pay me 15 112 talents.

And the one who resolved my dispute was Ennam-Aššur, so do not seize anycopper, and without any (authorisation) the tamkārum must not appropriate the 15 1/2 talents ofcopper for which I hold a certified tablet, lest you let it get out of my reach.
As for the rest of the copper, 10 talents from Kunanamit plus the 6 donkeys, I said:
"Come, I shall pay you"-so I trusted you, but you cheated me, saying:
"I shall lay claim to the 10 talents of copper and the 6 donkeys,
turn that into copper of good quality in Durhumit, bring it to Kaneš and your representatives will pay me in full in silver."
I did not payout the copper and the donkeys to you.
Why did you then say:
"I have been paid."
The donkeys belong to Ikuppia!
Release the donkeys to him!
For the rest of your silver I shall personally guarantee for you.
may Aššur and Amurrum, the gods of our fathers, know:
on top of the fact that I guaranteed for your joint-stock capital, it was no stranger who denounced me!
It is you who keep denouncing me in colony after colony!
Witnesses: Pilaḫāya s. Enna-Suen, Amur-Ištar s. Ennamāya, Ili-ālim the scribe s. Rim-Anun.
Elā(ya) and Aššur-mālik owe Puzur-Aššur 1 mina silver.
They will pay 7 weeks from the ḫamuštum of Puzur-Aššur.
If they do not pay (on time), they will add interest at a rate of 1 1/2 shekels per month
Month: Teʾintātim.
Eponymate: Aššur-imittī the boatman.
(The obligation to pay back) the silver is bound to whichever one is financially solvent and legally responsible.
Witnesses: Ikuppiya, Zuzubar.
Arši-aḫ s. Aššur-bāni (im-dí-lum) owes 1 mina 12 1/3 shekel
He has three weeks to pay.
Month: Allānātim
Witnesses: Usānum s. Amur-Aššur, Mašiḫ-ilī, my father, s. Ṭāb-ṣilli-Aššur.
To Sukalliya, Šū-Anum, and Ikūn-pī-Aššur from Iddin-Suen:
To Ikūn-pī-Aššur:
Aḫ-šalim and Aššur-nādā did not give me the silver.
Let your urgent message go to them.
I owe you 6 minas 24 shekels silver.
You paid 4 minas certified silver to my account.
If they did not cause the silver reach you, but you intend to go, on the day of your departure let Sukkallia and Šū-Anum take the silver for interest and give it to you.
If you do not receive the silver before your departure, (and) the interest does not ..., then send to Aḫ-šalim and Aššur-nādā so that they send your silver to me.
Ikūnim owes Aššur-imittī 23 1/2 minas 3 shekels refined silver.
He will pay 40 weeks from the ḫamuštum of Amurrum-bāni and Ikūnim.
If he does not pay at the fulfillment of his term, he will add interest at the rate of 1 1/2 shekels per mina per month.
Month: Allānātim
Eponymate: Sukkallīya
Witnesses: Aššur-rēʾī, Azunāya, Aššur-mālik.
The maḫši of Punuwa, Niwaḫšušar, and Šiwanala owe 1/3 minas silver to Aššur-mālik.
They will pay at picking of the "mother" grapes.
If they do not pay, they will add interest at the rate of 2 shekels per month.
Witnesses: Ennum-Aššur, Puzur-Aššur, Ḫappu-ala
Ennam-Aššur, son of Kurkur, owes Aḫuqar 10 shekels silver.
He will pay him 15 ḫamuštum periods after the ḫamuštum of Itur-ili and Aššur-taklāku in the month of Ṣipim.
If he does not pay (then), he will add 1.5 shekels per mina as interest according to colony policy.
Eponymate: Aššur-damiq.
Witnesses: Kiliya, Puzur-Ištar
The 4 talents tin belonging to Hinnaya, that is in Hinnaya's house, Elama and Aššur-nādā divided it three ways:
Elama took 1 talent 20 minas tin.
Aššur-nādā took 1 talent 22 minas tin.
Elama, Aššur-nādā and Aššur-dān sent 1 talent 20 minas tin the share of Karwaya to Durḫumit to Karwaya.
Aššur-bēl-awātim owes Pūšu-kēn (some amount of) copper.
He will pay 8 ḫamuštum-weeks from the ḫamuštum of Ku-x-x.
If he does not pay when the term is full, he will add 1 1/2 minas per talent per month.
Month: Teinātum.
Līmmum: Iddin-abum.
Zwei talent zwei Minen Zinn <vom> Hause des Pilaḫištar habe ich dem Āmurilī gegeben.
(Weitere) zwei Talent neun Minen Zinn von der Karawane des Ilīnādā habe ich ihm überreicht.
Elf Minen zehn Seqel Zinn  sind Ausgleichszahlungen; <x Minen x Seqel> Zinn sind Wegzoll.
Die mir (dafür zustehende) [Sil]ber(menge beträgt) 25⅚ Minen 3 Seqel.
Davon hat er 24 Minen 48 Seqel Silber bezahlt.
Den Rest des Silbers, eine Mine fünf Seqel Silber ist Āmurilī (mir) schuldig.
(Was die (Schuld)urkunde (auf den Namen) des Tarmānā über 8⅓ Minen 1¾ Seqel (betrifft), so ist das Silber und der Zins dazu zu (einer Summe von) 12 Minen angestiegen.
Davon gehören 6 Minen Silber dem Puzuraššur, (und) 6 Minen mir.
8 Minen Silber (betrug) die Schuld des Pferdemeisters, 4 Minen (sind) Zins: Insgesamt 12 Minen Silber hat vom Pferdmeister und dessen Frau er erhalten.
2½  Minen 7½  Seqel Silber: (dieses) Silber, den Preis für Gold, hat er vom ,,Stadtherren‘‘ erhalten.
Einen Dolch (?), eine (Dolch)scheide (?) und ein Halfter aus Silber hat er ihm (dem Stadtherren) (als Geschenk) überlassen.
Vor Aḫûqar.
Den Preis für acht gute Stoffe, den er (P) im Palast erhalten hat, außerdem den Preis für zwei Stoffe vom Zehnten, 1 Mine Silber, hat er (P) im bīt kārim erhalten.
(Was) den Preis für 40 Sack Gerste meines Anteils zu je 4½ Seqel pro Krug (betrifft): 12 Minen Silber ist der Preis dafür.
Dies alles (befindet sich) bei Puzuraššur.
1 Mine 10 Seqel Silber, den Zins für 7½ Minen 9¾ Seqel Silber für acht Monate hat von Aššurmuttabil Buzāzu gar nicht erhalten.
Wenn  die Geldgeber des Ašš[urmuttabbil] den Zins von Bu[zāzu] jeweils einfordern, wird 1 Mi[ne] 10 Seqel Silber Aššurmuttabbil an Buzāzu zahlen.
Wenn der Zins von Buzāzu nicht eingefordert werden sollte, wird keinerlei Silber A[šš]urmuttabbil dem [Buz]āzu zahlen.
Vor Belānum; vor Aẖšalim; den Söhnen des Šū’aššur.
⅔ Minen 1½ Seqel Silber: Aššurbāni, der Sohn des Bēlumnādā; ⅓ Mine 2½ Seqel Silber: Šū’išḫārā, der Sohn des Kurārā; von 14 Seqel Silber, die bei Aššurbāni, dem Schreiber, habe ich 5 Seqel erhalten.
9 Seqel Silber (ist) er (noch) schuldig.

15 Seqel Silber, (stehen) bei Abūšalim, dem Sohne des Aššurtāb; 6½ Seqel  Silber (stehen) bei Aššurmalik, dem Schmied; 2 Seqel Silber: Aššurtāb, der Transporteur; ⅔ Seqel Silber: Ḫaltika; 5 Seqel Silber: Daknabura ; 4 Seqel Silber: Lībūrbēlī; 2½  Seqel Silber: der Angestellte des Ḫalitka; 1⅓ Seqel Silber: der…...... des Öles (?); 2½ Seqel Silber: Šiwašmi; 3 Seqel Silber: Kakuzānum.
(Mit) insgesamt 1 Mine 55 Seqel Silber, dem Außenstand des Abumilī, hat Ṣillanum mich beglichen.

Für 20 Minen Silber, die Kulumājā dem Kaugmann schuldig ist und dessen Schuldurkunde seit dem Amtstag des Ili’a ausgestellt ist, haben den seit dem Amstage des Kurbištar, des Sohnes des Alâḫum, (in der Höhe von) 5 Minen 15 Seqel Silber (fälligen) Zins dazu Puzuraššur und Aššurmuttabbil dem Šūsu’in, dem Sohne des Ili’a, bezahlt.
Vor Ṭābṣillaššur; vor Aḫšalim; vor Bēlānum, dem Sohne des Šū’aššur.
Von den 5 Minen 15 Seqel Silber (sind) 2 Minen 15 Seqel Silber das des Puzura[ššur]; 3 Minen Silber hat Aššurmuttabbil bezahlt.
Regarding the 9 minas 2/3 shekels tin and 28 shekels silver belonging to Pūšu-kēn: Concerning(this?)  Šū-Ištar s. Dadānum (and?) Suen-rē'ī s. Amur-Ištar answered.
Pūšu-kēn will not aid (pay) the tin or silver, the debt of Šū-Ištar s. Dadānum.
Witnesses: Šū-Ištar s. Luzina, Puzur-Aššur s. Išar-kit-Aššur, Dān-Aššur s. Šalim-aḫum, Aššur-māalik s. Amur-lussu, Ilī-wēdāku s. Idī-Ašsur.

1 Talent 57½ Minen Zinn, gesiegelt, 41 Kutānū nebst der Verpackung, (6/7) 2 schwarze Esel und deren Geschirr, (was) den Treiber (betrifft) 4½ Seqel Silber für seinen Anteil: All dies habe ich dem Innarāwā anvertraut.
10 Seqel Gold mit meinen Siegeln (versehen) habe ich dem Asānum, außerdem 10 Seqel Silber ebenfalls dem Asānum für das (Geschäfts)haus des A<ššur>bāštī anvertraut.
Vor Šamašbāni, dem Sohne des Ennasu’in, ...; vor Ikuppāša; vor Ištarbāni, dem Sohne des Āmurištar 1⅓ Minen........ Kupfer habe ich für den (Lohn) der Diener ihm gegeben.

10 Minen Silber des tamkārum, mit den Siegeln des Aẖšalim (versehen), habe ich dem Ennasu’in, und dem Sohne des Šū’ištar, dem Uṣurštar, dem Sohne des Aššurimittī, und dem Aššurmalik, dem Sohne des Usānum, anvertraut.
Vor Idī’aššur, dem Sohne des Aššurmittī; vor Sukū’a, dem Sohne des Aššuridī.
Pūšu-kēn seized us against Ḫuraṣānum:
Pūšu-kēn said to Huraṣānum: You owe me 1 talent 13 minas 50 shekels tin and 2 minas 41 shekels silver.
Ḫuraṣānum responded: It is true. I owe you. I will pay your silver to you when Ikuppiya arrives.
For this matter, the colony at Kanesh gave us permission, and we gave our testimonies before the dagger of Aššur.
Witnesses: Aḫ-šalim s. Šū-Anum, Kurara, Ikuppī-Aššur.
Siegel des Zi’atatu, des Sohnes des Alâbum; Siegel des Amurrubbāni, des Sohnes des Bu-bu-wa-r[i] (?).
Diese Gottestor-Urkunde (ist es), die wir vor dem Dolche des [Aššur] [gegeben haben (?)].
Zupa seized us against the sons of Pūšu-kēn and Zupa said to the sons of Pūšu-kēn, "You father received the silver of my sealed tablet."
"Why does Suen-rē'ī withhold my tablet?"
The sons of Pūšu-kēn and Suen-rē'ī responded "Our father did receive all the silver of your sealed tablet.
Release it(him?) and we will give the matter to you.
Suen-rēʾī released Zupa in our presence.
For this matter, the colony at Kanesh gave us permission, and we gave our witnesses before the dagger of Aššur.
Witnesses: Ziadādu, Amurrum-bāni
[Siegel des] Labannādā, des Sohnes des Idīsu’in; Siegel des Ikuppī’aššur, des Sohnes des P[ila]ẖaššur.
Regarding this matter, the colony at Durḫumit allowed us to
give our witnesses before the dagger of Aššur.
Idī-Dagān [s. Sa]rnikum, Šalim-aḫum s. Ṭābilī, (were) our partner witnesses.
Ennasu’in, der Sohn des Ikū’am und Puzurištar, der Sohn des Alâbum, sind für die Frau des Ikuppi’a, die Töchter des Ikuppī’a und die Söhne des Ikuppī’a an deren Stelle eingetreten,
und haben 40 Minen Silber, die Shculd des Ikuppī’a, dem Aššurmuttabbil, dem Sohne des Pūšukēn, und dem Bēlānum, dem Kommissär des Pūšukēn, bezahlt.
Für diese Angelegenheiten hat der Kārum Turḫumit uns (als Richter) bestellt.
Vor dem Dolche des Aššur haben wir unsere Beurkundung gegeben.
Vor Labannādā, dem Sohne des Idīsu’in; vor Ikuppī’aššur, dem Sohne des Pilaẖaššur.
Idīdagān, der Sohn des Sarnikum, und Šalimaḫum, der Sohn des Ṭābilī, (waren) unsere Beisitzer.

Lā-qēpum, the mayor of the city, seized us against the sons of Pūšu-kēn and the mayor said to the sons of Pūšu-kēn, "According to the tablet of the city, this in the city with the chief of your(pl.) case I will speak."
The sons of Pūšu-kēn said, "We will establish it. We will clear regarding the tablet of the city and the mayor of our lord and we will come and give the case to the lord of our case."
Witnesses: Ilī-bāni s. Amur-Aššur, Ikuppiya s. Šū-Ištar, Enna-Suen s. Ennānum s. Amāya(Amuwa).

Siege[l des Us]ān[um, des Sohnes des] Ām[ur]aššur; Siegel des Kulumā´ā, [des Sohnes des] Aššurimittī; Sie[gel des Ḫuni’a, des Sohnes des Aššu]rimittī; Siegel des Tāb-ṣillaššur, des Sohnes des A[ššurid]ī; Siegel des Aššurtaklāku des Sohnes des Alâḫum; Siegel des Bēlānu[m, des Sohne]s des Šū’aššur; Siegel des Puzurenna, des Sohnes des Enn[a’aššur]; Siegel des Idī’ašš[ur, des] S]o[hnes des Dā]naššur; Siegel des Aššurpilaḫ, des Komissäars <des Hauses> Āmurištar; Siegel des S[u’i]nrē’ûm, Siegel des Ilībāni, Siegel des Aššurnīsū, Siegel des Š[ūlab]an, der Söhne des Āmurištar; Siegel des Aššurmuttabbil, Siegel des Buzāzu, S[iege]l des Ikuppāša, der Söhne des Pūšukēn; Aššurpilaḫ, [der Kommis]sär des Houses Āmurištar, Su’inrē’ûm, Ilībāni, Aššurnīšu und Šūlaban, in eigener Sache und als Vertreter der Abšalim, der Tochter des Āmurištar, und des Iddinadad, ihres Bruders, Aššurmuttabbil, Buzāzu, Ikuppāša, [die Söhn]e des [Pūšuk]ēn, in ei[gener Sache] und als Vertreter der Aḫāḫā <ihrer Schwester>, [der gubabtu]m-Priesterin, und ihres Bruders S[u’e’a haben auf] ihre gegenseitgigen Verpflichtungen un[s (als Richter) genommen].
Den Eid bei der Stadt haben sie ge[leis]tet.

Dann haben wir ihre Rechtsstreitigkeiten be[en]det: Entweder ist Āmurištar als Vertreter des Pūšukēn ist als Vertreter des Āmurištar aufgetreten; oder der eine hat dem anderen ein Depôt geschickt: Entweder hat der eine des anderen Silber vom Außenstand eingenommen, oder, (was) eine Doppel- urkunde mit den Siegeln (des einen) von ihnen oder das (Gut) der Karawanen beziehungsweise die Vorräte (betrifft), (so) hat der eine (es) dem anderen aufgespeichert, (und zwar) sowohl in Assur als auch in Kappadokien.

Die Söhne des Āmurištar und die Tochter des Āmurištar, die gubabtum-Priesterin, die Söhne des Pūšukēn und die Tochter des Pūšukēn, die gubabtum-Priesterin: Die eine (Partei) wird auf die andere in irgendeiner Sache nicht zurckkommen.
Diese Leute (waren) [die Beender der Rechtssach]en.

Aššur-pilah, the attorney of the estate of Amur-Ištar, Suen-rēʾī, Il-bānī, Aššur-nīšu, and Šū-Laban, sons of Amur-Ištar on their own behalf and on behalf of Ab-šalim, daughter of Amur-Ištar and Iddin-Adad their brother, and Aššur-mutabbil, Buzāzu and Ikūppaša, sons of Pūšu-kēn on their own behalf and on behalf of Aḫaḫa their sister the gubabtum priestess and Sueyya their brother Sueyya seized us in their agreement and swore the oath of the city and concluded their case:
Amur-Ištar stood as the legal representative of Pūšu-kēn.
Pūšu-kēn stood as the representative of Amur-Ištar.
One sent accounts to the other.
Each brother accepted silver for the funds of the other.
Sealed tablets with their seals or with witnesses or dividends(?) invested in each other.

Either in the city or abroad, the sons of Amur-ištar and the daughter of the Amur-Ištar, the gubabtum priestess, and the sons of Pūšu-kēn and the daughter of Pūšu-kēn, the gubabtum priestess, will not return to each other for any matter.

The following men were the adjudicators on the matter: Usānum s. Amur-Aššur, Kulumay s. Aššur-imittī, Ḫuniya s. Aššur-imittī, Ṭāb-ṣilla-Aššur s. Aššur-idi, Puzur-enna s. Enna-Aššur, Aššur-taklāku s. Āl-aḫum, Bēlānum s. Šū-Aššur, Idi-Aššur s. Dān-Aššur.
Seal of Waqqurtum

Eine Tafel von mir über 7 Minen Silber, eine Tafel von mir über 4 Minen Silber, eine Tafel von mir über 1⅔ Minen 5 Seqel Silber, eine Tafel von mir über 1 Talent 10 Minen Kupfer, eine Tafel von mir über 17 Minen Silber, die Pilaḫāja und Aki’a unter Beschlagnahme halten und auf welches Silber sie kein Anrecht haben und die meine Schuld (oder: eine Schuld an mich) (betreffen), insgesamt fünf Tafeln mit meinen Siegeln: (nehmt sie ihnen ab und) haltet sie zurück, zu meinen (anderen) Tafeln legt sie (die Urkunden) (mir) und dann möge euer Bescheid zu mir kommen. (Rs unbeschrieben.)
From Šalim-Aššur, Imdī-ilum, and Pūšu-kēn and Ilī-bāni to Kuziza:
Ilī-bāni brought 18 minas silver under your seal.
6 shekels were lost in the washing process.
We gave 1 shekels for the smith and wood.
3 2/3 shekels 15 grains poor quality silver under our seals is available in the house of Pūšu-kēn.
Your silver was deducted 16 1/2 shekels both deductions and losses.

Also, according to your instructions, in addition to the 18 minas silver which Ilī-bāni brought, we acquired for you 13 minas 16 1/2 shekels refined silver at a 1 shekel (per mina per month) rate and they sealed our tablet.
31 minas refined silver, your debt, we weighed out to Pūšu-kēn.
We asked him about your tablet and he said, "Their terms are two weeks past due. Have them pay the interest so that I may give you (pl.) his tablet. I hold your tablet for interest."
Let Kuzizīya come and we will negotiate about the interest.
Take care to send the 13 minas 16 1/2 shekels silver which we took for interest.
To Pūšu-kēn from Aššur-mālik:
You wrote me.
You said, "The copper from your account has been seized."
I paid to him 14 talents of tin three months ago.
As for myself and Šumi-abiya, on the day that I heard your letter, the man's son paid the certified agent(s) of the man and I said, "Your father is my agent."

As for me, copper and silver as much as their are, 8 talents of fine copper, 4 minas and 45 shekels of silver, we seized and we sealed them with seal of Šumi-abiya and my seal and deposited them in my inn.
He purchased merchandise worth 6 minas silver and (the merchandise) was seized.
They sent it for its release.
Now, they will go and we will seize (the goods).
4 talents of fine copper is deposited in my inn at Ulama.
Now, we will write to them and we will seize him.
Ḫaršunuma, the priest of Šamaš, owes Pūšu-kēn 11 minas of fine liti silver.
He will pay 13 ḫamuštum-weeks from the ḫamuštum-week of Šū-Kūbum and Kurub-Ištar at the festival of Parka which is coming.
If he does not pay when the term is full, he will add 2 1/2 shekels per mina.
Eponymate: The one following Idī-abim.
Witnesses: Adelat, Ennānum, Ḫalikiaššu, Arziap.
Al-aḫum owes Sueata 1/2 mina refined silver.
He will pay 13 ḫamuštum weeks from the ḫamuštum of Al-aḫum and Buzia.
If he does not pay (on time), he will add interest according to the rate of the colony per month.
Zu Pūšukēn sprich! Folgendermaßen Kulumā’a:

(Auch) wenn der Angestellte des Kura mit Enumaššur wegen (?) ihrer Angelegenheiten sich irgendwie streiten sollte, —mein Vater bist du, mein Herr bist du — bringe meine Sachen zu Ende, soweit du kannst.
9¾ Seqel Silber, den Preis für 1 Mine 13 Se[qel] Zinn, das ich dem Allu gegeb[en] habe [und] (welches) Silber Ikuppī’aššur im Hause des Ḫabu’[ā]lā erhalten hat, (dieses) Silber habe ich erhalten.
Zu dem Silber, das ich dem Šamaštaklāku gegeben habe, füge es hinzu; dann siegle das Si[lb]er und schicke (es) mir.
Die ⅓ Minen 2½ Seqel Silber, den Preis für 2½ Kutānū des Dānaššur, womit du mein Konto belastet hast, kannst du (?) von meiner Provision abziehen.
Dort braucht (das Silber) von deinem Konto nicht abzugehen.
Dein Aufzeichnung hat er [mir] gegeb[en](?).
Das Zinn und die Stoffe des Dānaššur und die 6 Kutānū seiner Schwester sind dir sichergestellt.
Den Imku’a, den Šūkūbum und die (anderen) Boten schicke (her)!
Mit dem ersten von ihnen wird (die Ware an dich) (ab)gehen.
Mein Vater (bist) du, mein Herr (bist) du! Wegen meiner Angelegenheiten betreffend das Haus des Kurā sei achtsam!
Zu Buzāzu sprich: "⅚ Minen 5 Seqel, Blumen (?)‘, die ich dir,überlassen‘ habe, schicke an unseren Ennasu’in!"
To Pūšu-kēn from Šū-Kūbum:
In accordance with the letter which you wrote to me, we gathered your investors and we brokered an agreement.
Now, their sealed tablet they bring to you.
3 fine 'finished' textiles, 7 kutānum-textiles, in all 10 textiles belonging to your wife, she entrusted them to Kulumaya in my presence and he brings them to you.
Aššur-taklāku your servant brings you one bundle of lapis belonging to your wife.
My dear brother, you and Innāya take half of the tin and textiles in Atata's charge and in accordance with (what we discussed) here, send the 'corresponding' silver.
Silver in the charge of [PN] ... (fragmentary) ... take.
Do not disappoint me.
Act in such a way that when you do me a favor, you do not disappoint me.
My dear brother, take heed to deposit my share, silver, textiles, or whatever they will invest so that they balance me in the same way they balance you and do me a favor.

As for the documents which states, 'Concerning the matter of Innāya,' which you brought in your transport, you and Innāya read them and when you have read them, you and Innāya seal them and entrust them to a reliable affiliated trader so that he puts them in protective casing and brings them to me.
Now, take heed concerning the matter of Šū-Suen.
May Aššur (and DN?) witness that Kulumaya ... in Burallum.
He did not want to receive(?) the 10 minas to Ali-...'s representatives and ... silver ...
To Pūšu-kēn from Amur-Ištar-ma:
Concerning the tin belonging to Ḫinnaya about which you wrote, th(at) affiliated trader and his packer are here.
I deposited the tin belonging to the house of Aššur-mālik for copper at a rate of 15 minas and there was copper available.
But then a great number of Eblaites arrived here and much copper was weighed out to them in the palace and they returned silver at 2 1/2 minas refined.
In 10 days its copper will be exhausted.
I will purchase silver and send it to you.
Thereof, 48 shekels gold from the (funds?) of Ennu-Aššur, share of Sueya, 48 shekels gold, the share of Ikuppaša, in total 1 mina 36 shekels gold, I myself purchased.
I gave 10 minas silver to the merchant for purchasing the gold.

Also the the tablet sealed with my seal from the eponym year of Akutum (REL 108) which stated that the representative of the merchant held the gold, ... x minas gold which I wrote down to/for ... , 20 shekels gold ... 4 shekels ...
Zu Aššurnādā sprich! Folgendermaßen Aššuriddin:
½ Mine 7½  Seqel Silber ist Amurrabbāni mir schuldig.
Seine Dopel-urkunde habe ich seit {dem Eponymat} fünf Jahren dir überlassen.
Entweder läßt du ihn das Silber zahlen, oder meine Urkunde gibst du mir zurück.
Wie ich immer wieder höre, ist Amurrubbāni nach Kaniš gekommen.
Silber, 1 oder 2 Minen, ist ihm anvertraut.
Mein Bruder bist du! Lade ihn vor und laß ihn das Silber zahlen!
Wenn er sich auf dem Markte nicht zeigt, beauftrage den Schreiber des Kārum bezüglich des Hauses der Šad’a, der Tochter des Su’eddādā.
To Šū-Kūbum and Aššur-pilah, and specifically to Šū-Kūbum, from Aššur-nādā:
With regard to the silver with which our father has become indebted to the fund of divine Šar-mātēn, they seized me here and said: "Pay the silver, your father's debt."
I answered: "You have received silver repeatedly, so little silver is left (of the debt).
There are memoranda of my father's available."
They said: "Produce your father's memoranda and let us see."
One person representing you and one stranger entered (the house) together with me and we opened for the tablets and took out the memoranda and I showed them;
I pleaded with them ... sacrifices ...
and ... we took out the memoranda and copies of the tablets from the Gate of the God concerning our own tablet ...
in the copy of the certified tablet of the Gate of the God which may appear, concerning x mina 5 shekels of silver from Alāhum's debt—(that) Amur-Ištar paid to Aššur-re'i.
Aššur-re’i said as follows to Amur-Ištar:
"Your one-mina weight is too light."
His one-mina weight was checked(?) and he then paid him 1 1/2 shekel of silver.
Witnessed by Libbaya son of Uzua, by Ennānum, the inn-keeper; Nab-Suen son of Illil-bāni was our co-witness.
For this matter, the Kanesh colony gave us permission, and we gave our testimonies before the dagger of Aššur.
To Abaya from Aššur-nādā:
In accordance with the message I sent to you, Innaya has here discussed with the tamkāru on your behalf of you and your paternal household.
He became unhappy becasue of Kura.

He said,"If he is not given instructions directly from her, these people will put continual pressure on travelers in the City, and then this one will sieze lots of silver there and constantly cause my reputation harm."
As for the x+3 wooden beamsof your house, Kura had sold them before I arrived at Kanesh.
I discussed that with you in that very place.
I said, "The house of Anaḫ-Ištar is almost finished, and it is you who should ..."
From Assur-nada to Ili-alum:
Against the will of the god misfortune has fallen upon me, as they have just written to me in Uršu.
My dear brother, act in such a way that no evildoer may do harm to our father's house!
While I may still be saved-
9 talents 20 minas of my copper that Aššur-taklāku has given on commission to an agent, 8 talents 40 minas less 2/3 mina apart from the transport tariff, which you have bought for me---
out of which you sent 5 talents to Burušhaddum, and whose proceeds I have already received-

1 talent 18 minas of good broken copper, proceeds from the sale of 3 donkeys, which you gave in commission to an agent, of that 10 minas belong to you, 25 minas of good (copper), proceeds from the sale of a donkey, owed by me.
The copies concerning Šalim-bēlī's earlier caravan are not here;
guard the tablet with my instructions!
45 kutānu-textiles (and) 25 minas of sealed tin, apart from what I gave to him for expenses, Šalim-bēlī brought to you earlier.
72 kutānu-textiles, 2 of those abami'u-textiles, 4 black donkeys plus their harness, 1 mina of tin (and) worth 2 2/3 shekels 15 grains of silver of small goods you carried personally.
4 kutānu-textiles are owed by Kurub-Ištar.
The terms for the agent are overdue by 7 months.
My dear brother, send as much silver as falls into your hands to Uśur-ša-Aššur, so he may let it reach me and I shall not be put to shame.
While could still I oblige you I gave 8 shekels of silver for the fodder of 2 donkeys and 1 shekel for your porters.
2 shekels were for the share of Aššur-šamši, witnessed by Šū-Suen the son of Itūr-ilī.
I bound him by contract to pay 1/2 mina per textile, witnessed by Aššur-tāb and Aššur-dān.
Zu Puzuraššur sprich! Folgendermaßen Igā’a:
(Was) all das (betrifft), worüber du klagst: Wer ist in Tu[rḫ]umit, der dauernd gegen einen Großkaufmann (?) ein Urteil fällt?
Als Su’e’a herkam, gab man gewöhnlich Zinn zu(m Kurs von) je 9 Minen oder je 10 Minen.
Ich habe je 11 Minen dir geschickt!
Aššur und die Götter der Bruderschaft mögen Zeuge sein!
5 Minen Zinn von deinem Zins habe ich Ḫanānum zu (einem Kurs von) je 30 Minen sehr schlechtes Kupfer gegeben.
D[er] hat (es) bereits weggebracht. Nicht einen (einzigen) Seqel vo[n der A]bgabe hat er mir gegeben.
In Sachen Igmillum (?) ärgerst du dich. Er tut doch wohl dauernd Unrechtes!
Ferner habe ich 55 Minen . . . . . . Kupfer, 12 Minen gutes Bruch- (?) Kupfer— 6 Minen sind Abzüge — dem Šū-ištar gegeben.
Das Kupfer, das Ennasu (?) dir gebracht hat, nimm (es!)
Wegen des Kupfers der Šadunum (?), bezüglich dessen sie mir geschrieben hat: 6 Minen [. . . . ] . . . . an ihren Herren hat sie weggebracht (?).
Zu Puzuraššur sprich! Folgendermaßen Ilīwēdāku:
Mein Vater bist du! Mein Herr bist du! An dem Tage, an dem du meine Tafel liest, sei achtsam!
Deinen Bedarf notiere in(nerhalb von) fünf Tagen.
Meine Angelegenheit erledige! Dann will ich deinem Bescheid mich beugen und (dementsprechend) meine Reise unternehmen.
1 Mine Silber (sei es nun) meines oder deines, halte ich in Händen.
Einen Monat oder zwei Monate sollst du nicht (darüber) verfügen.
Denn meine Angelegenheien hast du nicht erledigt und soll ich da nicht angesteckt (?) werden.
Was soll ich dir (noch) viel schreiben?
Mit Tafeln und Briefen will ich (es) dir kurz machen! Ḫutka soll nicht einmal übernachten; einen klaren Bescheid von dir soll er mir bringen.
Das Silber, 1 Mine, will ich bereitlegen.
Dann möge er, damit wir das Depot niederlegen können und nicht zuschanden werden, handeln.
10 Seqel Silber, den Preis für den Ring aus Eisen, den Ḫutka mir gebracht hat, mit meinen Siegeln: (damit) ist Ḫutka zu dir unterwegs.
½ Mine Silber hat zu Lasten des Aššurnādā Ḫarima gut.
Bei seiner Rückkehr von der (ersten), (Geschäfts)reise wird er 15 Seqel Silber zahlen.
Bei seiner Rückkehr von der zweiten (Geschäfts)reise wird er wiederum 15 Seqel Silber zahlen; dann ist er (der Gläubiger) befreidigt.
Vor Šūbēlum, vor Beru’a.
Zu Puzuraššur sprich! Folgendermaßen Ilīwēdāku und Buzāzu
Was den Dadā’a, betrifft, so hat der hier (ihnen) dein Kupfer gegeben und Gold (dafür) gekauft.
Wir haben ihn vorgeladen; dann (sprachen) wir folgendermaßen: "Silber oder Gold zahle! Dann wollen wir dir eine gesiegelte Urkunde (darüber) ausstellen. Also nimm du es auf dich! (?)"

Folgendermaßen (antwortete) er: "Ich werde zu ihm gehen. Denn bei meinem Geldgeber habe ich viele (Posten) gut. Ich werde gehen und mich dann bei ihm rechtfertigen. Dort möge er das Silber, das er zu nehmen (berechtigt ist), ne[hmen.]"
Der Mann ist zu dir abgereist. Hier haben wir seinen Gewandsaum einen Monat gehalten.
Folgendermaßen (sprach) er: "Zu ihm werde ich gehen. Warum haltet ihr mich (noch) in Haft?"
Da der Mann zu dir gehen wollte, deswegen haben wir den Mann nicht kränken wollen!
Zu Aššurrēṣī und Aššurmalik sprich! Folgendermaßen Puzuraššur:
Zu Aššurrēṣī sprich! Mit 2 Minen Zinn von dem des Kaufmannes hat man mich bezahlt.
Ich halte mich in Ḫaka auf. Ich weiß nicht (was tun)!
Ich kam her und (sprach) folgendermaßen zu deinen Kollegen: "Die Urkunde gebt mit!"
Folgendermaßen (antworteten) zu dein Kollegen: "Von dem (Zinn) des Kaufmannes bezahle das Zinn!"
Nach Kaniš werden wir es (das Zinn?) bringen und entsprechend (dem Stande) der Angelegenheit werde ich dorthin (eine Reise) unternehmen.
Folgendermaßen (sprach) Šūsu’in: "Die Tafel werde ich nicht (hin)bringen."
Er kam her und der Kaufmann wird (nun) den Besche[id] dir überprüfen (?).
Du sollst mir eiligst scheiben!
Weil ich an diesen Dingen keinen Anteil habe, mein Bruder bist du, möge zu mir nach Zalpa Bescheid kommen.
Dann will ich in Angelegenheiten einer Reise nach der Stadt (d. h. nach Assur) hinkommen und ich will mich dort rechtfertigen
Folgendermaßen Enna’aššur. Zu Āmurištar sprich!
Warum hast du mir (nur) bis zu diesem Tage gehorcht?
(Betrifft:) die kurrū (Getreide) für die Stadt dorthin zu schicken: sie (die Stadt) soll nicht hungern!
Bitte! An dem Tage, an dem du meine Tafeln liest, möge meine Urkunden Waza dir geben.
Ferner ist mit den Urkunden des Hauses Absūšalim, des So[hnes des . . . ] . . [. . . , wie] ich geschrieben habe, Aššurtaklāku zu dir unterwegs.
Gemäß meinem Briefe nimm meine Urkunden, die der Waza und die der Frau des Abūšalim und komm schleunigst her.
Deinetwegen habe ich nach Waḫšušana nicht gehen wollen.
Dich erwarte ich! Bitte!
Möglichst keine zwei Tage sollst du dort dich aufhalte!
Dann können die Geldgeber mir nicht zusetzen.
Auch sollst du nicht zugrunde gehen und meine Urkunden sollst du nicht zugrunde richten
Sei achtsam" Waza . . . Šūsu’in ist ihr nahe (?).
Sie möge herausgehen. Hierher möge er sie nicht herausgehen lassen (?).
Zu Mannumkī’eli’a, Idī’aššur und Zu-mi-ṣa sprich! Folgendermaßen Ilī’ālum: Zu Mannumkī’eli’a sprich!
Was das betrifft, (worüber) ich dich informiert habe, — und du hast mir vertraulich (dazu) geschwiegen — so (sage) ich (jetzt) folgendermaßen: "Silber werde ich kein zweites Mal schuldig werden!"
Zu Mannumkī’eli’a sprich! Wenn er darauf zurückkommt und Aššurmalik irgend etwas, das mich betrifft, sagt, so (sollst) du folgendermaßen (antworten):
"Die Urkunde hat der Sohn des Zuba, der (einer) von den Beisitzern (war), in Verwahrung."
(Hinsichtlich) des (Wertes) des Silbers ist er befreidigt.
Wenn er aber irgend etwas, das mich betrifft, sagt, öffnet meine Urkunde und dann laßt die Urkunde mit dem Siegel des Šūbēlum und des Išūḫum verlesen.
Ferner werde ich ihm über Silber, 1 Seqel, damit er nicht anficht und nicht (Silber) nimmt, bis ich mich mit dem Angestellten des Herren getroffen habe, eine Urkunde ausstellen.
Zu Idī’aššur sprich! Wegen des Silbers des Aššurnāṣir: Das Silber werde ich dir zahlen lassen.
Dein Herz soll nicht (darum) zittern.
Zu Addād[a, Buzāzu und] Aššurmu[ttabbil] sprich! [Folgendermaßen. . . . :]
[Meine] Brüder [(seid) ihr! Meine Herren] (seid) ihr! [. . . . . ]
10 sch[warze] Stoff[e. . . . . ] habe ich überlassen [. . . ] . . [. . . . ] dort . . [. . . ] des Kupfers [. . . . . . . . ].
. . . [. . . . ] des Kaufmannes [. . . . . ]. . . [. . . . .  ]. . . hast du mir ge<brac>ht.
[. . . . . ]. . . . [. . . . .] und wegen des . . . . [. . . An we]n sonst soll ich mich wenden? Meine Brüder, meine Herren!
Das Silber schickt mir umgehend! Dann will ich (es) dem Kaufmann zurückgeben.
Zu Buzāzu spr[ic]h! Du hast mir geschrieben, folgendermaßen du:
"Einen Kommissär sollt ihr nicht nehmen! Ihr sollt mir (das) nicht schreiben!"
Damit der Stoff <nicht> verderbe, habe ich dir vertraut und entsprechend (dem Wunsche) meines Gatten und Herren habe ich mir einen Kommissär nicht genommen.
Heute war ich entsprechend der Sklavin . . . . . dir nicht und die Genossen (?) für die Sklavin sollst du . . . . . ..
Hier hatte ich eine Schuldverpflichtung (in Händen). Ich habe ihm (einen Teil zurück)-gegeben;
Gold, 1 Mine, ist (der Rest) mein(es) Darlehen(s).

(Betrifft) die Angelegenheiten der Stoffe für mich, die mein Herr mir geschickt hat: Die von dem Anteil des Sohnes des Amā’a (hat) Titatra; 4 gute Stoffe: Buzāzu; 4 gute Stoffe: Asānum; 3 Stoffe: Kūṣum: Š[ūb]ēlum, der Sohn des Zurzur.
Ins[gesa]mt 10 [+ x gute [Stoffe]. Dies ist, (was) ich (mit den Stoffen) getan habe. Mein Darlehen . . . . de[m]
Bēlī’aššur [. . . . ]. . . .. Daß ich das Darleh[en zahlen kann,] habt ihr (das Gold) [nicht] gesiegelt und mir nicht geschickt. Das Gold habt ihr erhalten! Meine Brüder, meine Herren seid ihr!
Umgehend schickt mir (das) Gold! Tut mir doch den Gefallen!
Zu Imdîlum sprich! [Folgendermaß]en Idī’aššur:
[x Sto]ffe, 6 Behälter aus Zinn, 8 schwarze Esel [und deren Geschirr,] x beruische Stof]fe], [. . . . . . ]. . . und hier (?)

[x] Kutānū und 4 kusītum-Stoffe aus Akkad, die ich dem Puzurašš[u]r überlassen habe: Zusammen 80 Kutānū, 4 kusītum-Stoffe aus Akkad, 6 Behälter aus Zinn, 8 Esel und deren Geschirr habe ich gemäß dem Bescheid des Pu[zu]raššur einem Manne. . . . (K) . . . anvertraut; und (d)er wird (die Ware) dir schicken (?).
Hier sind die Esel erschöpft: Entsprechend deinem Bescheid habe ich die Diener beauftraft,
folgendermaßen (sprach) ich: "Bitte! (der Rest ist unverständlich)
Sigel des Inb[i’ištar,] des Sohnes des Sin. [. . . . ] Zu Lāqīpum, des S[ohnes des . . . . .  . ,] und Ṣilladad, [’dem Sohne des . . . . ,] meinen Dienern, sp[rich!]
Folgendermaßen Inbi’ištar. Zu Lāqīpum und Ṣilladad, zu Ṣilladad sprich!
Ich habe dir geschieben, folgendermaßen ich: "Bevor nicht Aššurmalik das Silber für die Stoffe bezahlt hat, sollst du ihm nicht(s) geben und seine Reise soll er nicht antreten."
Du hast ihn das Silber nicht zahlen lassen und hast den Mann freigelassen!
Nun sollst du so handeln: Gemäß den Zeugen hast du . . . . . . . und wir waren achtsam.

Also lasse das Silb[er des E]nbi’aššur und des Hauses [Aššu]rmalik, —Rs um welches mir zustehende Silber entspre[chend] (dem Werte) der Wol[lad]ung ich keine Furcht  habe, sie (den Enbi’aššur und den Aššurmalik) deponieren.
Ich habe dir geschrieben, folgendermaßen ich: "Stoffe für die Bekleidung der Diener im Werte von ½ Seqel, ⅔ Seqel (oder) 1 Seqel kaufe mir und schicke (sie) her!"
Du hast pali’ātum-(Stoffe) im Werte von je 1 Seqel oder je 1½ Seqel mir geschickt.
Ein Lager von früher (gelieferten) Stoffen habe ich nicht (in Händen).
Dies also sollst du tun.
Bis du herkommst, um dich mit mir zu treffen sind die Stoffe, (die) du (mir) auferlegt (hast), vorhanden.
Weder Stoffe, noch Wolle, noch einen Kaufpreis (dafür) hast du (bei mir) gut. Sei achtsam!
Folgendermaßen (läßt) Kasāsā (dir sagen) : "Komm schleunigst her!"
Folgendermaßen Abūšalim an Stelle des Ilī’alum. Zu Aššurimittī sprich!
Folgendermaßen (sprachen) hier die Gläubiger des Aššurištikal und des . . . [. . . . ] . . tili, des Sohnes des Aššurištikal zu Ām[u]raššur, dem Sohne des Sukalli’a:

"10 Minen Silber — die Abgabe war hinzugefügt — , mit seinen Siegeln, hat Aššurištikal, unser Händler, von Purušḫattum nach Kaniš, an das Haus des Ilī’ālum, daß  es (dort) zur Bewachung deponiert werde, schicken (wollen) (?) ; [x Min]en 50 (?) Seqel Silber hast du erhalten.

Ferner, [x M]inen [x Seq]el Silber und den Zins dazu war Pilaḫištar, der Sohn des Aššu[rm]alik, auf Grund einer Doppel-urkunde dem Aššurištikal, unserem Händler, schuldig geworden; das Silber und den Zins dazu hast du erhalten.

2 Minen 9 Seqel Silber und den Zins dazu war Tarāmilī, der Sohn des Palšeni (?), auf Grund einer Doppelurkunde dem Aššurištikal, unserem Händler, schuldig geworden; das Si[lber] und den Zins dazu hast du erhalten, 1 ⅓ Minen 2⅓ Seqel Silber, die ,Drittanteile‘ des Aššurištikal, unseres Händlers, hast du vom bīt kārim erhalten.
15 Stoffe hast du in Zalpa von der Ware des Aššurištikal, unseres Händlers, gekauft; Aššurlamassī, der Sohn des Šūkūbum, hat (sie) deiner Hand übergeben.
6 Stoffe vom Palasttore hat Aššurištikal, unser Händler, dir gegeben.
Dies alles, das Silber unseres Händlers, hast du insgesamt erhalten."
Vor diesen beiden leugne oder bestätige (es).
Unser Händler ist tot; doch nach dem Silber unseres Händler haben wir die Suche aufgenommen.
Du sollst uns nicht Mühe machen; viel Silber sollst du uns nicht ausgeben lassen. (Also) bitte!
Siegel des A[ll]u, des Sohnes des Adūdu; Siegel des Takniš, des Sohnes des Talaš; Siegel des Aššurmalik, des Sohnes des Aššurnādā; Siegel des Šamašbāni, des Sohnes des Šū’ištar.
2 Mine 1¾ Seqel  gutes . . . . . . Silber hat zu Lasten des Allu der (jeweilige) Gläubiger gut.
Vom Amtstage des Ili’a wird er 1 Mine 1¾ Seqel bis zum siebenten Amtstag zahlen.
1 Mine 1¾ wird er is zum zehnten Amtstag zahlen.
Wenn er nach Ablauf seiner Zahlungsfrist nicht gezahlt hat, wird er 1½ Seqel pro Mine als Zins im Monat hinzufügen.
‘Monat der Falschen’ ; Eponymat (aus) der H[an]d des Ṣilūlu.
2 Minen 3½ Seqel gutes . . . . Silber hat zu Lasten des Allu der (jeweilige) Gläubiger gut.

1 Mine 1¾ Seqel wird er bis zum zehnten Amtstag zahlen.
Wenn er nach Ablauf seiner Zahlungsfrist nicht gezahlt hat, wird er 1½ Seqel pro Mine als Zins im Monat hinzufügen.

Ṭāb-šill-Aššur owes Buzāzu 5 minas refined silver.
He will pay 40 weeks from the ḫamuštum of Iddin-abum s. Aššur-rabi, month of Ab-šarrānē, year of Maṣi-ilī.
If he does not pay (on time), he will add 1 1/2 shekels per mina per month as interest.
The house ...

From Imdī-ilum, Enna-Bēlum and Aššur-ṣulūlī to Puzur-Aššur:
From the 245 textiles and those of the transporters of the transport of Amur-Ištar, therein, 3 textiles of the Akkadian type were left in the hosue of your father-in-law in Ḫaḫḫum.
Now, I caused 3 luḫuppu-textiles to enter (the palace) here.
The remainder of your textiles, 239 textiles entered the palace.
Therein, 12 textiles as excise tax.
The palace took 23 textiles as the (tithe?) for purchases.
They will balance 38 textiles to you in the colony office.
They cleared the remainder of your textiles together with those of the transporters, 166 textiles from the transport of Amur-Ištar and they are available.
From the 100 textiles of the transport of Idi-Adad, which entered the palace, the excise was 5 1/2 textiles and they will balance 5/6 shekel silver to you.
The palace took 10 1/2 textiles for the tithe for purchases.
You will balance 18 1/2 shekels silver as losses.
They will balance you 2 textiles in the colony office.
They cleared the reaminder of your textiles, 92 textiles from the transport of Idi-Adad, combined with the (textiles) of the transporters and they are available.
The son of Erraya (Aššur-mālik?) brought his contraband (into the city) to Pūšu-kēn, but his contraband was seized and the palace seized Pūšu-kēn and placed him in jail.
The guards are strong.
The princess/queen sent to Luḫušattiya, Ḫurrama, Šalaḫšua, and her own land concerning the contraband and ENNATUm is established.
Urgent, do not deal in contraband!

If you departed from Timelkiya, I ... you, whatever you sent out, leave it in a good house in Timelkiya and leave one of your trustworthy ṣuḫārum-servants and you yourself leav it and be counseled here.

Also, if anyone tries to get you to agree for even a single shekel of silver for whatever you have, saying "Sell me tin or textiles so that I can smuggle them and I will be responsible.", do not sell!
There, a hand is set in hand against you.
[. . M]inen Silber [vo]n meiner Dop[pel]urkunde, [das] ich dem Puzuraššur [schu]dig war, [habe ich be]zahlt.
[Vor Ḫ]urāṣānum, [vor A]ššurṣulūlī.

Zwei Sack anderthald Krug zur Hälfte Weizen, zur Hälfte Gerste und 3⅔ Seqel 15 Korn Silber hat zu Lasten des Ḫašušman, des Tarḫula und des Šubunaḫšu Addāda gut.
Den Weizen und die Gerste werden sie zur (kommenden) Erntzeit geben.
Das Silber werden sie zur (nächsten) Aussaat zahlen.
Ḫabu’ala und Burka, seine Frau, sind Bürge.
(Betrifft) den Wohlbehaltenen und (Orts)beständigen: er wird zahlen.
⅔ Seqel 15 Korn Silber habe ich der gubabtum-Priesterin als (Betrag) für die Ringe, die sie dem (=für) Aḫištar unter Beschlagnahme gehalten hat.
2 Seqel Silber von dem Gut (?)  des Bēl habe ich im (?) Hause unseres Alâḫum bezahlt.

To Puzur-Aššur from Ilī-wēdāku:
I entrusted 5/6 minas silver, its excise added, to Aššur-baštī.
Witnesses: Kuzīya, Amur-Ištar s. Bala.
2 kutānum textiles are with Ṭābāya.
I gave 3 shekels silver to Urdala for managing.
(I gave) 5 shekels to Bēlānum for management.

5 minas poor quality copper is with Idī-Aššur s. Ḫamḫamtum.

10 shekels silver are with our Aššur-mutabbil.

Pūšu-kēn and Adad-šulūlī seized us and rendered accounts in our presence.

He will go to Waḫšušana and 4 ḫamuštum weeks will pass, then he will deliver the silver and the silver will cross back and forth and the colony at Kaneš will give (Pūšu-kēn?) the ebuṭṭum loan of Adad-šulūlī for this matter and I will give my witnesses before the dagger of Aššur.
Witness: Puzur-Aššur s. Išar-kitt-Aššur.
Puzur-Šamaš s. Šū-Nunu is my partner.
This tablet is entrusted to Il₅-mì-tí s. Šū-Ištar.
Seal of Šū-Išḫara s. Idī-Kūbum.
Seal of Iddin-abum s. Aššur-ṭāb.
Pūšu-kēn (and?) Buzāzu were our partners.

Šū-Ištar said to Aššur-mālik: ... from/after ... Ela? .. separately ... -um took.

To Pūšu-kēn from Tariš-mātum and Ištar-lamassī:
Our dear father and lord, none of the youth should ask you for silver, and you must not release silver to their accounts.
We depend on you!
We paid out 2 minas silver for the plot of Idī-Ištar.
We have heard nothing about Uṣur-ša-Aššur!
We have shipped off all your merchandise.
Our dear father, decide wherever you can salvage his capital.
It is sent(?) to his father.
Decide how much capital you can salvage.
To Pūšu-kēn from Ea-šar:
I wrote to you.
You said, "I will take from the 30 talents of excellent copper."
Because there were no donkeys available, Adad-bāni took 30 talents refined copper to Purušḫattum.
When the donkeys from Šū-Anum's transport arrive, I will rest them one day not two.
I will dispatch them.
There are textiles under the seal of Šū-Kūbum and Iliya. Take up three
š.
To Pūšu-kēn from Lamassī:
When you were staying here, I gave 1 heavy textile to Aššur-mālik.
Also, when he returned, I gave to him 1 kamtum textile and 3 kutānum-textiles.
Why is it that the textiles which I keep sending to you, which he (is supposed to) bring, he does not bring to you?
Let your message come and so inform me.
Also, concerning the textiles about which you wrote, you said, "They are too small. They are no good!"
Was it not according to your request that I made them smaller?
Also, when you wrote me(?), you said, "Raise a 1/2 mina each for your textiles."
I raised it.
Also, Urāni did settle the logs to your representative, concerning the beams he confirmed.
I did not exhaust it.
Also, he took the beams belonging to your brother.
The copper which you gave to him for the beams he did not give at all.
Ilī-bāni brought to the youth a namšuḫam-textile belonging to Aḫaḫa.
Later, I will send a nibrarum-textile to him.
Suetata said to Idī-abim, "I left the tablet? of Ilī-bāni to you."
Idī-abum said: "True. You left it."
In the presence of Išurānum and the son of Kiliya, we siezed Lā-qēpum and we said, "Pay the tin of your dātum-payment."
He said,  "I do not owe anything."
(We said), "Whatever you owe you cannot pay the tin or its purchases.
He said,  "I will pay."
Puzur-Ištar, representative of Puzur-Aššur, seized us against Sabasiya:

Puzur-Ištar stated: "I am questioning you on behalf of Puzur-Aššur. From the goods which were concerning Adad the share ...  and which Šū-Ištar and Il-wedāku delivered (it) to you and Puzur-Šamaš, 2 minas 36 shekels gold belonging to Adad to your debit was not paid. You paid whatever was on your person.

Sabasiya replied, "It is true. From the goods which were set for the share as Adad and the goods which Puzur-Aššur entrusted to Šū-Ištar and Il-wedāku and which they delivered to myself and Puzur-Šamaš, the goods were converted to gold and I owed 2 minas 36 shekels gold. It was weighed out as the share of Adad. I did not pay anything of myself. I paid from the goods a-mi-tim-ma."
The plenary colony assembly at Waḫšušana set for us  (witnesses) concerning this matter and we gave our witnesses before the dagger of Aššur.
Aššur-rabi, Dān-Aššur, Mamaḫer

Pūšu-kēn seized us against Aššur-mālik and Pūšu-kēn said to Aššur-mālik, "You have been prosecuting me about 5 minas silver for 10 days. Come. litigate against me concerning that which I owe in a suit."
Aššur-mālik wrote the words of the oath of the city of our ears.
He said, "They (f.?) will write that for the verdict."??
Pūšu-kēn said, ""It is enough(?)"
For this matter, the colony at Kanesh gave us permission, and we gave our witnesses before the dagger of Aššur.
Witnesses: Lāqēpum s. Izēzam-ilī, Hannanum.
To Pūšu-kēn from Abu-šalim:
I hear that my 'uncle' (maḫā'um) freed the maid of our father.
He must not bring her into the house of our father and cause a quarrel in our father's house.
My dear father, he bring her into the house of our father.
He can send her wherever (else) he likes.
At my departure, I seized Urāni and said to him, "I am going to the City. Give me whatever there is to give."
He said, "I will feed your children."
My dear father, let him give the maid 10 or 20 shekels of silver.
Also, here I have done according to the your message which I brought to Šalim-aḫum.

Amu-Ištar and Tuḫniš seized us and made accounts, copper, both yeilding from makuḫi-textiles and from the kutānum-textiles of his ikrībū-account, Amur-īštar deposited 32 talents 30 minas copper from Wašḫaniya.
He will weigh out the copper in Wašḫaniya.
Amur-Ištar said, "I took it for the z and textiles which I sold to you."
Witnesses: Pūšu-kēn s. Sueyya, Lā-qēpum s. Nabu-bāni, Enna-ZA s. Ennanum.
For this matter, the colony of Kanesh gave us permission, and we gave our testimonies before the dagger of Aššur.
To Pūšu-kēn and Ennam-Aššur from Ḫuṣārum:

Regarding the tin and textiles of the šēpum of Āl-ṭāb which the corresponding amount of the goods which Šū-Kūbum brought to you, my dear father, you and Ennam-Aššur sell there as much tin as they clear, cheap or dear and send the silver to me as soon as possible.
Also, send back Šū-Kūbum.
If the tin and textiles are sold, seal the silver and send it to me.
If the prices there are deflated, let my goods go on to Purušḫattum so that they may raise every mina possible.
Šumī-abiya owes 2/3 mina silver to Aḫ-šalim
From the ḫamuštum of Al-aḫim he must pay.
If he does not pay the word of the colony will be added in interest because of the silver.
Because of the silver Aššur-bāštī will be satisfied.

1 talent tin and its excess weight, 5 kutānum-textiles, under the seal of Šū-Ištar son of Dadānum, and 1/2 black donkey; all this Irma-Aššur drives to you.
From our awītum assestment whatever dātum payments, food charges and wages of the sāridum he is not informing us.
My dear father and lord, sell my tin, as much as arrives, for silver, and send the silver ahead of me.
If my tin is not sold, send 2 minas silver ahead of me and your message know from what day you sent it.
I am written down in the colony office for 3 textiles [(and x shekels)?] silver of the ... .

17 minas 12 shekels of tin which Dān-Aššur paid me just before Kulumaya's departure, seal the fine tin and send it.
Let your message come as to how many textiles you deposited at the colony office.
My dear brother, my dear father, do a favor for me!
I gave 1/2 textile to Ummana when his daughter died.
The 5 shekels silver which Enna-Suen son of Ilī-ālum owes, I will send it to him after he arrives from Waḫšušana.
Witness: Luzina son of Aššur-bāni.
From Šalim-aḫum's four donkeys in the caravan of Atata which acame up, the palace took 1 donkey and Agua received its yeild.
One donkey (brought by) the son of Erraya, which Amur-Ištar took to Purušḫattum, stands to be mine(??).
I gave 1 donkey to Lulu.

One donkey from the transport of Dān-Aššur they took off to Ilabrat-bāni.
3 shekels silver, the nabrītum of the 3 donkeys.

Thereof, the 27 shekels checked (silver) and the 9 shekels (silver) the price of šurum textile, he deducted to me(?) 5 shekels silver, the interest on 5 textiles, and he owes the rest of the silver and its interest.
He will 'check' the silver from the ḫamuštum of Narām-Suen and Ḫanānum brother of Dagāniya.
7 1/2 shekels silver from my lot and interest on 1/2 mina--4 1/2 shekels, comes to 12! shekels.

As for 55 shekels refined silver which Asqudum and Aššur-nādā received in Kanesh and the remainder worth 45 shekels silver which Asqudum received from Iddinnāya, if Asqudum cannot produce the sealed tablet or witnesses to Iddinaya, Asqudum will pay triple for this silver to Iddinaya.
If he does produce a tablet or witnesses, Asqudum will pay the silver in full.
He will negotiate from the beginning of the ḫamuštum of Ilī-bāni for 6 months.
Of the former merchandise:
5 talents of copper, 9 minas for expenses, the transport tariff took up 8 minas.

For 117 textiles: their price was 56 1/2 talents 3 minas (of copper); 23 textiles from Šalatuwar, their price was 4 minas 1/2 shekel of silver; 10 textiles, 1 textile: (for) the  colony office; in all in copper: 74 talents 20 minas.

Thereof 5 talents 15 minas, the price of a black donkey; he cleared 2 1/2 minas less 1 1/2 shekel of silver for me; the proceeds of 10 talents 20 minas of copper transported by Šalim-bēlī--its value in silver: 5 5/6 minas 1 1/2 shekel; thereof he sent 2 minas of silver to Uršu (to my benefit); Aššur-nādā spent 2 1/3 minas 6 shekels, the value in silver of 1/3 mina 6 shekels of gold; 12 talents 28 minas of copper which Ilī-ālum brought into Šalatuwar, I was charged with its value in silver, 5 1/2 minas 2 shekels; thereof Aššur-nādā acquired 5 minas less 4 shekels of silver; as the proceeds of 2 talents of good quality copper (and) his 4 talents 10 minas of copper Amur-Aššur, the packer of Dān-Aššur, brought you 3 minas 4 shekels of silver, including 5/6 mina less 1 shekel of silver, the price of the gold; 1 mina of silver is owed by Puzur-Anna; his tablet is in Amria's house.
I gave x
Tin and textiles (will go?) from Kanesh to Purušḫattum.
Concerning Pūšu-kēn, he has gone overland.
The silver (will go?) from Purušḫattum to Kanesh.
Concerning Aššur-imittī, he has gone overland.
Al-aḫum and Imdī-ilum resolved their matter.
To Pūšu-kēn from Dān-Aššur:
Sabasiya son of Iliš-tīkal owes 12 minas 34 shekels refined silver
His term is past due 4 ḫamuštum-weeks.
Seize him and make him pay the silver and its interest.
As for the silver which I did not send with Enna-Suen, there are no sales for tin or fine copper and the tin is bad quality, so I released them for one or two months to a trusted investor.

Kurub-Ištar must sue Šamaš-tappā'ī.
If Šamaš-tappā'ī and Illum-malik, have sold (their working capitals) then they must discuss with his witnesses.
Nannia, Katatum (and) Uṣup-iškum, (these) men are the judges.
When they ..., I wrote down the kutanu textile which he took.
To Pūšu-kēn from Kurub-Ištar:
Our father owns a share of 2 minas of gold in Šalim-Aššur son of Issu-rīk.
Akkukum the
My dear father, if the man's goods, his caravan, arrive, or if they are late, come to an agreement with the man for as much as you are able.

20 talents tin belonging to Pūšu-kēn, 20 talents belonging to Dān-Aššur, 5 talents belonging to Lā-qēpum son of Iliya, 6 talents belonging to Enna-Suen, 4 talents belonging to Šū-Suen, 6 talents belonging to Idī-Suen, 5 talents belonging to Ilišu-rabi, 8 talents belonging to Atata-- for the caravan of Pūšu-kēn-- altogether 74 talents tin, and 14 sacks (with) 121 textiles, will go.
To Šalim-Aššur and Pūšu-kēn from Kurub-Ištar:
To Šalim-Aššur:
My
My dear father, let neither my brother nor his representatives trick you to give out the silver.

Šuhurpia, Ma[ ... ] and Kurkura owe 10 2/3 minas 5 shekels of silver to Aššur-nādā.
They will pay 3 ḫamuštum weeks from the ḫamuštum week of Šu-Anum and Iliš-tikal.
If they have not paid within their completed term they will add interest at the rate 3 shekels per month per mina.
They are jointly responsible for the silver.

1 sack, 10 minas 49 1/6 shekels silver Aššur-imittī s. Ennānum, 1 bundle of 1 mina 5 shekels silver, the price of the house for my representative, I entrusted all this to Aššur-nādā s. Sutiya and Balṭušar.

1 sack, 6 minas 5 shekels silver beloning to Aššur-imittī s. Ennānum, 1 sack of 12 minas 18 5/6 shekels belonging to Šalim-aḫum, 1 sack 10 minas silver beloning to the sons of Lā-qēpum for Aššur-imittī, I entrusted all this to Šuli-s. Dādum.

Witnesses: Ikūnum s. Samaya, Dān-Aššur s. Šalim-aḫum

He will pay from the ḫamuštum of Šamaš-bāni and Aššuriš-tikal, year Ilišu-rabi, month ab šarrānē.
If he does not pay he will add interest at the rate of 1 1/2 shekels per mina per month.
From Aššur-idī to Pūšu-kēn:
I gave 2/3 minas of silver and its excise to Puzur-Aššur.
Regarding the tablet of Puzur-Ištar of (his) debt to me, which I hold, why are you silent?
For whom are you waiting every day? (?)
Seize him and Ilabrat-bāni so that he writes me and they entrust the tablet with my seal to your representatives in the City.
Wait this day for a tablet.
But watch very (damn) carefully! (OR) But be very careful!
The house of my father is clearing accounts.
I hear that Ilabrat-bāni has decided to come to the city.

We entrusted to Ennam-Aššur son of Šalim-aḫum the 25 minas silver and its shipping charge which Pūšu-kēn entrusted to Buzutaya and Imdī-ilum (i.e. us?) in the presence of Aššūr-imittī, Ennum-Bēlum, and Amur-Aššur.
From Ḫinnāya to Pūšu-kēn:
Here, I have spoken for you.
It is deposited in my account.
After my shipment is with my representatives, I will make accountings a second time.
And I do not hear the full report.
If my šadueti is ḫiatu, when my previous messages, matter.
Elama, Aššur-nādā, and Qarwiya took the 4 talents tin and its tithe from the caravan of Aššur-taklāku.
6 shekels rate for my tin they sent to me.
Now, I hold their instruction tablets.
They must not pay less than a 6 shekel rate for my tin!
My dear brother, because the days become many, take care to have them pay refined silver and send it to me.
Also, send tḫt to my representative to Durhumit so that they clear my instructions and send to me.
For about 8 minas of silver, they sold the  the (goods) of Uṣur-ša-Aššur to Šū-Nunu.
If he gave the silver, they should arrive it?
Let him consume(?) 2 minas gold to me!
To the son of Issu-rīk:
Let him/me send  8 2/3 minas silver and its interst which ...
16 shekels from the shipping charges is owed by Amur-Aššur.

Let him cause Aššur-dān to settle with you.
Amur-Aššur brings you a masium garment.
The son of Danna-il (Taqna-il?), Al-aḫum brother of Qarwiya brings you 2 fine textiles.
Sell them and give their silver to Dān-Aššur.
And as for you, from my own funds add as much as you can and take the silver at the arrival of my instructions.
Pay attention to the matter of Uṣur-ša-Aššur.

8 1/3 minas of refined silver Talia, Ha ... Tarhunu and Arawa owe to Aššur-nādā.

To Puzur-Aššur from Buzazu:
I arrived at Šalatuwar according to my message.
Buyers have not yet entered (the market).
I said, "Let me send so that I can cause them to leave the tin with my copper."
My dear father and lord, take care so that you you send (it) on the day that you read my letter, send as much of my tin as you can and dispatch them with the first caravan.
My dear father, to whom else can I look?
Take care to not delay the boys there overnight.
Give them the caravan.
As for me, I am mṣ' your instructions.
The  animals about which you wrote I will dispatch with the first caravan.
Let your word come as to whether you have come to an agreement about the matter of the wife of the chief of horses.

To Pūšu-kēn:
My dear brother!
You must not trust anyone!
If Aššur-taklāku is not available, take care to inspect the silver, both the leftovers(?) and the interest of my list and clear (these things) and not detain Aššur-emūqī.
Send him here.
I am awaiting him.
If they did not send me anything from Purušḫattum, let your message go with my tablet and yours.
If Aššur-emūqī is delayed, send 10 minas or 20 minas silver with the express messenger.
Regarding the debt of Kuzāri, 40 minas copper.

(We wrote), "We will credit the 2 minas gold to Pūšu-kēn's account."

Šāt-Aššur to Pūšu-kēn:
Concerning the attack (of the disease), the entire house is affected.
If you intend to come to the city, sacrifice to the gods!

Beside you, I have no one else!
Because you did not .... from Belet-ekallin (month i) to Kanwarta (month ix), Kutaya ... check MIchel's translation...

To Itūr-ilī, Innāya, and Aššur-taklāku from Ḫuṣārum:
I wrote to you.

I said, "As for the matter of Kurub-Ištar's and Aḫia's investors, if they come to an agreement settle the matter insofar as you can. However the matter falls out, or whatever they write, let your report come and inform me. Don't try to resolve the matter from there."
Don't you three know that becasue silver is scarce, he will send it from Purušhattum?
To Pūšu-kēn from Puzur-Aššur:

From the silver and gold that Ili-mālik brought, Ili-mālik drives to you 2 talents 20 minas of tin under seals and 110 kutānum-textiles together with 8 fine kutānum textiles and two kamsum-type textiles, 40 minas of 'hand-tin', and 6 black donkeys.
When he departed we did not write the .. and tablet.
We will dispatch the remainder of your goods at the first departure.

We said, "We will make purchases and I will send to you(f.)."

To Iddin-Suen, Aššur-nādā and Ennam-Aššur from Kurara:

I paid 10 shekels to the son of Puzur-Anna.

If you are truly my father, do not make me angry.
Seal (pl.) the silver.

x 1/2 shekels (was) the exit tax.
2 minas 28 1/2 shekels hand tin, its price (in silver was) 11 shekels.

10 talents 50 minas tin and its wrappings, 37 kutānum-textiles, 4 textiles for the boy, x textiles for the tadmiqtum, on 6(?) donkeys [PN brings to you.]

From Aššur-nādā to Pūšu-kēn:
You wrote me.
You said, Ennam-Aššur did not give me the textiles you sent to him.
Send whatever is available so that I can be favorable.
18 textiles ... Išme-ilī, ??? Ennam-Aššur?? his account satisfied, brought to you.
Why is that you refused to confront (him) about the textiles?
You've never done me a favor!
My dear brother, do not disappoint me.
Acquire textiles and act so as to do me a favor.
My dear brother, do not disappoint me.
Do me a favor.
And as for me, wherever there is a favor ...
Hinnaya to Pūšu-kēn:
Recently, I gave 35 minas tin, 2 kusītum textiles, 1 zakium textile and 2 šulupkā'um textiles to Kulumaya.
1 fine textile to my account is the 40 shekels debt of the daughter of Ištar-pilaḫ. (?)
As for Kurub-Ištar son of Šū-Ḫubur, declare his payings at his arrival.
Have him pay the silver, then seal it and send it to me.
Should they deposit silver or textiles, deposit my full share.
Then I will send to you mine with a traveller.
You spoke to me.
You said, "Aššur-ṭāb stays in Waḫšušana and he brought your tin and they gave it to Lulu at an 8 shekel rate and they sent the silver to Aššur-ṭāb."
If it is short, send to me by my youth or Anaḫ-ilī so that they may request and seal the silver and send it (verb tense).
My dear brother, take heed that your message goes to Kunilim, and the he dispatches the youth to me.
Besides you, whom do I have?
From Puzur-Ištar and Idnaya to Ennam-Aššur:
Regarding the copper belonging to Pūšu-kēn, do not come to an agreement with anyone.
From Puzur Ištar:
Let your message come on the (same) day when the copper goes out so that I myself may send the corresponding silver.
From Idnaya:
As for mine, I will send the corresponding silver.
From Aššur-imittī and Šū-Ḫubur to Pūšu-kēn, Amur-šamšī son of Mesar-rabi, and Kurub-Ištar:
2 talents 10 minas tin under seal, 10 minas hand-tin, 4 šurutum textiles, 1 black donkey and his tack--all this Uṣur-ša-Aššur son of Aššur-bēl-awātim drives to you.
If Uṣur-ša-Aššur arrives bound for Purušḫattum, give the tin and textiles to him so that he may convey them to Purušḫattum and convert them to silver and bring the silver in his transport.
To the representatives of Aššur mālik--Pūšu-kēn and Ili-ašranni, thus Šalim-aḫum:
8 'talents' tin under my seal, 32 textiles, therein: 8 kutānum textiles, 4 black donkeys, 2 talents tin, its wrapping, and a donkey send to Aššur-šamšī and Ḫinnaya.
My dear brothers, do not deposit my tin and textiles.
Sell them on credit to a trustworthy merchant, as trustworthy as yourselves.
Do not overvalue one or two months.
Then let your message come.

10 minas copper Libbaya and his partner, 10 minas silver Šū-Ḫabura, 9 minas (silver) Aššur-imittī, 13 minas Abum-ilum s. Abaya, 6 1/2 minas Amur-Ištar s. Iddi-Suen--all this silver there terms are full.
Inspect their tablets and makle them pay the interest according to their days which are past.
My dear brothers, make them pay the silver and seal (and send) it to me with the first departing (traveller).
Dispatch Ili-ašranni and Kudar-ilī to me.
?? To whom with Aššur-mālik Kudar-ilī did not come.  ??
There is not anyone like Aḫum(?) in the colony.
Now, the servant which ?was made?, if he does not with to go with Ilī-ašranni, assist him so that he ks' him and he brings it.

Regarding the 54 minas 45 1/2 shekels silver from the šēpum of Aḫ-šalim which you 'entrusted' on long terms, 58 minas 18 1/2 shekels from the šēpum of Pūšu-kēn, 28 minas 27 shekels from Lulu son of Zukuḫūm, 31 1/2 minas which Aššur-šamši and Ḫinnāya 'entrusted' in Durḫumit, 5 minas from Amur-Ištar for my tin, you (two) wrote me.
You said, "Ḫinnāya will pay it, and our message will go to him."
Thereof, Šū-Suen and the son of Šū-Aššur brought me 31 minas 15 shekels--its
