Ilī-ālum brought me 41 2/3 minas--its
Kurub-Ištar brought me 18 minas 18 shekels.
Total: 147 minas 18 shekels silver which they brought me
The remainder of the silver is 30 minas 33 shekels, those whose terms are past
Don't listen to the interest.
Have the silver paid and send it to me immediately.
In your (pl.) tablet (you said), "7 minas 35 2/3 shekels silver from the shipment of Aḫ-šalim is placed on merchants on 'long' terms.
As for the 31 minas 18 1/2 shekels silver (arising) from the shipment of Aššur-mutabbil and Nūr-Ištar, if their terms are full, have them pay the silver and send it immediately.
As for the silver which Ili-ālim and Kurub-Ištar brought, why has the tablet become too heavy for you(pl.) (to send)?
Don't send that to me.
To Šalim-aḫim and Pūšu-kēn from Al-āḫum, Imdī-ilum and Puzur-Aššur:
Ḫuraṣāum entrusted to us 2 talents, 6 minas tin, 32 textiles together with those for wrappings, and 2 black donkeys.
Amur-Aššur entrusted to us 2 talents 10 minas tin, 30 1/2 kutānum textiles, 4 šurūtum textiles, and 2 black donkeys.
Ilabrat-bāni entrusted to us 23 kutānum (textiles) and 1 black donkey.
From the 4 talents 16 minas of your tin, the excise tax was 8 minas.
We balanced 9 minas 3½ shekels (tin) to Ilabrat-bāni.
We balanced 1 5/6 minas (tin) to Ḫuraṣānum.
The deficiencies were 13 5/6 minas 5½ shekels (tin).
We cleared the remainder of your tin--3 talents, 43⅓ minas, the 85½ kutānum textiles, the 4 šurūtum textiles, and 5 black donkeys.
Therein, we placed 2 talents tin, 32 kutānum textiles, a 10 shekels rate (for) the tin, 15 shekels each for the kutānum textiles--20 minas silver for 25 ḫamuštum weeks.
We placed 1 talent tin, 16 kutānum textiles for 10 minas silver on (another) merchant.
We placed 43⅓ minas tin, 17 kutānum textiles, 2 donkeys for 9 minas 35 shekels (silver) on (another) merchant.
We placed 2 donkeys for 1 mina silver on a merchant.
We placed 1 donkey foal on a merchant for ⅓ minas (silver).
For 3 talents 43⅓ minas tin, 65 textiles and 5 donkeys--40 5/6 (minas) 5 shekels refined silver on trustworthy merchants, not ??the cheating kind??, for 25 ḫamuštum weeks are placed.
Month: Ab-šarrāni (v), Year: Buzuzu (REL 87).
We placed 8 textiles in your account.
Their silver we placed in your account.
1 šurūtum textile (went) into your account.
12 kutānum textiles and 3 šurūtum textiles are the remainder of your textiles.
To Aššur-imittī, thus Pūšu-kēn:
I do not have your tablet concerning the transport of Aššur-ṭāb.
I transfered the 1 talent tin from the transport of Aššur-ṭāb son of Uzariya to Itur-ilī.
(He said) "You promised nothing.
And you will not promise 10 minas to me."
I am the man (of favors).
I will do a favor or I will not do a favor.
In the presence of Aššur-imittī son of Ikuppī-Ištar and Ememe son of Azutaya, they brought down your tin and textiles from the palace and they are available.
They are depositing for 1 minas shares (at the?) kārum office and they will set 1½ minas each at accountings.
I paid out (for you) from my own funds.
They will announce/call out/have accountings in four months.
Make your decision.
Because there is much tin and it is fine, we will sold on credit what we could.
For that purpose I deposited tin.
To whom shall your breast turn (other than) to both of us?
You will say, "Give the silver to Pūšu-kēn or let him collect the silver."
To Aššur-imittī son of Ennānim, thus Pūšu-kēn:
Your awītum valuation is 5 talents 20 minas.
The dātum tax up to Kaneš is 5 2/3 minas at a 5 shekel rate.
A dātum assessment fell at 30 2/3 minas (tin?) .
The head-tax on the drivers was 15 shekels.
The tašiatum of the ŠA.TU was 1/2 mina.
The AŠ-a-dum feed of the drivers was 1/2 mina.
The excise-tax of the palace was 8 minas.
The deficiencies of your packs (and your hand tin?) was 11 1/3 minas.
X from 4 talents 40 minas together with your hand tin- 51 minas 15 shekels was expended.
I deducted it and they cleared 3 talents 48 minas and 45 shekels of your tin.
Thereof, Ilī-ālim took 1 talent.
Lulu took 1 talent 2 minas 15 shekels.
At a 9 shekel rate, your silver was 6 minas 55 shekels.
Thereof, I gave Kurub-Ištar 7 2/3 shekels for the shipping charges.
The remainder of your silver is 6 minas 40 shekels.
Kurub-Ištar brings you 1/3 shekels under my seal.
1 talent 46 minas of tin which they cleared, is in my charge.
From your 10 kutānum textiles, both the excise tariff and the purchases (tithe) tariff, they cleared 9 textiles.
Then 8 šurūtum textiles from the wrappings a deposited at the colony office to your account.
Aššur-rē'ī deposited the remainder.
From the 5 1/2 minas silver which I owe, 2/3 minas is a fine.
Both that of the 6 shekels of your tin and your textiles I paid (to/at) the colony office.
4 2/3 minas 4 shekels (from my own funds?) is the remainder of your silver.
There was a "depositing" at the colony office and (to?) it I withheld your silver.
(I said), "The šuruniʾum will not *drink water from their backs."
To Puzur-Aššur, Kulumaya, Amur-Ištar and Amur-ilī: Thus Ilī-nādā:
I heard that you received silver from Dadaya.
I heard that:
You (pl.) received silver from Dadaya.
Get rid of this level sentence
Since you received the silver, travelers have come once or twice.
But you have not sent me the silver.
My dear brothers, take care to send the silver with the first (traveler).
Whether you received the payment in full or it has produced interest, let your full report come immmediately.
If you have allowed the interest to accrue do not overvalue the goods which Arsiah brought to you until you have already __ the silver.
1 mina silver belonging to my  ikrībumistherein.
Regarding what I weighed out, send me silver for oil and the price of fine oil soon!
To Imdi-ilum, ...-a, and the merchant from Pūšu-kēn:

1 1/3 minas of gold and 10 minas of silver belonging to the merchant which he gave (at a rate of) 1 minas of gold at 8 1/2 shekels each is its value - 8 1/2 minas of  - 1/3 minas of gold - 8 5/6 minas shekels each it values 2 1/2 minas (silver)  - 2 1/2 minas 3 1/2 shekels -- all together 21 mians 3 1/2 shekels of silver - together with 10 minas (of silver)  - thereof 52 1/2 shekels (of silver)  its excise, and 21 shekels  shipping -- 10 shekels exit-tax the remainder of the silver 19 1/2 minas 7 1/2 shekels.
3 talents 37 1/2 minas tin at 14 1/2 shekel (rate) its value 15 mians silver, 3 talents 15 mians tin under seal (with) 12 minas hand tin is sold.

6 textiles for wrappings - their value 1 1/2 minas 1/2 shekel, 1 1/2 black donkeys - their value 36 shekels, 2 1/2 shekels (for) their gear, 1 shekel for their fodder, the remainder of the silver  - 3 1/3 minas 1 1/2 shekels - thereof  1/3 minas is poor quality (silver).
From Pūšu-kēn, the representative(s) of Puzur-Aššur, and Sueyya to Puzur-Aššur:
We checked the 19 talents of refined copper under seals which Ea-šar (brought), and it was deficient 13 2/3 minas.
Thereof, they brought 1 talent 40 minas of poor quality copper from the previous and former washed copper.
We checked the 7 1/2 talents of poor quality copper under seals which Ea-šar (brought), and it was deficient 10 minas.
All this Ea-šar brought.
3 talents of 'black' copper are placed in his copper.
They brought 2 talents of refined copper which he deposited in Walama and we checked it and it was deficient 1 mina.
20 minas of poor quality (copper) are deposited in the previous caravan-enterprise.
We checked the 10 talents 30 minas of poor quality copper under seals which Kurara and Šū-Bēlum (brought), and it was deficient 12 minas.
Your representatives brought 52  textiles from Waḫšušana.
Thereof, 30 kutānum-textiles are deposited to Pūšu-kēn at a rate of 9 1/4 shekels (of silver) and he has not yet paid the silver.
Idī-Aššur drove here 48 kutānum-textiles.
Total of your textiles is 148 textiles which arose from the transport of Idī-Aššur.
Enna-Suen son of Elāli is bringing you 20 minas silver under our seals.

We will convert to silver the copper, the textiles, and the outstanding claims and assets which you left like gentlemen, and we will clear your silver from the cargo of Dān-Aššur and we will send your silver to you.
According to your instructions your donkeys are put to pasture.
Your servant is well.
To the investors, Šū-Ḫubur, and my representatives, from Pūšu-kēn:
I requested a 3-year term from the god.
Thus I said, "Let me go."
Let me clear my assets (bûlātum) and I will go out.
Also, let me establish much before you (??).
Šū
Also, you (pl.) were in agreement.
As for me, I did not come before(?) him.
I said, "I will not wait 5 years. Let me go until the term I asked of the god and let me clear my assets."
To my merchants which I 'carry' 2 and 1/3 you did not ...
He wasted much silver.
He is not planted (firm? mature?) and I do not want to name him.
I said (to myself), "As soon as they go, the merchant will release every shekel of silver to them and then they will gather mine as much as possible.
May Aššur and your (pl.) god witness (that) I have been deprived of 2 talents of silver!

My dear lords, if you will, judge how much excise tax the houses of my investors will exact and seal a taḫsistum-tablet stating that my maškattum can continue for 3 more years and so that they may not seize the silver and write to me your kind words through my servant so that I can gather every shekel of my bulātum before the harvest and (...)
To Aššur-imittī and Šū-Ḫubur from Pūšu-kēn:
I wrote 28 minas 48 shekels silver at the colony office.
For this silver I both weighed out your(pl.) silver and sold textiles.
I weighed out 12 minas 49 shekels silver from the silver of Aššur-imittī.
They (the colony office) initiated a pouring in units of 1 mina of silver and I weighed out 2 minas of silver and I placed 1 minas-its
Altogether, 28 minas 48 shekels silver you gave.
The dātum-assessment came to 15 minas each and you will be refunded 1 mina 12 shekels silver.
I will take half from (each of) your (pl.) silver.
To
Why is it that Aššur-imittī wrote me saying: "I will take the silver and its interest from your silver."
As for your half of the silver, your brother is satisfied.
If you do not satisfy (your half), I myself will satisfy (the silver of) Aššur-imittī. With regard to the 15 minas silver, I will take your share, wherever it is, from your silver.
As for myself and Imdī-ilum, we cleared you of obligations at accountings.
We weighed out 6 minas silver, (the amount for) your clearance of obligations, from the price of your tin and textiles.
If you make a deposit, they will assess you a
If you will take responsibility, let your message come and from the day which we weigh out the silver, you will take 1 shekel of silver interest (per mina per month) in the colony office.
Satisfy (the silver) a month. I (already) pressed the colony, saying, "Let them stand for 1 1/4 man."
They did not agree with me. I returned, saying, "Let them stand for a man and a half."
They said, "Are we more 'men' than  them?"
On account of these things, I am delaying Uṣur-ša-Aššur.
To Puzur-Aššur from Buzāzu:
When I was freed up (deported?) to go to Kanesh, I deposited tin, belonging to both you and I, with Ilī-wēdāku.
After I returned from Kanesh, against the will of the god, the bed seized me.
To Puzur-Aššur from Ilī-wēdāku:
Regarding the tin of Iddin-abum about which you wrote, becasue it was(the time of?) their harvest and (becasue of) the price of his share, I did not want to open the tin.
To Puzur-Aššur: Thus Ilī-wedāku:
To Puzur-Aššur fom Aḫ-šalim:
Ikuppiya brought 6 talents tin.
We keep getting reports about the price of tin in Purušḫattum.
Come and send out as much of your tin as (has arrived?) so that you buy a shekel of silver.
To Alāhum, Ememe and Aššur-taklāku from Aššur-nādā:
I hear that Ṣiriā's son has left for the City.
Why is it that Šalim-Aššur's servants and other travellers have come here twice, but no message from you has arrived?
Ask the maid how much grain has come in.
Send me word.
If you wish to have barley, then buy for up to 1/2 mina of silver.
Send me word about every single shekel of silver which has accrued to you both from Durhumit and from here, where you will entrust it and the month in which it left your hands.
Ninni and Huluba have robbed me, so fill my horn with good quality oil.
To Imdī-ilum from Idī-Adad, Annali and Puzur-Ištar:
To Uzuwa, Mazāya, Šumī-abiya, Aššur-mālik, Šū-Anum, Aššur-imittī, and Amur-Ištar, from Ilī-imittī:
Amur-Aššur, Šū-Anum, Aššur-imittī, and Amur-Ištar bring to you 4 1/6 shekels extremely fine iron under my seal.
Let them take the profits for Amur-Ištar and Šū-Anum.
Write in your (pl.) report how much iron is sold.
From Aššur-nādā and Ilī-ālum to Aššur-taklāku:
You brought 18 kutānu-textiles, 15 Akkadian textiles, 1 black donkey, 9 1/3 minas 9 shekels of tin from our votive offerings, (and) 34 2/3 minas of tin from the votive offerings of Ahaya.
To Alāhum and Aššur-taklāku from Aššur-nādā:
Whatever silver and gold they will send to you from Durhumit, add that to what (I owe) on goods entrusted to me, and if Ilī-ālum (is there), then certainly it is agreed.
Hannānum son of Ikuppiya, grandson of Ikua, is on his way with 10 minas of refined silver that belongs to us both.
Deposit its import duty and its transport tariff (with money taken) from my silver or from the price of my textiles, and let the amount go for us both.
Dispatch the servants who have arrived with Saher-ilī.
From Aššur-idī to Amur-Ištar, Al-āḫum, Ilī-ālum and Aššur-taklāku.
Uṣur-ša-Aššur has brought to you 2 talents 10 minas of tin under seal and 38 textiles.
The wages of the driver are paid.
Do not give him anything.
In my previous letter I wrote to you:
"Give (the goods) to Ilī-ālum."
Do not give him anything.
He took much tin from his own caravan.
Out of my textiles, take those of lesser quality and deposit them as my share on my account.
Give the remainder of the textiles and 2 talents of tin to Aššur-taklāku and let him bring that to wherever there is even a small profit for me.
If he is absent, send (the goods) to him wherever he is staying.
If he is on a journey, well, then entrust my tin and textiles witn a trustworthy agent in commission on fixed terms.
The agent must be reliable!
Do not attach importance to terms of one or two months.
To Ili-ālim: Send me the rest of the previous silver shipment, 2 minas as soon as possible.
Clear the goods from your own caravan, set out and come here.
This tablet is late(?)...
From Hinnaya to Aššur-nādā:
To Pūšu-kēn from Šū-Ištar:
Silver is scarce in Waḫšušana.
I siezed Šū-Kūbum and he sent (some?) to Šalatuwar.
He said, "Let my servants arrive, then I will pay you the silver."
His servants arrived, I caused him to pay (the silver), and I send it to you.
Ea-šār did not want to pay the silver (he owed).
He said, "In ten days I will clear my own funds and I will personally go."
I spoke to him there.
I said , "May I cause you to stand for it after that."
You had said, "Do not allow him to stand later. He does not want to pay the silver."
My dear father and lord, write so that they sell fleeces in Luḫusattiya so that they send the silver ahead of you.
Let your message come as to how much silver they send to you.
Do not give a single shekel of silver to the sons of Amur-Ištar.
They sold my lapis and took the silver.
To Alāhum and Aššur-nādā from Iddin-Suen:
We are well.
Also my goods are well.
We have just left Timelkia.
To Šalim-aḫum from Lā-qēpum and Ili-ālum:
They took 4 1/4 kutānum-textiles and a šurum-textile from the 6 1/2 talents tin under seals 20 šurum-textiles together with wrappings, 85 kutānum-textiles which you gave to Ilī-ašranni.
They refunded 2 shekels silver.
The palace took 8 kutānum textiles as your tithe.
Then you balanced 2 shekels silver.
They took 1 šurum textile for the remainder of your textiles-72 3/4
They repaid 3 shekels silver.
The remainder of your
From your 6 1/2 talents tin, they took 12 minas tin as excise.
Losses were 9 2/3 minas.
Ilabrat-bāni took 6 1/3 minas tin.
He is not here.
(Everything?) from the 50 minas 5 shekels hand tin, 4 silas high quality oil, 1/3 minas tin and 5 shekels silver which you sent to Abitipan is exhausted.
We balanced 9 minas tin to Ilī-ašranni.
The remainder of your tin is 5 talents 53 minas tin.

Thereof, 2 talents 59 minas, at a 7 shekel rate, 20 kutānum-textiles at 1/2 mina each, 10 šurum-textiles at 10 shekels each--the total of your silver: 38 minas 4 1/4 shekels, he (Ilī-ašranni) entrusted to Puzur-Anna s. Elāli.
Thereof, he will pay 28 minas in 50
10 minas 4 1/4 shekels he will pay in 45
2 talents 14 minas 10 shekels tin, at a 7 shekel rate, 20

He gave 8 kutānum-textiles and 3 šurum-textiles to us.
The palace took for purchases (tithe) 5 very fine kutānum-textiles and we deposited 1 2/3 minas in the accounts.
In exchange for 2 textiles he (Ilī-ašranni) gave us 7 1/2 shekels less 6 1/2 grains gold and 5 shekels silver.
The remainder of your
Their (the kutānum textiles) value in silver at 1/3 mina silver each, and with 10 shekels silver each for the šurum-textiles, is 5 5/6 minas silver.
The remainder of your tin is 39 minas 50 shekels.
Its value in silver is 5 minas.
That of the remainder of your kutānum-textiles, your šurum-textiles, and of the remainder of your tin, 10 5/6 minas silver is placed on the debit of Ilī-išranni.
It's tablet stating 10 1/3 minas silver and separately of 1/2 mina silver is written.
Month of Kuzalli, eponym year of Šudāyā son of Ennānum (REL 82 X).
He will add 1 1/2 shekels per mina per month.
Five donkeys of Ili-ašranni's transport died.
To Aššur-nādā from Iddin-Ištar:
After I arrived in Durhumit I received 10 talents of copper from your outstanding claims.
Now, I shall await your orders there.
From  Šūmī-abiya to Abela and Ennam-Bēlum:
Imdī-ilum is bringing you 1 mina and 1 shekel
I owe 9 5/6 minas silver to Imdī-ilum.
Sell the gold (for silver) and weigh out the silver to Imdī-ilum.
Write the remainder of the silver to me so that I send it from here.
If (it is his journey?) borrow (the silver) on interest and ...
To Pūšu-kēn, thus Šū-Ištar:
I am setting out from Širmuin.
In addition to the silver of the transport of Kulumaya and Imkuwa, seventeen donkeys go with me: (carrying) 10 talents 50 minas tin under seal and 300 kutānum textiles together with 10 fine textiles.
I will select one hundred textiles in Ḫaḫḫum, fine (ones).
I will exhaust every 'available' shekel of silver and I will arrive.
Let your instructions come quickly to me.
Inform me.
Also, as for myself, my ten fine textiles which I am carrying to you. inform me.
Send two minas silver ahead of me.
I will take care to arrive (in time).
From Kurub-Ištar and Kikkulānum to Puzur-Ištar:
To Aššur-nādā from Aššur-taklāku:
Take action for me there with respect to two pairs of open sandals, bronze nails worth 5 shekels of silver plus the tablet that Aššur-lamassī, the son of Alāhum, entrusted to Aššur-tāb.
I searched all my own things and those of the servants, but it is gone.
Ask the servants there and return the bronze nails and the tablet to Aššur-tab, and sent me word here.
Ask Minusilka.
To Šāt-Aššur from Aššur-mālik:
I am well.
Let not your heart be troubled.
Please, on the day that you read my letter, write to me about your well-being and the well-being of the household so that I do not worry.
Idī-Suen brings you a šitrum-textile under my seal.
Ili-mālik, the servant of Ikuppiya, bring you 2 ox-hides(?).
You wrote me.
To Pūšu-kēn from Kulumaya and Kurub-Ištar
From Kulumaya
As soon as the merchandise of Dān-Aššur ...
I spoke to you.
I said, "Here are the 6 kutānum-textiles for Šāt-Aššur."
The textiles do not belong to Šalim-aḫum's daughter; rather, the textiles belong to Kurub-Ištar.
My name is on the fringe of the textiles.
Ilabrat-bāni is not informed.
They wrote a tablet of the merchant for Dān-Aššur.
His textiles, they are those from Kurub-Ištar.
To Pūšu-kēn from Kurub-Ištar:
My dear father, my dear lord, take heed to give the textiles to Šalim-Aššur.
If he does not want to accept them, speak to him before two witnesses and send your message.
Also, the textiles which Dān-Aššur owes, are to my name.
Send the textiles (brought by) Qarwiya's packer and the tin of Amur-Aššur son of Sukkalliya.
From Pūšu-kēn to Waldi-ilum and Abaya:
To Waldi-ilum:
Idi-abum brought 20 textiles.
At 7 1/4 shekels each, their yeild in silver was 3 minas 1 1/4 shekels.
Thereof, Idī-abum brought to you 1/2 minas silver silver.
I gave 5 shekels silver to the accounts of Idī-abum.
I gave 1 mina 10 shekels silver to Puzur-sadūʾē.
The remainder of your silver, 21 1/4 shekels, ...
(As for PNf?) her silver is cleared in full to you.
To Pūšu-kēn and Šū-Ištar from Aššur-bēl-awātum:
Šū-Ištar brings to you 1 textile.
My dear father, approach him.
Šū-Ištar (also) brings you 1 SILA of top quality oil.
6 minas tin, when he departed, I gave it to Idī-Ištar son of Aššur-mālik.
If you are my lords, make him give it and send it to me.
To Pūšu-kēn, from Aššur-šamšī, Puzur-Ištar, and Aššur-mālik:
Puzur-Šamaš brings to you 23 1/3 minas silver of Šū-Nunu's sack under our seal.
Keep your ears open.
To Pūšu-kēn from Šubultum:
Dān-Aššur brings to you 7 kutānum-textiles under my seal.
They did not make known the dātum-charge and excise.
If you are my brother, send the youth to me with the first travelers.
From Buzutaya and Ennum-bēlum to Pūšu-kēn:
Regarding the 10 minas silver which Imdī-ilum paid to us, Amur-Ištar sent 6 minas 57 shekels from Durḫumit.

We took from your outstanding merchandise 3 minas 3 shekels for payments, 2 minas 53 shekels for Innaya son of Ammurāya, 2 minas 32 shekels belonging to Aššur-imittī, 3 minas checked silver with the 'natives'.
Thereof, 15 shekels silver (went) to Pala and the priest of Tibnum, 3 shekels silver for sickles and the half-pack.
Total: 28 minas 3 2/3 shekels which we took from your outstanding merchandise.
We (still) needed 2 minas 36 shekels and we borrowed it for you on interest.
We will (add) it from the yield of your silver.
In sum, your silver is 30 minas 39 1/6 shekels.
Il-bāni brings you 30 minas silver under our seals.
We gave 1/2 minas silver to his share, 1 shekels to his sacrifice(?), 5 1/3 shekels silver to Kissē.
According to your instructions, we will clear the remainder of your outstanding merchandise and we will send you your silver.
To Aššur-nādā from Šarrat-Ištar:
Zuba brings [x] textiles to you.
1 belt for you, 1 belt for ...
Sell the 4
The undergarment is for the maid in Kaneš.
2 textiles cost 37 minas of copper.
I sold 1 textile for silver ....
Kurub-Ištar ... is deposited with you.
I have said nothing to him.
Set out and come.
All this Zuba brings to you.
1/2 mina 5 shekels of silver Ennam-Aššur brought me.
5 shekels of silver and 3 shekels of gold Puzur-Ištar brought me.
5 shekels of silver and 5 minas of copper Ṭāb-ṣill-Aššur brought me.
I shall love your maid who is with you in Kaneš.
To Innāya, Inaḫ-ilī, ... from Šu-Ištar ...
To Pūšu-kēn from Lamassī:
You wrote.
You said, "Aḫu-waqar and Ea-šār are bringing you 5 minas wool."
They did not give me anything!
Ea-šār said,  "I will make a textile for him myself."
Urani brought you 8 textiles.
I will send to you that which they took out 1/2 mina (?) with Ea-šār.
As for that which Urāni brought to you, earlier, why did you write me, "...?."
While you were there, we have been (haunted?) by your ba
Let them ...
When you send the leather bag, put some wool (in it).
The girl is growing up, so come and place her on the lap of Aššur.
Kulumaya brings you 3 heavy textiles and 6 kutānum textiles.
Aššur-mālik brings(?) brought (?) you 1 heavy textile and 5 kutānum textiles and Ea-šār gave me 2 shekels silver worth of wool.
Aḫu-waqar brought me (only) 1 shekel (of silver worth of wool).
From Lā-qēpum, Asqūdum and Kurub-Ištar to Aššur-nādā:
Aššur-šamšī brought 2 talents 10 minas of tin under your seal, plus 4
We paid 26 shekels aside to the office of the colony.
We shall sell the rest of your tin, 2 talents 6 5/6 minas 4 shekels of tin belonging to you, and we shall send you the silver.
In accordance with your letter Aššur-šamši's donkey will lead it to you.
From Ilabrat-bani to Uṣur-ša-Ištar:
Kurara s. Abu-šalim brings 10 shekels silver to the sister of our father under my seal.
I entrusted the silver of your revenues to him.
My dear brother and friend, you and Amur-ilāi send to him so that he does not give the silver to anyone.
Let him bring up 1 abarnīum for my clothing.
My dear brothers take heed to send to him.
Establish the silver for Tariš-mātum.
Why must I constantly be writing?
Do me a favor.
From Ilya and Lāqēp to Idī-Ištar:
To my representatives and Nini, specifically to Nini, from Aššur-mutabbil:
If there is any silver anywhere, raise it from my outstanding claims.
From Aššur-mutabbil to Kunanniya:
Wherever you can ..., set the tablets which Nazi and Ili-bāni they brought to you and entrusted to you, and send (them) to me.
To Kuzu:
Here, my mother has taken a man (as husband).
To Šū-Bēlim and Kuzu, from Zuli:
To Kuzu:
Do not come to me until you have sold the maid.
From Šalim-Aššūr to Pūšu-kēn:
As for the silver which Urani and PN brought, I bound 4 talents tin on 2 donkeys, and they are driving (them) to you.
I purchased textiles and I will send them with the next (departure).
Concerning the house of PN which is next to ...
To Pūšu-kēn from Lamassī:
Make known the silver which you gave to Iliš-tīkal for purchasing grain.
Iliš-tīkal did not buy grain for us.
From the investors, Šū-Ḫubur, Aššur-bāni, and Šalim-Aššur to Pūšu-kēn:
You wrote to your investors.
Set my term at three years.
Your investors are in agreement.
Anything ...
Let your message come.
Do not fear whatsoever.
.... are in agreement.
... terms ... which you wrote ... they agree with you.
To Pūšu-kēn and Aššur-imittī from Adad-ṣulūlī
Here Pūšu-kēn treated me harshly and he ... to my fund ...
Write down ...
Deposit it.
Let Ikuppi-Aššur give 1 mina of silver to you (pl.).
Write to me as much as you need so that I may send it to you.
To Pūšu-kēn from Lamassi:
Kulumaya brings you 9 textiles.
Idī-Suen brought you 3 textiles.
Ela did not want to take textiles.
Idī-Suen did not want to take 5 textiles.
What is this that you keep writing me?
What man staying in your house is going about disparaging the textiles?
As for me, I try my best to make textiles and send them to you so that every caravan trip will bring 10 shekels silver in your house!
To Innāya from Mannum-bālum-Aššur:
My dear father and lord, there watch after my goods.
To Aššur-rēʾī, Pūšu-kēn, Ennam-Aššur, Kurub-Ištar, and Aššur-mālik from Šū-Ḫubur:
51 kutānum-textiles, 1 šurum-textile ... 10 minas hand-tin, 2 donkeys and their gear ...
From Šalim-aḫum to Pūšu-kēn:
You wrote me.
You said, "At accountings I will assist/stand in place of you. Also, you will pay the debt to the city from our accounts."
If you wish, do not stand.
In your assistance, your account ... I took and I gave for one or two and as many textiles as were to be given ... mine ...
... shares? one or two which I placed/established, these accountings did not pay.
Concenring the boy, if you have made up your mind, ... to brother and partner ...
To Innāya from Šamaš-ṭāb:
On the day that Ikuppīya arrives, he must not stay a single day.
Dispatch him to Waḫšušana.
With regard to my textiles which are there, my dear father and lord, as much the textiles were sold for silver, seal and send the silver to me.
Winter overtook us and the caravan is stalled...
The caravan ...
Your consignment and donkeys are well.
Here the donkeys will dispatch one or two at a time from Ḫaḫḫum to Timelkiya.
From Šalim-aḫum to Pūšu-kēn:
... x minas 10 shekels ... Pilaḫ-Aššur and Buṣiya owe me.
I myself hold the sealed tablet of their debt.
My silver is bound to the head of their reliability(?)!
They will pay 20 ḫamuštum-weeks after REL (?) II.

Ušur-ša-Aššur took 1 minas silver-the share of our father, 1 mina-my share, and 30 minas wool-worth 28 minas 53 1/2 shekels from the caravan of Pūšu-kēn in Karpata and Al-āḫum wrote his tablet.
Al-āḫum holds his sealed tablet, which will go to the interest.

1 mina silver-beʾulātum, 7 shekels silver-price of the kusītum-garment, 1 black donkey which Idī-Ištar left, and 40 minas ṣaḫirum-copper-the remainder of my copper--all this is with Aššur-idī son of Mumulānum.

A copy of a sealed tablet that is sent overland.
To ... Ennam-Aššur, Usānum, and Addu, from Ennum-Aššur.
I took 40 minas weri-copper of the dead man, a fifth of your share.
Amur-Ištar is written down(subj.?) (for?) 180 minas as the price of the fine weri-copper at the colony office.
Thereof, I myself took 78 minas 15 shekels.
Usānum took 100 (minas) weri-copper at the colony office, the price of the fine copper.
You are satisfied with regard to your weri-copper.
150 minas weri-copper, as much of your share in the colony office which I took, I gave to Usānum and Adu.
Addu took 18 minas from the 250 minas.

Šumma-libbi-Aššur and Adad-ṣulūlī seized us and we brought their dispute to an end:
(as for) the 1 5/6 minas of silver which Šumma-libbi-Aššur owed to Adad-ṣulūlī, Adad-ṣulūlī has been satisfied with the silver;
Adad-ṣulūlī's representatives will give his certified debt-note to Šumma-libbi-Aššur and it will be destroyed.
(As for) the 1 mina 1 shekel of silver which Adad-damiq had as claim on Dadaya son of Tilia, Šumma-libbi-Aššur took that silver.
The plenary assembly in Wahšušana gave us for these words, and we gave our testimony before the dagger of Aššur.
In the presence of Ahu-waqar (and) Uṣur-ša-Aššur, Puzur-Aššur son of Išar-kitti-Aššur was our partner.

The chief of the city seized us against Ennam-Aššur son of Anninim and the chief of the city said, "Unfortunately Suaeyya has changed. Did Sueyya give to you 40 minas silver under his seal for nabšum or not?"
Before these men, our seed?, the chief of the city myself and the the extensive assets I requested??

Ennam-Aššur said, "you filled? and Ikūn-pīya when Sueyya asked, on that day the governor asked, he established. To the governor and my lord, do not carry my matter concerning Pūšu-kēn, I myself?, to general assembly ...."
Concerning these matters the large and small assembly of Purušḫattum gave to us and we gave our testimonies before the dagger of Aššur.
Winesses: Bēlum-bāni son of Naram-Su(en), Idī-Suen son of Ennānum.
He will pay 2 months from the head of the month Teʾinātum.

As for 50 minas silver which Kūziya and Sueyya owed to Ennam-Aššur and their tablet was sealed and bound upon their head, for 50 minas silver (becasue of) this tablet, Ennam-Aššur s. Anninum will not return to Sueyya s. Pūšu-kēn whatsoever.

From Šalim-aḫum to Pūšu-kēn:
You wrote to me.

“I sent the tin of Kuzari’s transport to Purusḫattum when he arrived.  I expect the silver in 5 days.  On the day you read this tablet, purchase 45m silver worth of tin for our common property and let you silver be thus disposed.”
I purchased the tin and Puzur-Aššur transports it to you.
In addition to the silver from Kuzari’s transport, send to me that which you entrusted to Aššur-idi’s son with the first departer.
According to your tablet: “When Dan-Aššur arrives, I will set off to Purushattum myself and the goods, both mine and yours, I will clear and in my transport will deliver (it) to you.”
Apart from the the goods between us and that of Dan-Aššur’s transport, and Kulmaya and Idi-Suen’s transport, from your transport, my dear brother, you did not leave me any silver.

So that I will not be put to shame in the city gate, make some deposits to the colony office in your name (to) my account as previously, so that I will not have to balance anything at accounting time.
Šalim-aḫum to Pūšu-kēn:
Ela brought 16 minas silver.
Idi-Suen brought 16 minas silver.
Thereof, 2/3 minas 'inspected' silver, a bag which Idi-Suen brought, I opened in the presence of Kulumaya, and
20 2/3 shekels silver were deficient.
The lumps? were too large.
It must not bear it in the repeated reception.
I gave 3 1/3 shekels for the nisḫat nisḫatum.
I paid 10 minas 54 1/6 shekels for the goods which Aššur-taklāku transported.
130 minas tin under seal, and 10 minas hand-tin, the silver price was 10 minas 4 2/3 shekels.
10 textiles, they were valued at 33 1 /3 shekels (each).
The donkey and its feed together cost 17 shekels.
And (I gave?) 2 shekels silver to Ela(?)
The gear for the donkey was 2 shekels (silver).
The exit tax was 5 shekels.
1 heavy textile apart belongs to Aziya.
Ela brings all this to you under my seal.
The remainder of you silver was 9 minas 36 1/2 shekels.
2 talents 7 minas tin under seal, 9 minas hand-tin, at a rate of 14 5/6 shekels, their (price in) silver was 9 minas 10 shekels.
The price of the donkey was 1/3 minas (silver).
The exit tax was 5 shekels.
The gear for the donkey was 1 shekels (silver).
Kulumaya brings you all this under my seal.
The silver from the transport of Ela and Idī-Suen is exhausted.
I did not give the wages of a driver to Kulumaya.
Kulumaya brings you 1
Ela brought 1/2 minas silver corresponding to Iluwa.
I gave 1 2/3 shekels for the excise.
At a rate of 13 2/3 shekels, He put 6 minas 33 shekels tin its package in your sack.
Kulumaya brings this to you.
To Innā from Mannum-bālum-Aššur
Why did you write me in anger?
You said: "I sent you a letter, but you paid no attention to my letter, and you did not return me your missive."
I sent you a letter, but you paid no attention to my letter, and you did not return me your missive.
From Hinnaya to Aššur-nādā:
I gave you 5 2/3 minas of silver and you sent it down to the City.
Since you claim that you do not administer a joint-stock capital, you offered the tin and the  donkey to Ištar-pilah.
Why have you booked me for transportation costs and a donkey driver?
It is now two years ago but the agreed amount for the silver has not been reached yet;
To Iddin-Suen, from Ḫinnāya:
From Ḫinnaya to Pūsu-kēn;
Concerning the matter of the son of Lā-qēpum about which you wrote, the investors of Lā-qēpum took their silver.
Also, if Kunilum laid on him anything there, let his tablets be strong so that I can collect the silver here from his 'holdings'.
Take care that when you read my tablet you send your message.
We took the copper and we gave/deposited it for silver against the arrival of Kulumaya.  ???
We have done according to your message and we will dispatch your 'youth.'
The son of Dannum-ilum brings you 5 white garments.
From Šalim-aḫum to Pūšu-kēn:
Concerning the matter of Ilabrat-bāni in which you entrusted to him, you wrote me and in your message: "I sold the goods in Amurrum and I took my silver."
The remainder of the silver is 51 1/4 shekels.
Regarding the remainder, I wrote to you.
I said, "Let him weigh it out to you and give his tablet to him."
Five or six of your tablets have arrived.
As for these, why did you not write in your tablet that I am paid in full?

6 1/3 minas tin--its price in silver: 1 mina 3 shekels; a mal'aītum kusītum-textile and 1/2 a kutānum-textile--their price in silver: 35 shekels; 3 textiles for my votive fund; and Aššur-mālik son of Azuza brought him 1 textile for the girl along with his textiles.
He must not pay less than 1 mina silver.
If you yourself received the textiles, then let your message come.
When you read the tablet addressed to both of you, confront him with it so that he cannot deny all for which I am written.
Let a tablet from both of you come to me so that I can take my silver here.
As for his silver which is here, I have done him a great favor.
And you know it very well!
He had sent word to me to withdraw his silver.
He should have written at the same time so that I could take my silver here.
If he quarrels, let your message come with the first traveler and I will make my decision about taking my silver myself here.
To Pūšu-kēn and Innāya from Šū-Kūbum:

2 talents 20 minas of tin sealed, 35 kutānum-textiles, 18 minas of hand tin, 2 black donkeys, and their gear, 1/3 minas silver--the be'ulātum-loan of Amur-Šamaš, 3 kutānum-textiles for his be'ulātum loan which are packed up separately, all this, Atata drives to you.
My dear brothers, take half of the tin and textiles and deposit the corresponding silver from your own funds as a favor to me and let the silver come in the šēpum of Innāya.
If you will not take the tin and textiles and not do me a favor, sell (them) either for cash or on long or short term credit so that I make a profit and let your message come here.
To Innaya:

In addition to the message which I wrote to you in the caravan of Pūšu-kēn, what do I owe you, seeing as in your last šēpum you withheld the price of my donkeys and you did not send it in Iliya's šēpum?
Pay attention to the letters in Pūšu-kēn's šēpum.
Do not say at your arrival, "Why did you not inform me?"
To Aššur-imittī, Ennu-Bēlum, Ennānum, and Buburānum from Imdī-ilum, Pūšu-kēn, Aššur-ṣulūlī, and Uṣur-ša-Ištar:
Unfortunately, Puzur-Aššur died.
There is both silver and tablets belonging to Puzur-Aššur.
We seized from Wašḫania, tablets (nom.?) from Waḫšušana and from ...
... about a talent of tin ... mina (silver?) .. him.
When ... (left?) there was very little and I was disappointed.
..... as for myself I retained (?) it.
I said, "Let him ...  the goods of the transport of Ennum-Bēlum, or ..., every single minas of silver and make known the silver mastima."
I will bring it myself and divide the silver.

On the day your read the tablet, (with the) 40 minas silver which Ennum-Bēlum brough to you, the excise added, the shipping paid, purchase tin, wrappings, and top pack, and dispatch it with the first departer.
Here, Imdi-ilum regarding the ??? was short.
We said, "Let the prices come up and when the not true he causes to sorrow and every minas silver ...arise and Imdi-ilum bring the silver when he comes and our silver ...."
If anyone for ... sues you (pl.) go? to Imdi-ilum.
You said, "When Imdi-ilum goes/comes ... he ahd brought it, let him gather the silver."
If anyone for ... sues you (pl.) ...
... something which I ... is owed by Assur-ēmūqī s. Idī-Suen.
Our dear fathers and lords, as for you, let him read the very tablet to you and to our presresentatives with you ... and let the x hundred that are written enter.
... the matter.
If Ennum-Bēlum is late, enter and ... in the same way and at the arrival of Ennum-Bēlum sell your .... for silver.
The goods are missing.
From Pūšu-kēn to Lamassī:
1 minas 15 shekels silver, its excise added, its shipping charges paid, under my seal, Dān-Aššur brings to you.
As for the proceeds of the 1 or two xx textiles which you sent to me, your silver is exhausted.

21 minas fine copper, for the ikrībū of Bēlum, 2 s. of bronze, 14 e., x minas their weight, above half heavy half taziki divided, which to Kitaum, 5 e. talḫadiatum, 1/3 minas silver, both a š. and a musarrum belonging to the youth (Dān-Aššūr? or the other youth?) their worth 62.5 shekels, separately his anuqqum, a youth and a maiden, all this Dān-Aššur bring to you.
Urgent, do not release the youth to anyone so that he may grow up among us.
When Dān-Aššur departs from there, Give the š and m. in addition to the 1/3 minas silver which I gave to him so that in total he makes purchases worth about a mina of silver.
Send him back up.
To Aššur-imittī from Pūšu-kēn:

6 minas 53 shekels silver, which Iliš-tīkal entrusted to Aššur-rēʾī and Ennam-Anum, at the fulfillment of the term Iliš-tīkal collected the silver and thereof I gave 5 5/6 shekels, its šadduʾutum, to Uṣur-ša-Aššur.
The remainder of the silver, 6 minas 48 1/6 shekels silver, Uṣur-ša-Aššur brings to you under my seal.
Sealed tablet for (even?) 1 shekel silver is not in my house nor the house of Aššur-rēʾī nor even the house of Ennam-Anum.
Concerning the matter of Ikūnum about which you wrote to me, I sent Adad-bāni to Ḫaḫḫum and he put his hand on the textiles.
The textiles entered in and he collected the silver according to your instructions.
Your silver is exhausted.
To Pūšu-kēn from Puzur-Aššur:
I spoke to you there.
You said, "As for me, I will be delayed one month in order for me to clear every shekel of all my outstanding claims."
You said, "Leave them here for me and I will have the silver paid out and send the silver after you."
Also, I will deposit (arrange)-from my own funds- the proceeds of the copper from the palace and the 4 minas silver from the sealed tablet--10 minas silver and send it to you.

My dear father and lord, take care to clear every (remaining?) shekel of silver there and so deposit the 10 minas silver which you promised me and seal the silver and ship it to the city so that my account can make purchases and I may raise every shekel of silver possible.
5 minas silver which  Ikuppi-Aššur promised (subjunctive?) to pay Adada, cause Ikuppi-Aššur to pay the silver.
You must not delay Imgua but dispatch him immediately to the city so that he may catch up to me.
May your house and your little ones be well.
5 minas silver belonging to Ea-šār which I deposited, if he did not send it, write to him so that he sends it.
From Aššur-imittī to Pūšu-kēn:
I sent out to you your goods, tin and textiles, in the caravan of the son of Šū-Enlil son of Idī-Aššur.
We despatched to you that which (arose) from your silver and the silver which the son of Erraya brought.
If you are my brother, send the silver from your own funds and from my tin immediately.
Concerning the matter of Šū-Aššur son of Al-aḫum about which I wrote you, take care to enter into the man's house and let your message come as to how much he left.
Also, concerning my tin which the son of Ikkupya and Il-bāni gave to him there, turn to his brother and say, "The man is a man of favors. Do not overvalue every shekel!"
Let him give the silver to you.
Send it to me immediately.
From Aššur-imittī to Pūšu-kēn:
Your message came and on the same day that I heard your letter, I gave 3 minas silver to your (pl?) representatives, and thay purchased tin for you.
My dear brother, from one traveler, "Send my sivler immediately!
But when I weighed out silver, I sent (it) to you and your message has not returned.
Say to Imdi-ilum: "Send as much as can be sent of the profits of my (Aššur-imittī's) wheat grain."
From Aššur-imittī to Pūšu-kēn:

Concerning the matter of Puzur-saduʾē son of Tuimim, question him about (his) sack-capital entering the house of our father for (only?) 1 shekel of silver and listen to his word and let your message come as to whether it is this or that so that I may make up my mind.
Urgent-take care to let your message come with the first traveler.
Let your message return regarding the tin and textiles from the cargo of the son of Usariya, as much as they cleared, and (how you are) selling them wherever you can, according to my instructions.
From Puzur-Ištar to Pūšu-kēn and Ikūn-pī-Aššur;
To Pūšu-kēn;

My dear brother, assist Ikūn-pī-Aššur to ... terms so that he can instruct you about the joint-stock fund of Zupa, the funds which are with Zupa tablets of Ikūn-pī-Aššur so that you wrap up whatever (she) has not shipped? to you.
Let the youth instruct you about the property of my merchants wherever they owe you a single shekels of silver, and inform the youth wherever a single shekel of silver draws near(?).
If you two have completed the matter of Zupa, the wind from my purchases of silver from your (pl.)  word until they pay the silver in full, let the wind carry my hand/funds.
Let me clear my proceeds there and those in the city in the presence of Pūšu-kēn (something is wrong here) so that I may inform him.
From Šalim-aḫum to Lā-qēpum and Pūšu-kēn:
2 talents 10 minas tin under my seal, 12 minas 'hand-tin', 4
Bundle the textiles and the black donkey with the tin and sell them on short terms to a trustworthy merchant as responsible as yourselves.
Do not overvalue one or two months.
Your merchants must be trustworthy!
Write down the silver as much as you have placed on the merchant and the term period in your tablet.
The textile for the driver (is laid out?) within my textiles.
Entrust the textile to Šū-Suen.
Upon his arrival let him give to you 12 1/2 shekels silver, his beʾulatum so that he may go where he pleases.
From Šalim-aḫum to Lā-qēpum and P
26 kutānum very fine textiles under my seal, a black donkey, 5 minas tin for his 'expenses,': all this Nūr-Ištar drives to you.
The wages of the driver are paid.
Sell the textiles on credit to a reliable merchant as reliable as yourselves.
Your merchant must be reliable.
Don't overvalue one or two months.
Bundle the donkey with the textiles.
In addition to the 'hand-tin' of Idī-Ištar's son, I gave (him) copper worth 5 minas tin for Ammurum.
And he added it to his caravan.
As for the silver from my textiles, let you full report come about how much you placed on the merchant and the terms.
From Imdi-ilum to Pūšu-kēn:

Stand so that when they asses the excise on the goods transported by Aḫu-waqar son of Zurzur, the merchandise comes down, and dispatch the goods to Purušḫattum according to my instructions so that the goods are sold for cash.
They are not to be sold on credit.
Do not release them.
Let the silver arrive and let tin and textiles depart!
Also, just as I set witnesses here for myself, you must set witnesses there for you.
Let silver and textiles pile up!
Deposit my share in the colony office.
Finish my share at accountings.
To Aššur-imittī Šū-Ištar, Šū-Ḫubur, Ennānum and Bubrānum, from Imdī-ilum:
Goods from the transport of Amur-ilī, until this day you have delayed.
Also, the goods of the transport of Āl-aḫm, when Āl-aḫum arrived .. you yourself have delayed until this day!
... the goods of Puzur-Aššur which came down with ..., until now, you have delayed(?) them there.
Also, the which came down with you (pl.) let is go up to here so that I can convert it to silver and return it.
As for you, for three years not you have retained it and ... the tablets.
Also, Āl-āḫum as much as he gave you at accountings, your report has not come whatsoever.
Also, Ḫinnaya went there.
Assist the investors and casue difficulties(?) and raise about a mina of silver.

In the tablets I wrote to you, I said, "Let all the goods, either from the transport of Amur-ilī, or from that of Puzur-Aššur, or from the transport of Āl-āḫum, get to Kanesh to Nāb-Suen so that he can convert them to silver and the caravan may draw close."
But as for you (pl.) you have delayed my merchandise.
Afterward, Puzur-Aššur the transporter of Pūšu-kēn who after he brought my goods down, he(?) exhausted all of my goods.
Pilaḫ-Ištar s. Uzuwa brought (goods) to Mamma (for?) you (s.)(?).
From Aššur-bēl-awātim, Šū-Aššur and Aššur-nādā to Iddin-Suen, Amria, Šar-Suen, Aššur-rē'ī, Puzur-Suen and Puzur-Anna:

Aššur-bēl-malkim has here settled accounts with Aššur-rē'ī, and he must deposit for you 45 minas of tin sealed by Adad-ellat and Aššur-bāni from the second package that bears the seal of the City; then you must have brought 34 minas 15 shekels of tin and take it.
Furthermore, he shall give you 15 minas 15 shekels of tin, cleared.
In all: Aššur-rē'ī shall give you 1 talent 34 minas of tin and, 2 black textiles and you should sell that at whatever price, seal the silver, entrust it to the very first traveler who can bring
Send Aššur-bēl-malkim.

To Iddin-Suen: As you gave us your word here, and if you are truly our brother, ask for silver for a working-capital from colleague and friend for Aššur-bēl-malkim, send us the silver under seal and let us here turn over his working-capital to him and send him to the City.
If you do not ask for anything for him to dispose over, there will be no working-capital for him.
Enlil-bāni to Aššur-rabi, Al-aḫum, Ab-šalim, and Šakrilka, and Iddi-Šamaš:

If the perephinalia is deposited and the (entry?/path?) accessible, bring all the perephinalia which is in the house into the new house, and seal the 'palace' and strongroom with your seals so that no one can open (them).
Both flour and wheat, wherever their is grain, bring it in and secure it.
And also, exit from the 'palace' and let the maid depart with Al-aḫum.
As for the kilaritum maid, sell her.
As for Iddi-Šamaš and the senior maid, wherever the house is insecure, let then extract seals of the 'palace (courtyard?)' and strongroom.
Let no one enter into the p. of Šū-Ištar's house.
If you need grain, store more grain within the grain (already there), and ... 3 shekels silver and šitrum textile ...
To Aššur-nādā from Iddin-Ištar:

as to the silver  that you have written about once or twice, may Aššur and Ilabrat, the gods of our fathers, be my witnesses, that since the day you came to Durhumit and we met, people collected goods at a purchase price exceeding 2:1 and at a rate of exchange of 60:1, but within my stipulated term the copper has tripled, so would I envisage losses in copper of maybe a hundred talents?
While Aššur himself and your own god have rejected the man, still silver has fallen into my hands and until this day you have been fully satisfied.

As to the affair of Anninum's son, whom you know, the tin and its overweight stood ready to be shipped with Ṭāb-Aššur, but on the very day that the merchandise came out Ṭāb-Aššur son of Ešu-bāni came in and said: "Within 5 days the man will be disfamed.
Turn back your merchandise!"
So I turned back his merchandise.
The very day I wrote a tablet for you my orders were  dispatched to the young man.
If I should personally seize the merchandise both you and I will be happy.
To Pūšu-kēn from Lamassī:
The 'gates' memorandum tablet which stays in your house, your representatives got it out and they have it in their possession.
As for me, what am I responsible for?
Now, I do not know whether to pay out to your merchants or not!
As for you, make up your mind!
And becasue I write to you must not remember them (or their names).
6 1/2 minas silver is with Aššur-Šamši s. Lā-qēpum.
Thereof, they deducted the shipping charges and excise.
3 minas 45 shekels silver is with Uṣur-ša-Aššur s. Iliya.
35 shekels (silver) is (even) with Šalim-Aššur!
In total he will pay 8 1/2 minas silver to Aššur-imittī s. Ennānum.
From the 4 minas silver which I owe to Iliš-tīkal, 2 minas silver is with Ikūn-pīya.
2 minas (silver) is late.
Warad-Nana (has) 9 shekels.
Send the x+1 1/2 minas silver of Ilī-mālik, the copy of the tablet which you left, and xx shekels for exit-tax.
To Pūšu-kēn from Lamassī:
Kulumaya brings you 9 textiles.
Idī-Suen brings you 3 textiles.
Dān-Aššur brought 2  bronze spoons.
Ea-šār brought 1 spoon made of bronze, and a container of bronze.
Idī-Suen brought 2 containers of bronze.
Aḫu-waqar brought 1 container of bronze.
Ikūppiya brought 1 container of silver.
The son of Ibbī-Sua brought 1 supānam of silver.
They brought here cups, spoons, and interest(?).
If you are my lord, do not be angry about the textiles which you wrote that I did not send to you.
Because the girl is growing up, she? took one or two textiles for riding.
And I (must) also make (textiles), for the members of the house and for the little ones.
I was not finished and so did not send the textiles to you.
They will finish as many textiles as we can.
I will send them to you with the next travellers.
As for the house of Abum-ilī, Ikūn-pīya put his wall from the house of Attaya on your wall!
Now as for me, I quarreled (with him) and he said, "I will enter into a partnership with him. Or I will not cooperate with him whatsoever."
Get up and go out!
You yourself speak to him there.
Thus you will say, "Why did you set your wall in my house? You did it when the house was not aširim!'
Also, concerning the beer about which you wrote, "Tell (me) about the beer."
It's made.
It's finished.
Now, the girl has quite grown up.
Get up and come here!
Place her in the lap of Aššur.
Now get going! (lit. Take the foot of your going!)
From Šū-Ḫubur to Imdī-ilum, Pūšu-kēn, Amur-Šamaš, and Zupa:
To Amur-Šamaš and Zupa:
The instructions of Lālum came to you from Haḫḫum and my representatives gave you (pl.) 1 talent tin.
You took (them) on behalf of Lālum.
Here, the man promised me 10 minas of silver for my tin.
Unfortunately, Lālum died.
Here, I took from his silver and his representatives said, "Send so that whoever received your tin pays you your silver."
My dear brothers, When you read my tablet, take 10 minas of refined silver from the silver of Lālum and pay it to Imdī-ilum and Pūšu-kēn.
From Šū-Ḫubur, Aššur-bāni and Šalim-Aššur to Pūšu-kēn:
1 1/3 minas silver the account of the investors we 'entered' and from the silver which Aššur-Šamšī took (where is the subjunctive form?)
Both the
From Šū-Ḫubur, Aḫu-waqar and Ea-šar to Pūšu-kēn:
Qarwiya brought 1 mana 12 1/2 shekels gold and 7 minas 14 shekels silver.
2/3 minas 2 1/4 shekels gold, at a rate of 7 1/3 shekels, was 5 minas 9 3/4 shekels (silver?),
Also, 30 1/4 shekels fine gold, at a rate of 8 2/3 shekels, was 4 minas 22 1/6 shekels silver.
Altogether, it was 16 minas 402 1/6 shekels silver.
Thereof, 149 kut
The 5 black donkeys cost 1 minas 36 shekels.
Their gear was 15 shekels.
Their fodder was 10 shekels.
The 23 minas 51 shekels hand tin cost1 mina 46 shekels silver at a 12 1/2 shekel rate.
The ša saitum charge was 3 shekels.
The exit tax was 8 1/3 shekels.
Additional expenses were 17 shekels.
Your silver is exhausted.
Aššur-mālik son of Erraya brings it to you under our seals.
From Šū-Ḫubur and the sons of Aššur-imittī to Buzutāya, Pūšu-kēn and Imdī-ilum:
We received here the tablet of the city concerning Ikūnum son of Samāya and his clearing and Puzur-ilī son of Il-bāni our attorney brings the tablet of the city to you (pl.).
There, assist Puzur-ilī our attorney to clear Ikūnum concerning his
Also, take a sealed tablet with his seal from when they clear (him).
From Aššur-idī to Aššur-nādā:
The words of the gods are urgent!
Why do you keep renouncing your obligations towards the house of Ennānum?
Please, do not renounce them!
You will perish!
As to Aššur-malik, if he wants to give you even 1 shekel of silver as an investment loan, don't receive it!
If he appoints you to be his representative, don't do it!
Say instead: "I am on my way to the City."
Because of Puzur-Aššur's message you are not to enter (the house), and do not try to sell the textiles all over the place.
Stand outside together with the shareholders and observe the textiles and the silver that come out.
If they divide up the textiles, then stand by and join in the division for our share.
Since divine Assur would then humble me, do not become a slave of the entire country.
... they refuse to come out, let he who wishes to sell all over the place do so, but you should not be involved.
From the council of ten of Buruddum to Pūšu-kēn;
The ten-person council from Šimala is seized in a disagreement with us(?)
Our dear brother, if any of the trusted ones(?) have written to the colony office at Kaneš, return a (good) word on our behalf and let your message come.
Inform us.
Our dear brother, we are taking care to send your youth on his way.
From Aššur-idī to Aššur-nādā, Ilī-ālum and Aššur-taklāku:
How come that your brother has been ill for 2 years now, but you have held him back?
Please, on the very day you hear this letter you must write and let him come.
Have Ilī-ālum seal 20 minas of silver for me and let him send me furthermore the 8 minas of  silver that he owes on the maintenance of the house.
Have also Aššur-nādā seal as much as he makes and send it to me.
Send Aššur-taklāku with the very first travelers.
Let Ilī-ālum leave in the spring.
To Aššur-nādā: Your forgot 11 minas of tin belonging to Alāhum in the safe when you left.
We shall send it with travelers.
40+[x minas of] tin and 2/3 minas of silver ...
From Aššur-idī to Aššur-nādā and Aššur-taklāku:
2 talents 10 minas of tin under seal, 2 black donkeys, 30
To Aššur-taklāku: Clear these goods (with the palace), and, as you are my brother, send me silver with the very first caravan.
Do not make me angry!
Take care to send me the corresponding amount out of your own funds.
2 talents 10 minas of tin under seal, 35
Give the tin and the textiles, as many as are cleared in the palace, to Assur-taklaku;
Send me a letter about the goods that are cleared.
To Assur-taklaku: In Burushaddum you should not stay in the colony; when you arrive, do not stay more than 10 days.
Ask for the girls; clear yourselves and set out to come here personally.
From Aššur-idī to Aššur-nādā:

In accordance with Šū-Kūbum's tablet according to which on account of the servant he owes silver for a fibula, deduct 8 shekels of silver and make him pay the rest the very day he arrives, and send it to me.
Please, make him pay.
Send me Iddin-Šamaš.
From Aššur-idī to Aššur-nādā.:
You have sent me 10 minas of silver.
Specification: 2 talents 10 minas (of tin) under seal at the rate 16 1/2 to 1 - in silver: 7 5/6 minas  2 2/3 shekels.
4 black textiles (and) 5
It diminished 7 shekels during the washing.
17 shekels of silver: the price of one donkey.
5 shekels: its harness.
1/3 mina of silver: the price of 2 black textiles that Aššur-taklāku left with you.
You said (earlier): ''Take that out of the 1 1/3 mina of silver that Ennam-Bē1um is bringing."
I did not take the silver then, (so) I have taken it out of this silver.
12 minas 5 shekels of tin for expenses at the rate 15 to 1 - in silver: 2/3 mina 8 1/3 shekels of silver.
Aššur-taklāku brings all this to you.
(Your money) has been spent for you.
From Aššur-idī to Aššur-nādā, Ilī-ālum and Aššur-taklāku:
Both once and twice I have written, saying: "Send me the 30 minas of silver from Ilī-ālum's previous transport!"
Both once and twice travelers have come here.
Why, then, have you not sent the silver?
Please, send 30 minas of silver with the very first traveler.
The men are standing right behind me.
Please, take care and send it to me!
From Aššur-idī to Aššur-nādā:
Why have you written to me as follows: "I shall pay my accounts with your silver.
You gave me your word."
I did not give you my word!
However, you begged me, so with Aššur-kāšid as witness I gave you a gift of 20

Since our affairs are concluded, you must send me at least ten minas of silver both from the proceeds of the textiles and from the proceeds of the donkeys, the first silver you may obtain, I shall then buy two talents of tin and send that to you, so you can enjoy the profit.
Do not use any of my silver!
If you wish, then stand!
If you do not wish to, then don't stand.
I have raised your son, but he said to me: "You are not my father."
He got up and left.
Also your daughters have I raised, but they said:
Three days later they got up and left to go to you, so let me know what you think.
From Aššur-nādā to Šišahšušar:
As to the fact that I wrote to you, saying: "At the beginning of spring I shall write to you, so you can come here"-- do not be angry at me!
The cold weather caught up with us, and consequently the capital that I was expecting reverted to outstanding claims, and that is the reason I did not write to you.
Why do you say: "I cannot manage"?
The capital that I could lay my hands on-- very little could be had, much has been lost.
When I arrive at Kunanamit I shall take what there is to take, and as soon as I leave again I shall write to you so you can come to me.
As you know, my funds he must not touch.
If he comes, do not look the other way and do not give it to him.
But if he asks you for the girl, then let him take Sarna and his children where he wants.
To Alāhum, Ememe and Aššur-taklāku from Aššur-nadā:
I hear that I have not been booked for anything in the enterprise.
They have sent the silver belonging to Anninum's son plus small goods worth 2 shekels of silver to Šar-Adad.
Look at the note, and irrespective of whether Anninum has paid anything or you personally have sent it, make him pay to whom the merchandise was addressed.
1 mina 7 1/2 shekels of silver, the proceeds from the sale of the hides that were owned jointly by Alāhum and myself, is owed by the leatherworker.
Make him pay.
If donkeys are expensive, do not conduct any to Durhumit.
I shall clear myself of obligations and leave.
Instruct the maid that they shall grind the old wheat for food, but she must not add any beer bread.
Take care with the oxen and sheep.
Demand the silver from Kurara and his partner who are obliged to lodge our claim to it.
To Aššur-idī from Aššur-nādā:

My dear father and lord, quickly dispatch the 1 mina of silver which Kurub-Ištar brought you plus whatever goods Ilī-ālum sent to you, so that the goods reach me to be available, and let me receive it en route so it will be heard here and the owner of the goods entrusted to me will not demand a guarantor when I am about to leave, and I shall not be put to shame.
If the goods have not left so it will not be heard here, who then will let himself be noted as my guarantor for the silver in its entirety?
They will say: "Go to your father!
Who knows whether the father is good for his name?"

Things are fine for you, in fact, silver lies in front of you, while I here repeatedly have to pay silver for textiles on your account and my own, and, yes, I constantly establish a reputation for truthfulness; and in this way I am paying the fees.

If you do not send some of your own, then with respect to the silver entrusted to me plus the (silver) belonging to outsiders that Aššur-taklāku sent to you-- clear the goods and dispatch them so it will be heard here, and so that at my departure the owner of the goods entrusted to me will not hold me back and I shall not perish.
To Alāhum, Ememe and Aššur-taklāku from Aššur-nādā:
After my account and our father's account had been recorded at 11 1/3 minas 5 shekels and 7 1/3 minas respectively, I have been booked for 18
10 kutānu-textiles and 4 black textiles I left in our guest-house.
Thereof they will deposit 4
The colony has given it to me.
Send me word telling me whether or not he has deposited anything and how much silver has been recorded for our father's account and mine.
2 1/2 minas of silver together with the gold ... Dān-Aššur ... 40 minas of copper I left in our guest-house. ... copper ... shekels 15 1/2 grains of silver ...
I deposited 2 minas of refined silver on my account and on our father's account, so that 28 2/3 minas 7 1/2 shekels of silver is from Pūšu-ken's enterprise:
As to the 1 mina for three textiles from Uršu transported by me, you have written, saying: ''The silver draws interest."
If they have brought the 2
2/3 mina 5 1/6 shekels is owed by Haluli.
1/2 mina is owed by Azu.
Have paid in full out of all this 2 1/2  minas of silver plus interest belonging to Azu.
20+x sickles plus 2 minas ... Have paid 1 mina for grain.
To Aššur-idi from Aššur-nādā:
Aššur-dān is on his way to you with 6 minas of refined silver, its transport tariff paid, from your joint-stock capital and under my seal.
3 shekels of silver, its export-duty, he has been paid.
We wrote to you (in a letter) transported by Šū-Adad, saying: "Within 10 days travelers will come here(?) two or three times, so now we shall set aside for you 5 minas each time."
But after they had left the sikkātum went out and the market is disturbed so we are not in a position to fulfil our promise given when the goods were commissioned.
Silver is hard to get.
Do not expect a lot of silver.
Prices being low, I have sent Ilī-ālum to Wahšušana.

Of the present silver I have received 4 minas of silver from Šū-Anum, and he in turn received a certified tablet with my seal, which says that we have been paid in full for the one mina of gold that was booked in Aššur-emūqi's  joint-stock company, and that we shall not raise the matter again.
To Pūšu-kēn from Ištar-pilaḫ;
Idī-Aššur brings you 1 mina refined silver.
If the instructions of Bur-Suen come at all, send silver ahead of him.
From the instructions of Bur-Suen; 160 kutānum-textiles, 4 talents tin under seals, 6 Akkadian textiles, he carries.
My dear brother, when you wrote to him himself and they his, then send your own so that they can hide? fine textiles, 50 textiles.
Now, stand at the beginning of the excise so that they bring my goods down from the palace.
Besides you, who do I have?
To Amur-Ištar from ...
6 talents tin under seal from the city in his debt I opened one sack and I checked 1 talent 3 minas.
išertam itašsu .. 12 kutānum textiles their wrappings 3 donkeys, all this belongs to Šalim-aḫum and myself.
4 talents tin under seal from the city, 8 kutānum textiles their wrappings, ... 2 talents 10 minas tin masram, the tin and the silver marsam I paid out.
In total, 12 talents 10 minas and its uturaúm tin 20 kutanum textiles, and 6 donkeys Iluwa brought to you.
My dear brother, Be a man/ Act like a man and after the tin of the caravan arrives, convert the tin to gold.
Do not release the tin for bali (PN? or purpose?) but idī-Kūbum requested a talent or 2 talents from you.
He said, Llet me exhaust it."
Give it to him.
Urgent, take heed to convert the tin to gold, seal the (silver?) and entrust it to Iluwa and send it 9and him) with the first travelers.
# talents tin ... do not retain
Sell it to him and send their send the gained silver.
The caravan, as soon as the caravan arrives, sell the tin.
Do not retain it.
I gave Iluwa 15 shekels tin for 3 1/3 shekels silver.
To Aššur-nādā and Šū-Suen from Pūšu-kēn:

The 3 minas silver which I gave to my kaṣṣārum, Il-kāšid, for purchases, whatever Il-kāšid 'stands', whether donkeys or purchases as much as he purcahsed, entrust the silver to a traveller immediately so that he brings it.
Now, as for him, let him come with his goods.
If he will not come, entrust it to a traveler and let them bring it.
The silver will return to my silver (funds).
If he says anything (against it), give your (pl.) word concerning the gold.
From Aššur-kāšid to Aššur-nādā and Zikur-ilī:
You have written as follows: "Binima-ahum has led 52
(The import duty was) 2 1/2

3 kutānu-textiles for pre-emption, and you will receive 1 1/2 shekel of silver in the storehouse; 4 1/3 shekels of silver accrued to you as losses in the sa'utum; for 5 kutānu-textiles you will receive 1 mina 45 shekels at the accounting; 6 kutānu-textiles have been taken from the sa'utum in the name of Elamma and Hinnaya; they will balance it with you at 16 shekels each, whereof we have received 28 shekels of silver; 7 1/2 kutānu-textiles have been taken for the transport tariff; Binima-ahum has received 1 kutānu-textile; 1/2 kutānu-textile was either loss
To Aššur-nādā:
Do send me silver, even 1 or 2 minas, so I can do you a favour on the tin.
To Aššur-nādā and Iddin-Suen from IIī-ālum:
Seize Abum-ilum, and with respect to the 4
He is to pay in 3 months reckoned from the month
If he does not pay, don't show him any favours over the interest.
I have in my possession his certified tablet.
The import duty for the textiles has been deducted.
To Šāt-Aššur from Aššur-mālik:
I am well.
Don't worry at all.
Il-mālik brings you 2 ox-hides(?).
Please, on the day that you read my letter, send me news about your well-being and the well-being of the household.
To Pūšu-kēn from Tariš-mātum and Bēlātum:
Do you not know?
Because someone has roughly a mina of silver (on them), the accounts of our 'boys' are ruined!
Our dear father and lord, do not treat the 'boys' harshly.
Let the tin and textiles, until they are returned for silver, be in your own house so that the silver will return and (you can) send the silver.
Let our dispatches reach you wherever you are.
To Pūšu-kēn, Pūšu-kēn and my representatives, and to Pūšu-kēn specifically, from Ṭāb-Aššur;

Concerning the tablet which states 10 minas silver, the debt of Pūšu-kēn s. Šarawa, which  Pūšu-kēn s. Šarawa and Aššur-idī son of Ṭāb-i? entrusted to you in their m., I have placed the tablet stating 17 minas silver the debt of Pūšu-kēn s. Šarawa with him and it will be killed.
The letter which is concerning the tablet which states 10 minas silver of Aššur-idī my brother, instead of the tablet you released, Pūšu-kēn holds that tablet.

You and my representative must read them and according to the našpertam, release the tablet that states "10 minas silver" to Pūšu-kēn and kill that tablet and the tablet of fulfillment for the 10 minas silver which has my seal--all the tablets.
From Kurub-Ištar to Aššur-nādā:
Aššur-bām brought me 2 minas of silver, its import duty added.
I bought for you 30 minas of tin at the rate 15:1; thereof I gave 2 minas of tin for  expenses to Pilah-Ištar.
Pilah-Ištar is on his way to you with 28 minas of tin under my seal.
To Šū-Ištar from Ilī-bāni:

As for the 43 shekels of silver belonging to your daughter which you gave me for purchases, Aššur-taklāku with me and our certified representatives, we purchased for you 2 abarnium-textiles and 1 fine kutānum textile.
They are available under our seals at (the house of?) Dadaya son of the priest of Suen.
As for me, send another on my journey (?) so that he can give the textile to you.
To Aššur-nādā from Uṣur-ša-Aššur and Aššur-taklāku:
2 minas of silver under our two seals Dāya and Ṭāb-Ṣill-Aššur are bringing to you.
I confronted the colony here, but you will have to come anyway.
Set out and come the very day you hear the letter.
Concerning the 25
We went up to the palace, and the queen said as follows: "The one who seized the textiles (and) the tin will come.
If the
If they have been infested, take silver instead."
From Aššur-idī to Aššur-nādā:
As if by the foot of divine Adad in full rush my house is devastated!
But as for you-- you have gone away!
Please, please heed the words of the gods!
Do not renounce the decision that the god has drawn up for you.
If you renounce it, you will perish!
The tin for which I was booked in the tablet, let them claim that at the accounting.
Then you too may claim 6 minas 8 shekels of tin belonging to us at the accounting.
Zuzu owes me 2 minas 13 1/3 shekels of silver.
1 mina of silver is owed by Šamaš-bāni son of Puzur-Ištar.
1/2 minas 5 shekels of silver is owed by Illil-bāni.

From Aššur-idī to Aššur-nādā:

Seal the import duty separately.
Place 6 minas of good quality scrap silver plus its import duty, for divine Ištar, under seal.
Seal then also the rest of the silver and send it to me.
Then you must clear yourself of obligations, set out and come here.
People less important than you administer joint-stock investments, and people less important than me have invested 10 minas of gold.
Come and take over a joint-stock capital and only then leave again.

2 talents 10 minas of tin under seal, 34 kutānu-textiles, 2 black donkeys, 2/3 mina of silver and 6 minas of tin for his expenses--he must calculate for you the value of the tin in silver using the rate which is established by the enterprise--as for the donkey-driver, his wages have been paid for the stretch until Hurama--with all this Šuli son of Puzur-Aššur is on his way to you.
Entrust both the tin and the textiles, as many as are cleared in the palace, to Aššur-taklāku and let him bring it to where there is even a single shekel of profit for me.
