(The obligation to pay back) the silver is bound to whichever one is financially solvent and legally responsible.
Ṭāb-ṣill-Aššur
T
Whether it be silver or copper or sickles, he will settle accounts and he will convert it to tin and (out it) into my account.
To Pūšu-kēn from Ikūnum, Kurub-Ištar, and Ḫuraṣānum:

Šumi-abiya and Urāni brought 75 kutānum-textiles, their price 6 minas 29 shekels, 15 minas hand-tin, its price 1 mina 4 shekels, 3 donkeys for 44 1/4 shekels, 8 shekels for the donkey's gear, 34 shekels for the be'ulātum of the driver, 4 1/2 shekels for the exit tax--in total 9 minas 3 3/4 shekels silver.
For this silver, we took out (a loan of) 1 mina 10 shekels for you at the house of the merchant.
Send the silver immediately so that the interest does not take you for much and disappoint you.
If we did not take the silver after we read it from your tablet, we would not have on interest in this way ???.
From Šū-Ḫubur to Pūšu-kēn:
Regarding the house next to yours which the house of Ilī-lmālik sold, (we said), "We will 'bear the
When I myself departed from there, the house was not sold.
Since (I have departed), your representatives and my representatives are working hard to purchase the house for you.
If when I arrive (back) your representatives and my representatives have not yet acquired the house, I myself will acquire it for you at my arrival.
I did not abandon them.
Concerning the 1 talent of tin which Aššur-mālik and Irma-Aššur sold on credit to Lāum in Ḫaḫḫum, here, I seized the house of Lālum regarding this tin and they said, "Gather your witnesses."

Urgent, there, Aššur-mālik and Irma-Aššur must prepare their witnesses that (witnessed) them (when) sold the tin to Lālum so that the oaths seize the 10 minas silver from my holdings there if they do not present it towards here.
Seal and send the silver.
If the representatives of Lālum are there, clear the men of obligations so that they take the silver.
Also, I gave ... to Hawilia.
I gave 1/3 mina silver to Šasarara(?).
10 shekels silver and 2 minas of tin to the son of Uraya, all this I paid out in consequence of the colony.
There, request the silver from the colony and send it.
Lālum owes Aḫātum 1/2 mina refined silver.
Month of Kuzalli, Year of Aššur-idī (REL 94).
He will add as interest 1 shekel per mina per month.
Separately, 2 shekels of silver, 6 shekels silver to the tadmiqtum, and separately, 1 1/2 shekel silver (for) the ikribū of Aššur--all this I gave to Lālum.
From Idī-Aššur, Adad-bāni, Aššur-imittī, Ikuppī-Aššur, Puzur-Ištar, and Imdī-ilum to Pūšu-kēn, Zupa, Aššur-ṣulūlī, Innāya and Pilaḫ-Ištar:
We will turn over the joint-stock fund to him.
Entrust all of it to him.
And let your authoritative message come seprately as to how much you entrusted Aššur-mālik.
If Buzutaya is not available, cause two others who will go to the city to enter with with Aššur-rē'ī.
In the presence of the men which you bring in, speak to him.
Except for you, those delineated in the tablet, and the two partners of Al-aḫum, no one else is to enter the house with you.
To Pūšu-kēn from Lamassī:
Each man stands prepared to swallow his neighbor.
Place the girl on the lap of Aššur.
Wool is scarce in the city.
When you set a mina silver for me, put it within the wool.
The mina of silver for your exit tax which you sent me, the exit regulators demanded it, and fearing for your reputation I did not give it.
Your sister sold a maid but I liberated her for 14 shekels.
Šalim-aḫum had built two houses before you left.
As for us, when will we build?
As for the textiles which Aššur-mālik took earlier, why have you not sent the silver?
Šalim-aḫum to Pūšu-kēn, Aššuriš-tikal, and Dān-Aššur: To Aššuriš-tikal:
They sold you 35 minas tin, 1 textile, ½ donkey of your šēpum; 2
They sold my deposit in your shipment, my tin for a 7 shekel rate and my textiles for 20 shekels, and brought me the silver.
Regarding the matter of my consignment, 2 ...
... send ...
My dear brother, give the silver to them so that I may make purchases and make every shekel of silver possible, so that when you come they will write me in the tablet of your joint-stock fund.
Now, as for me, I will give (it) to you and ....
To Pūšu-kēn, Puzur-Ištar, Uṣur-ša-Aššur, Ilabrat-bāni, and Idī-Ištar, specifically to Puzur-Ištar, Uṣur-ša-Aššur, Ilabrat-bāni, and Idī-Ištar, from Tariš-mātum and Bēlātum.
Our dear brothers, Bēlātum is grieved becasue of the silver of our father's votive fund.
And we are tormented by the
There, turn to Pūšu-kēn and let each (of you) give all the tin and textiles they can and seal up silver and send it so that he can save your lives and our lives.
Here, the god is angry.
He is harming the house of your father!
Whoever among any of you there who makes a single shekel of silver, do not claim it.
Let the tin and textiles that we send up remain in the house of Pūšu-kēn until they are converted to silver.

1 1/2 minas silver - its excise added and shipping paid to Lamassāi, therein 1/2 mina for š, and 1/2 mina for kišĭhanuil, 13 shekels of the silver is revenues of (her!) textiles from Urāni's shipment from Aššur-bāni and Šalim-Aššur, 5 shekels silver to (her!) niqe of Anninum, 5 minas washed copper to Imraya-- in total I entrusted 7 bundles to Kulmaya.
Witnesses: Ikūn-pī-Aššur s. Puzur-Ištar, Ennam-Aššur s. Šalim-aḫum.
1 sack: 20 minas silver, its excise added for my investors, 10 minas silver, it's excise paid for (purchases???) to my representatives.
To Pūšu-kēn from Aššur-mālik and Adad-ṣulūlī:
5 2/3 minas of silver and 12 shekels of gold under his seal belonging to Ikūppī-Aššur is placed in his package.
Ikūppī-Aššur brings it to you under our seals and let Ikūppī-Aššur weigh out to you 1 2/3 minas of refined silver so that you sell the gold to him.
Send 7 minas of silver to Puzur-Aššur, the price of about 7 talents of copper belonging to Puzur-Aššur.
From Šalim-aḫum to Pūšu-kēn:
Concerning the matter about your investors ...
... textile(s) ... ( purchase?) ...
Also, you will say to Ilí-bānī, "I will dispatch (your tablets?) ... ."
1 1/2 minas (gold?) and 5 minas silver ...
From x-naya, the representatives of PN, to Pūšu-kēn:
22 talents 46 minas tin which ...
... we repaid.
From Šalim+aḫum to Pūšu+kēn:
I wrote to you regarding these accountings.
Now, if there are none, the ... and textiles and ... when with ... account(?) ... silver ... 15 ...
To Pūšu-kēn from Lamassī:
Aššur-bašti brings you 2 textiles.
Regarding the šurbuitum textiles about which you wrote, you said, "Send 1 textile for my clothing, inform me about the textile," I made it.
Later I will send up to you a šurbuitum textile for your clothing.
Seals: Ikuppī-Aššur s. Puzur-Ištar, Idī-Suen s. Aššur-ṭāb.
Idī-Suen s. Aššur-... owes Pūšu-kēn 18 shekels refined silver.
He will pay 13 ḫamuštum weeks from the ḫamuštum of Šū-Kūbum and Kurub-Ištar.
If he does not pay at full term, he will add (as interest) 1 1/2 shekels per mina per month.
Month: Ša sarrātim.
Eponymate: The one after Idī-abim.
Idī-Suen owes Pūšu-kēn 18 shekels silver.
He will pay 13 'weeks' after the week of Šū-Kūbum and Kurub-Ištar.
If he does not pay when the term is full, he will add 1 1/2 shekels per mina per month.
Month: ša sarrātum
Year: year after the year of Idī-abum (REL 94 ii).
Witnesses: Idinnāya, Ikuppī-Aššur.
From Šalim-aḫum to Pūšu-kēn:

2 talents 10 minas tin under seal, 10 minas hand-tin, its value 10 minas 4 2/3 shekels, 10 textiles, for 33 1/3 shekels, 17 shekels for the price of the donkey, its gear, and 2 shekels for extras I paid to Ela. 2 shekels for the gear of the donkey, 5 shekels for the exit tax, 1 heavy textiles separately in the wrappings of Aziya--all this Ela brings to you under my seal.
Abu-šalim owes Ilī-ālum 10 minas refined silver.
He will pay 15 ḫamuštum weeks from the ḫamuštum of Aššur-Šamši.
If he does not pay (on time), he will add 1 1/2 shekels per mina per month as interest.
Muza d. Iliš-tīkal, wife of Ilabrat-bāni will live in the houses of Aššur-mālik s. Puzur-Ištar as long as she is supported.
She will ??? in the houses of Aššur-mālik.
Neither Aššur-mālik nor his sons will send her away.
house, six beams, doors, household, goods, ...
Witnesses: [PN], Attaya, Idī-Aššur, Amur-Aššur, Maṣi-ilī.
Seal of Ennam-Suen, son of Ilī-ālum, seal of Aššur-ṭāb, son of Ki'ki;
Suen-nādā, son of Ennam-Aššur, and Išme-Aššur son of Ḫinnaya, were our partners.
Šu-Ištar, son of Aššur-bāni, Ennam-Aššur, son of Šalim-aĭhum, and Mannum-kī-Aššur, son of Aḫu-waqar, by mutual greement seized us in Waḫšušana

and as for the meteoric iron of Mannum-kī-Aššur that had not been given to rabi sikkatim, whether copper had come forth (and) is in Šu-Ištar's house, or there is an iṣurtu-document, or copper is still due from the palace, or copper has come forth from the palace, the three of them will convert it to silver and that silver will go to Kanesh and then Šu-Ištar, Ennam-Aššur and Mannum-kī-Aššur will discuss on the basis of their tablets and valid deeds without raising claims.
Until they have discussed, nobody shall take anything before the other.
For this matter the colony at Kanesh gave us permission, and before Aššur's dagger we gave our testimony.
From Kurub-Ištar to Aššur-nādā:
It was here that I gave you instructions about Iṣmid-ilum's textiles.
Write before you (leave) so Ṭāb-ṣill-Aššur may travel on to you, and then give him Iṣmid-ilum's textiles on your own authority.
As for the 2 minas of silver that you sent me, since the trade in Akkadian textiles is affected, I have not sent you any.
If within 10 days the trade in Akkadian textiles does not return to normal, I shall buy you tin and send it to you.
Puzur-Suen son of Ikaya should give you 10 2/3 shekels of silver.
Then check the tablet of Katātum son of Nanaya in Puzur-Suen's house, and have the silver and its interest paid.
To Alāhum and Aššur-taklāku from Ilī-ālum:
Why is it that you have given orders to your packer, saying: "I have taken the slave; but if they refuse to receive (him), then take him for our father."
But there you said: "If the price is 8 shekels of silver, then take him and lead him away.
If it is not like that, I shall keep him."
You pointed out your packer; you then gave me 8 shekels of silver belonging to your packer; you refused to give anything to our father's slave.
When you return to Aššur-idī to take decisions about me, I shall say: "Whatever my father's representatives will say, I shall refuse to ask."
Thus Šalim-aḫum to Lā-qēpum, Ilī-ālum, and Pūšu-kēn:
The term period of the merchants to whom you sold goods on credit is full.
Take care to cause the merchants to pay and seal and send it to me immediately.
Dispatch Dān-Aššur and his brother to me.
From the merchant whose term has expired, make him pay the silver and its interest.
Don't listen (to the interest).
Except for the caravan of Lā-qēpum, the goods which you sold on credit, the terms of my merchants, those which are past due, they are past are due
10 1/2 minas silver of the sons of Aššur-šamšī son of Ibni-ilī, their representatitves will balance Lā-qēpum.
21 minas (silver) which Ḫinnaya extended as credit in Durḫumit, their terms are full.
Let your report come.
To Aššur-idī from Aššur-nādā:
With respect to my account you told me 10 times: "Pay with my silver."
And the day I left I said: "Let me clear it."
You answered: "Do not clear it!"
For which of my affairs have I personally appointed  someone to represent me?

Also, instead of sending these angry messages, let Aššur and Ilabrat be my witnesses that I have scraped together what I had in my possession, and that I did pay 3 1/2 minas 4 shekels of refined silver for my balance payment, amounting to 16 minas each.
Today I am booked for a share of 16 minas of your silver.

As to the one or two who have cleared, what they have deposited has been balanced, and he will have to pay at the rate 6 minas each in refined silver to the treasury of Aššur, and he will then clear it.
It is up to you.
10 minas of refined silver, its import duty added, its transport tariff and export duty paid for, Aššur-taklāku is on his way to you with that.
Buy good quality tin and send it to me.
From Buzutāya to Amur-ŠamaS, Aššur-taklāku, Pūšu-kēn, and Suen-nawer:

As for the tin and textiles that Suen-nāwer and Libbaya transported to you (pl.), let your message come as to whether you sent it to Waḫšušana to Kuzizīya, or Suen-nāwer took it, or you sold it on credit to a merchant.
If you do not send it to Kuzizīya, send the remainder of the tin, as you read in my letter, to him.
I am in business relations with the man.
He must not detract any silver for every mina of tin.
Deposit the remainder of my goods on a trustworthy merchant whom I have no reason to worry, and do not overvalue (a short) term or two months.
Now, concerning my share in the colony office, take care to deposit my share and ... and the silver not ... and thus disappoint me.
And if they call for a pouring .. of silver (?), then you yourself will deposit silver from my silver (account?).
From Aššur-idī to Aššur-nādā:
I have appealed to the elders, but they have not released any donkeys to me.
To Aššur-idī from Aššur-nādā:
The 10 minas of refined silver which is owned jointly by Alāhum and myself, Hannānum, the son of Ikuppiya, has sent to Alāhum and Aššur-taklāku.
I said: "Add the import duty and the transport tariff and send it to our father and Alāhum's representatives."
If you are truly my father and lord, for all the silver and gold
To the City they will go two or three times.
To Aššur-imittī, Ilī-šudu, Buzazu and Waqqurum, from Puzur-Aššur.
I owe 3 minas 10 1/6 shekels silver to the limmum-official Al-aḫum.
Since the month of Tēʾinātum, 12 2/3 shekels as interest has continued.
In sum, (it is) 3 minas 22 5/6 shekels silver.
I owe 2 minas silver to the limmum official Aššur-idī.
Since Teʾinātum, 2 shekels in interest have accrued.
Since Kuzalli, 7 1/2 shekels interest have accrued.
To Puzur-Aššur from Ili-wēdāku:

As for the 2 minas of silver, its excise tax paid, its shipping charges satisfied, which Sueyya gave to Idī-ilum son of Ṭāb-ilī and which he transported to the city for purchases and about which informed the merchant, I am the merchant.
I hold the certified tablet with Sueyya's seal.
As for the matter of the silver, our silver and the message with the seal of Sueyya has been written for Idī-ilum and Ikkūppī-Aššur brings it to you.
Aššur-mutabbil son of Pūšu-kēn, instead of the merchant, which is me, checked and received the silver.
Because (?) they received the silver, of which it can be said that I do not owe it, seize him and received from him gold for silver.
Seal the silver and entrust it to Aššur-šamši so that he brings it to the representative of the merchant in the City.
My dear father, take care to cause them to be deposited with the textiles of Idī-Aššur and of ...-Aššur so that ...
Deposit your taḫsistum (concerning šipkātim, as much as they took and send ... .
Ikūppī-Aššur brought 3 textiles.
From Šalim-aḫum to Pūšu-kēn and Ilabrat-bāni, specifically to Ilabrat-bāni:
You wrote me.

You said, "Let your instructions come to your representatives so that when they sell me tin and textiles on credit, they sell me (some) totaling about a talent of silver. And in confirmation of these things let a 10 minas silver portion (of the total sale amount) go to you so that you heed my message."
There are 2 talents tin with Ḫurašāum.
There are 2 talents with Amur-Aššur son of Šū-Ištar.
Also, there are 100 kutānum-textiles and fine tin on top of the (bulk) tin.
Now, come to an agreement (for a price) on the textiles on short-term credit and take them.
If you send your silver for purchases, then before your silver enters, let your tablet travel overland so that I can purchase the purchases which you send from my own funds and send them to you.
Let my silver be lent out for a month or two
My dear brother, for my tin, do no go less than a 6 shekel rate.
Send me 5 minas silver and 1/2 mina
Fulfill 1 mina silver for the god from your own funds.
Do not disappoint me!
May the god, the owner of my votive fund, drive you!
My dear brother, send me my silver!
To Aššur-nādā from Asšur-taklāku:
From Aššur-bāni and Šalim-Aššur to Pūšu-kēn:
Šuma-abiya and Mannum-bālum-Aššur arrived
They brought 8 1/2 minas of silver.
The excise-tax was not added.
According to your instructions, we ... the silver (in) the house of the merchant and made purchases for you.

3 donkeys (loaded with) kutānum-textiles, 1 donkey (loaded with) tin and its wrappings are yours. A donkey belonging to the merchant, and separately 1/2 donkey(load) of tin and one donkey (loaded with) kutānum-textiles--all this, purchases made, Šuma-abiya departed five days after Kiliya.
(There are) donkeys belonging to the merchant, and separately 1/2 donkey(load) of tin and one donkey (loaded with)
All this, purchases made, Šuma-abiya departed five days after Kiliya.
Your silver has not yet come.
We will dispatch Mannum-bālum-Aššur with the next travellers.
Concerning the matter of the merchant about which you wrote to us, you said, "Let him raise about 1/2 mina silver for my
He does not want to raise the money.
We borrowed 1 1/2 minas silver and we wrote 3 minas silver with the investors from the assets of the ebuttum-loan in a tablet under the name of the merchant.
All the merchants gave each 4 minas of silver to him.
If you desire, you yourself add 1 mina of silver to him.
Send the 1 1/2 minas of silver which we owe immediately.
We will return it.
From Šalim-Aššur: My dear brother, when Kiliya arrived I enrolled him for service and then dispatched him.
There, they are informed about the man.
Please, assist him so that (he does) according to his instructions.
Now take heed concerning the matter of Azua.
Urgent! Do not set him for dishonesty(?) so that it grieves me here.
My dear brother, keep your eye on Erra-bāni your son so that he does not act high-handedly.
From Aššur-idī to Aššur- nādā:
You left four years ago, but so far, have my goods left?
To Pūšu-kēn from Aššur-mālik:

On the fifth day after I arrived, the ladies of the house of Aššur-mālik approached the city council and the city rendered a verdict that whoever seized the goods worth 30 minas of silver belonging to the votive fund of Aššur-mālik must release them.
Now, whatever he took he will return.
He will have stolen from him whatever he does not release or return.
We received a certified tablet from the city.
And we acquired an attorney.
The colony is his authority.
Within 10 days, during(?) the ḫamuštum-official of Teinātum, the attorney, and Ilī-bāni will depart.
Now, with regard to the matter of Ilī-mutabbil, my traveller has arrived and will he not go with my traveler?
I made inquiry and he departed for Timelkiya.
He agreed with his brother for textiles of Timelkiya.
If he departs for the city, I will give to him whatever you instruct me.
Will you not give me instruction?
To Aššur-bāni, Šalim-Aššur and Ikūnum from Pūšu-kēn:
Unfortunately, my wife has died.
To Alāhum and Aššur-nādā from Eddin-Aššur:
In Wašania 260 fleeces, (which are) your goods, are available.
I wrote to my representatives in Wašhania saying: "As long as the fee-paying member appoints Kurara as his agent; Do not release to him his half to dispose over!
He must not write to his representatives there lest they should approach the colony and it should release the fleeces to him.
Stand up and lay claim to the fleeces on my behalf, saying: "Our
Kurara has cheated me here and stood ready to remove your silver.
Until I and Sasia received a tablet from the colony authorities concerning his extradition, he would not come.
Take care that your silver does not get out of reach!
To Pūšu-kēn from Bēlātum and Tariš-mātum:
Regarding the 8 minas silver and its interest which we owe to the house of Al-āḫum, we borrowed 6 minas silver on interest and we paid it to the son of Qayyātum.
Our dear father, to whom else can we turn?
Cause silver to be sealed and send it here.
Our dear father, to whom else can we turn?
If anyone asks you for silver from my youth, saying, "Give me my possession!", do not give him anything.
Also say to ?Alama?, "We have the tablet of the city."
Fulfill the things which are not yet arrived (but)? owed ???
... give it (f.) ... the cheif of the city ...
From Aššur-idī to Aššur-taklāku:
3 thin textiles, 2
1/2 shekel: export duty.
1/3 shekel: the price of a sack.
2 minas of tin at his disposal--at the rate 17 to 1, in silver 7 shekels.
Your gold was not sold.
You said: "I shall send it to you as soon as possible."
No one among you should send me any alluvial gold or any kuburšinnu-gold; if the pašallu-gold is of good quality, then send me some.
All this Šamaš-bāni and Ilšu-rabi are bringing to you.
From Šū-Bēlum to Pūšu-kēn, Puzur-sadue, Ḫuraṣānum, and Mannu-ki-Aššur:
If the colony office ... the house ... do not ... the houses/my house.
Take from my silver wherever it is good and deposit it.
If anyone among my debtors will pay you silver, open the tablets and cause them to weigh out the silver and its interests according to the tablet.
As for Qatata, the silver which he brought, let him 'clear it out' to you (pl.) and seal it in your seals and do not delay a single day.
Dispatch him here.
If you collect any silver, attach(?) Mannum-kī-Aššur to a reliable affiliated trader.
Let him come.
My dear brother, heed my instructions.
To Pūšu-kēn from Amur-Ištar:
Ilabrat-bāni sent 4 talents 14 minas of washed copper, 1 talent of Ḫaburatine copper: total - 5 talents 14 minas of copper.
He said, "The copper belongs to Pūšu-kēn."
Thereof, I gave about 5 minas of fine copper to the colony office.
45 shekels were deficient.
The remainder of the copper, 4 talents 8 minas 15 shekel, washed copper, at a rate of 46 shekels silver, its yeilded silver was 5 minas 23 2/3 shekels.
As for the one talent of Haburatāyyum (copper), its silver was 1 mina 5 1/2 shekels.
In total, it was 6 minas 29 1/6 shekels copper.
Thereof, I deposited 6 shekels silver to the accounts of the youth. (?)
As for Adad-bāni, Adad-bāni brings you 6 minas 23 1/6 shekels (of silver).
To Pūšu-kēn from Puzur-Aššur-ma:
My dear father and lord, who else can I trust?
Have the silver paid, as much as I wrote to you in my copy, and cause it to reach me in the City so that it is not your silver (that I need to use(?)).
Have Adada s. Ikuppī-Aššur pay the 5 minas of silver which he promised to pay and also send the 10 minas of silver which you promised.
Dispatch Imgua with the very first traveler.
To Pūšu-kēn from Ḫusārum:
If you are my father, when he brings my letter to you, give him 3 shekels from my silver and do not delay him 5 days.
Dispatch him with the express caravan.
Sell the textiles and tin, cheap or dear, and send me the silver in the first caravan.
My dear father, besides you I have no other father!
Dān-Aššur owes Pūšu-kēn 6 minas 32 shekels refined silver.
He will go and in the city he will write down 2 minas gold among his investors for Pūšu-kēn and he will return and Pūšu-kēn will pay 1 mina 28 shekels silver from teh city to Dān-Aššur.
Witnesses: Qarwiya, Dān-Aššur

Seal of Ṭāb-ṣilla-Aššur son of Šū-Nunu, seal of Šū-Laban son of Āl-ṭāb, seal of Pilaḫ-Ištar son of Aššur-bāni, seal of Anina son of Uṣur-ša-Aššur, seal of Idī-abum son of Aššur-mālik, seal of Sueyya son of Pūšu-kēn, seal of Buzāzu son of Pūšu-kēn, seal of Ikūppaša son of Pūšu-kēn, seal of Aḫaḫa daugher of Pūšu-kēn.

The sons of Pūšu-kēn and the daughter of Pūšu-kēn, the ugbābtum-priestess, will not return to (did not return to?) their brother Aššur mutabbil for the silver--the 40 minas silver which Ikūppiya son of Attaya owed to Pūšu-kēn in Kaneš and Aššur-mutabbil and which Bēlānum the attorney received.
Now, right at his ascent to Kanesh, the sons of Pūš-kēn and the daughter of Pūšu-kēn, the ugbābtum-priestess, will give the tablet stating the debt of Ikūppiya son of Attaya to Aššur-mutabbil.
According to the verdict of the city, the sons of Pūšu-kēn and the daughter of Pūšu-kēn are paid (their) silver in full.
Iddin-abum son of Aššur-mālik stood for Aḫaḫa.
From Aššur-idī to Aššur-nādā:
Šū-Aššur should give you 1 talent of tin that belongs to Alāhum, and then pay him 10 minas of refined silver promptly.
He should place 2 containers under the seal of the City authorities before you, and then you choose one of them.
66 kutānu-textiles, 2 talents 10 minas of tin under seal, 10 minas of tin and 1/2 mina 6 1/6 shekels of silver for his disposal, 4 black donkeys:

26 kutānu-textiles, 1 black donkey, 5 minas of tin for his disposal: the property of Aššur-idī: 4 kutānu-textiles of the votive offerings for Aššur, 2 kutānu-textiles of the votive offerings for Ištar, 8 shekels of silver for his disposal: the property of Aššur-idī.
Aššur-mālik s. Ennānum, Al-aḫum s. Enaḫ-ilī and Qarwiya s. Aššur-ṭāb- my witnesses.
Witnesses: Ṣilūlu, Aššur-dān, Ikūnum.
Witnesses: Zigigi, Iddin-Aššur.
From Šalim-aḫum to Pūšu-kēn and Dān-Aššur:
Let your message come as to how many tin and  textiles from the transport of Dan-Aššur, as much as they clear.
From the silver of Ḫuraṣānum and Aššur-mālik, and the 7 1/2 minas  (silver) worth of textiles about which you wrote me, seal 30 minas silver and its excise, and send it with the first departers.
If Dān-Aššur is late, then the remainder of silver, whether from donkeys, or wherever a single shekel is available, fill 20 minas silver and send it with the next travelers.
As for the silver of Puzur-Adad and Ennum-Aššur, if their terms are full make them pay and send it to me.
Clear both the goods from Dān-Aššur's transport and Agua and Kulumaya's transport and dispatch Dān-Aššur here.
From the silver which you will send, Ḫanu must(?) not ...
If Dān-Aššur does not bring the maid at his departure, I will be angry with you.
In your tablet, you said, "Aššuriš-tīkal will pay the silver of Apila."
From Aššur-bāni and Šalim-Aššur to Pūšu-kēn:
Concerning the matter about which you wrote, we gathered your investors for you.
They read your letter and said, "Whatever wages he has received, income he has gained, houses he has bought, who ..."
... Šamaš-taklāku brings ...
Aššur-nādā son of Puzur-Anna and the son of Mešar-rābi did not want to seal the tablet.
They said, "We also (will agree) if our partners are in agreement. (?)
Make your own decision there.
Šū-Ḫubur did not want to give us the 5 1/2 minas silver of the son of Qayyātum.
He said, "To his brother, (I will go and ...) I will give him ...
We will (give?) 2/3 mina silver which ... to your brother. From the silver ... Aššur-imittī ...
From Aššur-bāni and Šalim-Aššur to Pūšu-kēn:
We purchased the house of Ennānum son of Aššur-rēʾum for you for 16 minas of silver.
They will measure out three
Take care to send the silver.
The goods of the šēpum of Aššur-mālik: 4 talents of tin and its wrappings.
He has departed to you.
Because tin was scarce, we did not leave the house of the merchant and we sent the proceeds of your (pl.) silver to you (pl.).
The goods of the
We will clear (ourselves?/you?) and write to you.
Please, in your letter honor Šū-Ḫubur.
If not him, from whom will we borrow for you even a single shekel of silver in the house of his father?
From Aššur-rabi to Pūšu-kēn:
My dear brother, my message has come to you once or twice.
I said,  "Take every single shekel of silver for the blood of the youth, as much as Ennum-Aššur son of Qarwiya recieved, and send to me."
As for me, why is it that no message of your has come whatsoever?
My dear brother, I have heard that my messenger that I sent you took all the silver that could be taken.
Get both the silver that my messenger took and whatever is available from Ennam-Aššur son of Qarwiya, and seal the silver and send it to me.
My dear brother and lord, as for that which he took away, if not you, to whom else can I look?
To Pūšu-kēn from Ḫuṣārum:
2 talents 11 minas tin under seal, 40 kutānum-textiles together with wrappings, two black donkeys, 17 minas hand tin--all this Šū-Kūbum son of Āl-ilī brings to you.
When the merchandise come down from the palace, do not detain Šū-Kūbum for a single day.
Let Šū-Kūbum take my goods to Purušḫattum, to your representative and Aššur-ṭāb son of Al-āḫum, and let them sell my goods-high price or low-for cash.
Take care that they not release it to a merchant.
Let Šū-Kūbum assist them so that they convert my merchandise to to silver.
My dear father and lord, beside you I have no father!
Heed my instructions and entrust the silver to an affiliated trader and dispatch Šū-Kūbum with the silver.
Keep your eye on Šū-Kūbum.
From Šū-Ḫubur, A
Urani brought 30 minas silver, its excise tax added.

Thereof, 27 fine šurbuitum-textiles, their price 3 minas 21 2/3 shekels, 63 kutānum-textiles, their price 6 minas 1 1/3 shekels, total 90 kutnum-textiles, their price 9 minas 23 shekels, (then) 15 minas 'hand-tin,' their price at 14 shekels (per shekel of silver) (was) 1 minas 4 1/3 shekels, 2 black donkeys, their price 1 mina 14 shekels, 15 shekels (silver?) for their feed, 12 2/3 shekels for their gear, 21 1/2 shekels add 'added expenses,' 4 shekels for their head-tax--they levied that on your "servant," 6 shekels the exit tax, 3 2/3 (shekels silver) for 'saetum,' 45 shekels from the tithe he 'set.'
In addition to the 10 minas previous copper from Iluwa, which is 'on his account,' 15 1/2 shekels silver we increased to him.
As for the 7 1/3 minas silver which we paid out to Aššur-imittī, 2/3 minas interest we added.
As for the 6 talents of copper which were the price of the houses of Abum-ilī, we added 30 minas (copper) interest.
At a 1 1/2 mina rate, their price (in silver) is 4 2/3 minas.
We paid 4 minas 22 5/6 shekels for the house of Sutiya.
We took the tablet of your debt.
5/6 minas to Tupezi. X shekels for the reeds? and (hire?) for Ziarim, 1 textile belonging to Aššur-bāni, 1 textiles belonging to Šalim-Aššur, all this Urani brings to you.
From Aššur-imittī to Pūšu-kēn:
I owe you 5 1/2 minas refined silver here.
What is it that you wrote?
You said, "I withheld silver from your account to your accountings, to your sales."
I don't owe money there!
Indeed! You're witholding silver which I owe you here!
Now, if I do not owe silver there, then weigh out (silver) from your own funds and let it be a loan from you for a month or two!
Everything? goes to Kurub-Ištar and you have not collected silver from the son of Al-āḫum or from my merchants whose terms are full, and you have not sent it.
I anticpated 20 minas or more of silver.
You sent (only) 7 minas.
My dear brother, in whom else can I trust there?
Heed my instructions!
Wherever there is a single shekel of silver, collect it and send it!
From my merchandise to my accountings ... my own share/spendable cash.
Enter into the house of Aššūr-rēʾī and take my tablets so that they are in your possession.
At the very moment of his dying, he said something about my name!
He took something of my silver there!
Learn (something) and send me some good news and thus inform me.
Also, his silver of his naruqqum, no one must take anything.
Seal it and send it here.
Concerning the purchase of the son of Šū-Aššur about which you wrote, "If I do not write you anything in the next 10 days, I will clear you."
It is lost./not here.
If ..., send so that with you I may be able to šxx.
To Pūšu-kēn from Kuzallim:
Say to P
I owe 20 minas of silver to Enna-Suen son of Šū-Ištar and I set his share at 15 minas of silver to the city.
I owe 20 minas of silver to Enna-Suen son of Šū-Ištar
I set his share at 15 minas of silver to the city
I dispatched copper worth 20 minas of silver two months ago to Purushattum.
At the departure of the silver, I will send his/corresponding silver.
Inquire there if Rab-Aššur will go with the caravan as the transporter of my goods.
Here the colony owes 213 textiles to the palace and they (the colony) ask it daily of us.
26 textiles will fall to Hinnaya and myself.
There, send the 26 textiles for the share from Hinnaya's fund.
Do not send from my own share.
(But) do send (the textiles).
If Enna-Suen's representatives retain my goods, pay them back for the silver.
To Pūšu-kēn from Amur-Ištar:

According to your message, regarding the 43 minas of tin which are brought to you and the 9 kutānum-textiles which you sent from Kaneš, I said, "As for me, the man wrote to me. I did not strike(?) the share."

I did my best with about a mina of silver of my own funds and I wrote a tablet which stated '10 minas of refined silver in the presence of Ašina, the affiliated trader' and Šuluma brings it to you under his seal and my seal.
My dear father, take care to send my textiles to Purušḫattum.
I will take care to clear my own funds and come to you in Kanesh so that at that time you will open the tablets referring to the matters about which I wrote you.
Becasue the matters do not 'go out' to justice, I did not inform those matters which were written in your letters.
I hold your messages.
I gave Šuluma 2 minas of copper for expenses.
To Pūšu-kēn from Aššur-mālik, Ea-šār, and Adad-ṣulūlī:
The copper which Ea-šar owes Puzur-Aššur, he (Ea-šar) has given us the full payment of copper.
Because the (supply of) copper is cut off in Purušḫattum, we were unable to rent a wagon and we were unable to take (the copper) to Purušḫattum.
Send donkeys so that we can take the copper to Purušḫattum.
If Puzur-Aššur's tablet comes for us, read it and send it here.
On the day you read our tablet, send the donkeys.
To Pūšu-kēn, Ūraya and Pilaḫ-Ištar from Aššur-taklāku-ma:
Enter into the storeroom and open my tablets so that the 2 tablets concerning the debt of Puzur-Suen son of Ammuraya - 11 minas refined silver, both tablets, come out.
Entrust the tablets to Pilaḫ-Ištar so that your message comes with the very next traveler.
When you entrust the tablets, ...
Šalim-aḫum to Pūšu-kēn:
Concerning the houses about which you wrote me, if we purchase them for you, I will pay as much as is required from my own funds, and my message will come to you.
The men requested a lot of silver.
On this account, we will wait.
Besides you there are no buyers or murri qablītim.
If any sales develop, I will make sure to purchase them for you, and I will pay the silver from my own funds.
The gold which Aššur-mālik's son owes me, why did you return 1 minas 11 shekels silver to him?
On account of this he defaulted and wrote me here.
Sell for cash the 14 minas ma-ZI-ra-am-tin which Dān-Aššur brings on behalf of Agua, and besides the 5 or 4 shekels of gold from Ilī-ašranni, send 1/3 mina gold and 1 mina pašallum-gold immediately.
The
To Šalim-Aššur and Pūšu-kēn from Šū-Kūbum:
I purchased a share of our Šū-Anum which divided to Šalim-Aššur from the
To Šalim-Aššur,
Had it not belonged to out father's estate, he would not have carried a share.
My dear brother, as for me, I can do you a favor for anything else.
To Pūšu-kēn, Puzur-Ištar, Ilabrat-bāni, and Idī-īštar from Tariš-mātum and Bēlātum:
We sent the attorney.
And the attorney holds a sealed tablet of the city.
As for the fact that no one must approach anyone either in the city or abroad, they will divide the silver that Šū-Nunu gathered in the city, (here) in the city according to their witnesses.
They will confiscate every shekel received by anyone who makes claims abroad!
We are hearing that you are plundering the men for his goods.
Also, P
You must keep answering the man the mehratim.
Urgent, do not add?take away? anything from the silver!
Let them gather the silver to the city and let your (pl.) representatives take it and wherever there is a single shekels of silver in the city to be sent (?), let your reports be cleared.
To Pūšu-kēn:
As for us, we have no father beside you.
If you are our father, set witnesses on whomever makes a claim on his silver., so that he does (not?) steal silver from him.
Take care to gather the silver and entrust it to the attorney so that he brings it here.
Urgent, do not fear!
Be diligent!
Also, regarding the textiles, the tithe which you credited, which we gave to the son of Šū-Nunu, take care to send me 3 1/3 minas silver in good time(?).
Be diligent!
To Imdi-ilum and Pūšu-kēn, from Kurūb-Ištar:

As for my merchandise in the transport of Imdī-ilum about which you (pl.) wrote me, you said, "We entrusted what we could. And the remainder, cheap or dear, we will sell and we will send you the silver."
My dear brothers,  let you full message come as soon as possible regarding what you gave on credit, and what you sold cheap or dear, (and) as much silver as I have deposited in the colony office.
Ameta brings you 2 1/2 minas exceedingly fine carnelian and a goblet of carnelian under my seal.
If (the going rate) is 6 minas silver or higher, sell the carnelian.
If 1/2 mina pašallum-gold or higher, sell the goblet.
If no sales arise, then do not sell.
As for the carnelian and the goblet, until I  come, its heart and tin prices that will make me a little look for(?) and I will borrow an amount around 10 or 15 minas silver and make a purchase.
My brothers either from the previous merchandise or from the price which Ameta brought to you, sell.
Seal the silver and let Būr-Suen bring it at the earliest opportunity.
If Būr-Suen is not available, give it to the first affiliated trader and let him bring it.
If there is not silver from the goods, my dear brothers, give silver from your own funds.
.... let it be a loan to you, and let it be a favor to me.
To Pūšu-kēn:
The one mina carnelian about which you wrote, we received it.
Ameta brings your... to you.
From Ḫinnaya to Qarwiya, Pūšu-kēn, Aššur-dān and Anaḫ-ilī:
To Qarwiya and Aššur-dān:
When you sell my tin, if they give you the exchange value, sell the tin.
If it is not so, bring it to Kunilum in Durḫumit.
May Aššur know that he has held the price of my tin for six years past its original term!
Wherever you sell my tin, make them pay and arise and come here.
To Pūšu-kēn:
Wherever my tin he sells, take care to assist him so that he collects the silver and dispatch him.
I sent to you.
I said, "Do not clear my account at the accountings, but deposit my share either silver or textiles.
Now, if you reach Purušḫattum, ... and cause him to take your instructions, and let your representatives deposit my share.
My dear brother, as for me, who do I have beside you?
Regarding the iron about which you wrote, we will arrest the limmum-official, and if it arises, we will take it according to your instructions.
Ennānum son of Šū-Ḫubur the IHME official, has promised to pay you 2/3 mina silver upon his arrival.
Also, separately, cause him to pay 10 shekels per mina per month.
To Ikūnum from Pūšu-kēn:

4 kutānum-textiles and 1 black textile which Šū-Ištar brought, 13 shekel rate for the kutānum-textiles--52 shekels is their yield, 8 shekels for the black textile--in sum: 1 mina was their yield in silver.
Excise, purchases and losses of 15 shekels silver fell to you.
55 shekels tin was their dātum.
At 10 shekel rate their silver price was 4 1/3 shekels.
The remainder of your silver is 55 shekels.
Šū-Ištar brings the silver to you under my seals.
Witness: Dān-Aššur, witness: (not written).
From Šalim-aḫum to Lā-qēpum and Pūšu-kēn
You (pl.) wrote me.
You said, "From the merchandise of Ilī-ašranni's transport, 6 1/3 minas tin and 1/2 textile are with Ilabrat-bāni."
He acted on his own authority and opened my package and took my tin!
Instead of some random thief, he took my tin!
Cause him to pay a six shekel rate for my tin!
I read that Iddin-abum s. Iddin-Ištar owes 19! 1/2 minas [silver] (for) tin from those very same goods, (paying) 1/2 mina silver (per kutānum textile) and a 7 shekel rate (for tin).
He will not pay less than a 6 shekel rate for the tin!

In the presence of Enlil-bāni and Puzur-Aššur son of Elāli, he drove my goods and their goods together from here and the thief (i.e. Ilabrat-bāni) broke up 1 or 2 ‘talents’ (i.e. sacks) of tin in addition to the hand tin which I gave to them.
In this way they who were there ‘informed’ the man so that he took from mine while they took away their merchandise intact.
As for the caravan of Lā-qēpum, they charged feed (expenses of) 45 shekels each.
How is it that they took it out of my own merchandise?
Did he take (anything) from their tin or did he take (anything) from their textiles?
They 'informed' him and he took from mine, and he returned their textiles and tin intact!
Urgent! I shall not lose out!
Let one or two of them stay and do whatever is appropriate.
If they speak harsh words, [go] to the colony.
From Alāhum to Aššur-nādā and Puzur-Anna:
Open the tablet containers and send me the tablet concerning 10 minas of silver, Nanna's and Akaya's debt, plus the two shekels of gold which Imlikaya deposited.
Further, among the tablets which were put away--Aššur-amārum knows where they were placed--send me the tablet concerning 20 minas of silver relating to Šikmatum
If you have already given the two minas of silver to Ilī-ālum, then send later on with a trustworthy affiliated trader 3 further minas of silver.
Šalim-aḫum to Pušu-ken:
Puzur-Ištar son of Aššur-mālik owes me 2/3 minas
He promised to pay upon his arrival in Kaneš.

Now, I personally gave you a copy of his certified tablet, (saying) “As for the man, there, he will pay in installments severally at his arrival. Travel overland, seize him, and make (him) pay the gold.”
You said, "I will send it to you with PN son of Šū-Ištar."
Add 1/3 mina gold from your own gold and seal 1 mina gold in a single package for my
My dear brother, give heed to my messages and clear my tablet and do not detain Ennam-Aššur for a single night.
Send him to me.
From Aššur-nādā to Šišahšušar:
55 minas of lard, (in) a leather pouch under my seal, plus the narūtu-malt that has arrived, Šamaš-bāni is on his way to you with that.
Please, guard the
Let them sell copper, and buy straw.
Take care to dry the chaff.
Let Al-aḫum buy oxen of good quality and gather the straw.
From Šalim-aḫum to Lā-qēpum and Pūšu-kēn:
To Lā-qēpum:
You sent me the 10 minas silver which you and Aššur-šamšī entrusted the merchant.
Šalim-Aššur brings to you 53
I hear that the merchant, his hand is weak.
As for the man, his terms are full.
... silver ...
From Šalim-aḫum and Šū-Ḫubur to Pūšu-kēn, the merchant, and Ela:
Ela brought 11 minas silver, its excise tax added.
Seal of Kurub-Aššur son of Ṣilliya, seal of Pilah-Ištar son of Ṣilli-ilī, seal of Takil-Aššur son of Hannānum, seal of Kuninahšušar, the wife of Aššur-pilah son of Amur-Aššur.
As to the tablet concerning 2/3 mina of silver, being the price of Hadāni, the slave of Aššur-pilah son of Amur-Aššur, which Ahuni son of Šū-Ištar and his wife
(This is) a copy of the certified tablet of Kuninahšušar, the wife of Aššur-pilah son of Amur-Aššur.
The 38 shekels of silver that Amur-ilī had as a claim against Adad-bām, Aššur -taklāku has taken (that).
If Amur-ilī raises claim concerning the 38 shekels against Adad-bāni, then Aššur-taklāku will clear him.
Witnessed by Šū-Bēlum, witnessed by Aššur-imittī, witnessed by Aššur-nādā.
To Pūšu-kēn from Puzur-Aššur:
On the second day after Ilī-mālik arrived, I wrote you these tablets.
Ilī-mālik brought your silver.
Concerning the tin about which you wrote, tin is at a 13 shekel rate.
Moreover there is not a full package available.
Donkeys and 20 sacks were purchased in the gigamlum.
They will arrive and we will purchase tin and send it to you by the first express.
For silver of my transport, because tin is in short supply, I did not purchase anything.
The tin will arrive, I will make purchases and I will depart with your tin.
Now, as for the purchases of Akkadian-textiles, if (someone) saved some, I will purchase goods worth 1 mina of silver.
About the textiles about which you keep writing me, there is no northern wool.
We purchased 1 heavy textile in the market and we will send it to you.
There are no fine textiles.
I will send to you foodstuffs and ripened dates with Šū-Ištar.
You wrote me.
You said, "Inform me about what you heard from the talk of my investors."
There are no complaints.
Your heart must not bear any concern.
Regarding the matter of Ela: Šū-Ḫubur said, "Why did he send the silver somewhere else?"
1 talent tin which Šū-Ḫubur gave to Il-bāni son of Puzur-Ištar, after Il-bāni arrives in Kanesh, it will go for 15 months and he will pay 10 minas silver to Pūšu-kēn, the representative of Šū-Ḫubur.
He will pay the silver of Šū-Ḫubur in Kaneš.
In the presence of Kunānia, Išme-Aššur, and Uzuwa
To Pūšu-kēn from Puzur-Aššur:
7 1/2 talents of tin under seals, 180 kutānum-textiles, 2 1/3 (textiles) for the transporter, 1 talent of 'hand-tin', 9 black donkeys and their equipment: Šamaš-bāni transports all this to you.
Šū-Ištar transports 2 1/2 talents tin under seals and 10 kutānum-textiles.
Wherever any shekel of silver arises, sell the tin and textiles which can be sold to Šū-Ištar and send (them) to your representatives and let them stand at his side.
To Pūšu-kēn from Puzur-Aššur:
Concerning theamūtum-mineral and lapis about which you wrote, the -office will not sell them.
There was nothing at your departure.
You wrote me.

You said, "Take 10 minas of silver from the cargo of Ilī-mālik. Also, take 25 minas of silver from the proceeds of the cargo of Šū-Ištar, your copper and that of the merchants and take the remainder of the silver for that of my account."
Send 10 minas of silver so that I can make a reckoning with your representatives here so that if they took your silver we can deposit in your silver.
You wrote me.
You wrote, (saying) "Add 2 minas of gold belonging to the lady to my account."
In the tablet, may the writing of the lady's name not be retained.
Let your message go to her.
My dear father and lord, clear the silver, tin, and textiles both as to that of Ea-šar and of my outstanding claims and send them to me so that he may make purchases for my account.
If my claims persist as outstanding, send 10 minas of silver so that he may take it when my assets go out, and as much as their term period ...
... know.
... available ...
To Aduwe from Walawala:
Pūšu-kēn brought 2 shekels silver under my name to you.
Let your message come as to whether or not Pūšu-kēn also brought to you  2 r. for Ištar and Išḫara and 1 k. for Išḫara under my seal.
Pūšu-kēn does not bring a tablet.
I weighed out 3 1/2 minas tin on behalf of Pūšu-kēn to Uṣur-ša-Aššur.
I weighed out from my own funds 4 minas tin, the excise on the tin of Pūšu-kēn.
3 minas 53 1/4 shekels tin which ... in his own debt(?),
Amurra son of Amriya entrusted him with 1 mina 15 shekels silver and 5 kutānum-textiles.
I weighed out x minas 5 shekels silver belonging to Puzur-Aššur.
I am in debt to the representatives of Pūšu-kēn ... minas silver (and) [.. talents?] copper.
All this Pūšu-kēn owes (?).
9 minas 3 shekels, the n. of the tin, and 42 shekels tin of Timelkiya belong to Dān-Aššur son of Šalim-aḫum.
5 minas 19 shekels is in the heart of Būr-Suen.
4 minas 20 1/2 shekels tin is in the heart of Šu---- son of Asqudum(?).
7 minas 37 1/2 shekels silver - Aššur-bēl-awātum s. Panaka
3 minas 15 shekels -- Šū-Kūbum his son.
11 minas 15 shekels -- Aššur-imittī s. Amur-ilī.
8 minas -- Amur-Ištar his brother.
20 minas 52 1/2 shekels -- Pūšu-kēn
25 minas Ilī-bāni s. Ikūnim
10 minas -- Aššur-imittī s. Ennānum.
2 minas ...
1 mina 15 shekels -- Aššur-ṭāb ...
13 minas Al-ilī
8 minas 20 shekels -- Amurrum-bāni
1 mina 18 shekels Āl-ṭāb s. Anali.
8 minas 30 shekels -- Nāb-Suen s. Enlil-bāni.
5 minas 40 shekels -- the son of Attaya.
6 minas 40 shekels -- the son of Attāya s. Šū-Bēlum.
Total: 4 talents 28 minas 19 1/2 shekels -- the lot of Pūšu-kēn.
From Šalim-aḫum to Pūšu-kēn:

Regarding the matter of Ilabrat-bāni about which you wrote, "On the day which I am writing the tablet, his term is full. Purchase cleared tin. Let Dān-Aššur depart with Puzur-Aššur to Amurrum and seize the tin on his own authority."
Dān-Aššur was ill and did not go.
Ennum-Aššur brings my instructions to you.

Now, Puzur-Aššur departed with him and Ennam-Aššur seized the tin on his own authority from (lit. in) the goods of (Ilabrat-bāni’s) son, and deposited it with Puzur-Aššur and I received 19 minas 53 5/6 shekels.
Get the remainder of my silver there, 51 1/6 shekels.
Now, wherever he is, write to him (the following):
Let your message come as to whether he send the remainder of the silver to you or not.
12 minas 15 shekels silver which you sent to me, tin is purchased.
Now, I will raise what I can and I will purchase (more) tin and I will dispatch Dān-Aššur and Puzur-Aššur.
As for the 18 fine
Send 5 minas silver so that I can make purchases and can cause (the goods) to reach there while you are still there and maximize profit.
My dear brother, besides you in whom can I trust?
Heed my messages!

1 mina 6 1/2 shekels pašallum-gold and 5 minas silver for my votive fund, 2 1/2 minas for nāiqum to my investors, 2 minas silver belonging to Šū-Bēlum and myself, between us, 4 minas silver belonging to the house of Ilī-dān, 1/3 mina for their votive fund is deposited at the top of the sack, 1 mina bracelets--all this , its excise added and shipping paid, 28 1/2 shekels as tadmiqtum of Iliya, 10 shekels shipping charge of Ištar-ummī, 2 shekels for Agiya, 2 shekels for Meme, 2 shekels for Iliya, 2 shekels for the house of Ilī-dān, 2 shekels for Šimat-Ištar, 1/2 shekel for Lā-qēpum, 1 1/2 shekels for Adad-damiq, 1 1/2 shekels Šī-Lamassī, 1 1/2 shekels for the m., 3 shekels beloning to Lamassī to (go to) Lammassatum, 10 shekels silver for the votive offering of Bēlum I gave to Buṣiya, 10 shekels votive for Bēlum, 5 shekels for the votive offering of Šamaš I gave to Aššur-dān-- all this I entrusted to Aššur-dān.
Witnesses: Aššur-bāni, Šuli s. Merali.
From Šalim-aḫum to Pūšu-kēn:

2 talents, 10 minas tin under seal, 40 textiles with wrappings--therein let Dān-Aššur take the 1 textile belonging to Šāt-Aššur--2 black donkeys, 15 minas tin as 'hand-tin'--all this Agua drives to you (pl.).
Let Agua pay to you 25 shekels silver and its interest as his capital fund.
2 talents 10 minas tin under seal, 40 textiles together with wrappings, 2 black donkeys, 15 minas 'hand-tin'--all this Kulumaya brings to you (pl.)
The (wages) of the transporters are paid.
Combine the tin and textiles and sell them on short or long term credit
Wherever the price is even a single shekel higher, sell as much as you are able and make known to me the silver and the terms in your tablets.
If there are no merchants as reliable as your surety, do whatever is in my best interests.
Witnesses: Irma-Aššur, Aššur-mālik s. Amuraya.
I deposited 2 shekels silver for their offerings.
I brought 2 shekels silver under my seal, a pair of shoes, and a pair of šaḫirum-footwear to Ab-šalim, Nannaya, and Lā-qēpum s. Buzutaya.
I gave 2 minas copper to the son of Maniya as an offering.
I gave 1 1/3 minas copper to Al-aḫum for the house of Adad-ellat.

He entrusted to Kēnum s. Ennānum and Aššur-mutabbil 1 package for Nannaya d. Dudu, 1 package for Waqqurtum d. Pūšu-kēn, 1 package for Šāt-Aššur d. Šalim-aḫum, under the seals of Sueyya, and separately 22 1/2 grains of gold under my seal for Aḫaḫa altogether four shipments.
Witnesses: Irma-Aššur, Aššur-šamšī s. Amāya.

25 shekels silver, its excise added, under my seal to the wife of Šū-Ḫubur, 2 shekels to Aḫaḫa under the seals of the amtum, and a pair of shoes and a pair of šaḫirum-footwear for Nannaya, I entrusted all this to Irnuit.
Witnesses: Ušmiya, Abiya.
Aššur-šamšī delivered 10 shekels silver under my seal.
5 shekels silver from the city he will return to him.
Aššur-idī will pay.
Witnesses: Aššur-mālik, Bēlānum.
Dadaya owes Enlil-bāni 7 1/2 mians refined silver.
From Šalim-aḫum to Pūšu-kēn:
Concerning the matter of Ilabrat-bāni, as for the 29 minas of his silver, I weighed out 8 minas silver for a pouring of the son of Al-āḫum.
I gave 12 1/2 minas to his mother, his sister, and his representatives (and) 17 minas to your representatives about which you wrote.
Dān-Aššur will drive to him 1 talent 10 minas tin, 2 textiles, (and) a black donkey.
We paid 5 minas 25 shekels silver (for that merchandise).
(And paid) 1/2 mina for 'additional expenses' of his silver.
He requested silver from you for management.
Reject him and so that he pays you the remainder of my silver!
As for my tin and my textiles which you entrusted to him, When it is him(?) he paid the silver.
Now, let it be a favor to me!
Every year I have given him silver, I am embroiled in arguments.
Who amoung us here (in Aššur) have sold him tin on interest and got (our) silver?
Now, as for the rest of his silver, there is a tablet or two of a merchant.
The hand is indeed quite slack.

Aššur-bāni owes 1/2 mina of refined silver to Aššur-nādā. reckoned from the week of Šū-Anum he must pay within 3 months; if he does not pay within his completed term he will add interest at the rate 1 shekel per half mina (monthly).
He must pay 3 months after the ḫamuštum week of Šū-Anum.
If he does not pay (on time) he will add (interest) at the rate of 1 shekel per 1/2 mina per month.
Witnessed by Šū-Ilabrat, witnessed by Puzur-Anna.
Seal of Šū-Ilabrat, seal of Puzur-Anna, seal of Aššur-bāni.
Concerning the debt of Aššur-bāni: he must pay 1/2 mina of refined silver reckoned from the week of Šū-Anum and within 3 months; if within his completed term he has not paid ....
Šalim-aḫum to Lā-qēpum, Ili-ālim, and Pūšu-kēn:
You (pl.) wrote to me.
You (pl.) said, "From the goods of the šēpum of Aḫ-šalim, we 'placed' 12 minas 35 2/3 shekels silver on long terms on a trustworthy merchant."

As for the 54 minas 45 shekels which are due (thereof, Šū-Suen brought 31 1/2 minas together with the shipping fee; Aššur-mālik brought 21 minas 10 shekels silver), he owes the remainder of the silver, 2 minas 5 shekels.
Aššur-mālik brought 21 minas 10 shekels silver.

58 minas 18 1/2 shekels silver deriving from the goods of the šēpum of Pūšu-kēn, 28 minas 27 shekels deriving from the goods of the šēpum of the son of Erra-idī, 10 minas 10 shekels silver which the sons of Aššur-šamšī will measure it out and which Lā-qēpum will balance the son of Šū-Enlil, 21 minas [17 shekels] silver with Ḫinnaya and 5 minas silver separately of Amur-Ištar-it is also with (Ḫinnaya)--all this silver, their terms are due.
Inspect their tablets.
As for those whose term is due, do not listen to the interest.
Seal the previous silver you recieved with its interest and send it with the first (departer).
1/2 mina silver is the
1/2 mina silver is the
25 shekels silver is the
Galgalia and Alu owe Pūšu-kēn 25 minas fine
They will pay 15 ḫamuštum weeks from the ḫamuštum-week of Itūr-ilī and Kūrub-Ištar.
If they do not pay, the will add 2 shekels silver for each mina (silver) as interest (per month).
Month of Ab-šarrānē, limmu-ship of Idi-abu(m).
In the presence of Aššu-rdān, Ikūn-pī-Aššur, and Aššur-ṭāb.
In the presence of Aššur-dān son of Pudādum, Ikūn-pī-Aššur son of Puzur-..., ...
... per mina as interest they will add.
Month: ab šarrāni, year eponym: Iddin-abum.
The silver is on their person and their trust.
Šū-Ištar owes Pūšu-kēn 1 mina 31 1/2 shekels refined silver.
He will pay him 7
If he does not pay, he will add 1 1/2 shekels interest per month per mina.
Month Ḫubur, limmu-ship of Kūbiya servant of Išār-bēlī ...entrance (KEL 97).
Witnesses: Urāya, Aššur-ṭāb.
Seal of Urāya son of Manana.
Seal of Aššur-ṭāb son of Mannum-kueani.
Seal of Šū-Ištar son of Malik-ilišu.
Šū-Ištar owes Pūšu-kēn 1 minas 31 1/2 shekels refined silver.
He will pay 7 ḫamuštum-weeks from the ḫamuštum-week of Aššur-imittī and Puzur-sadūʾē.
If he does not pay, he will add 1 1/2 shekels interest per month per mina.
Month Ḫubur, Limmu-ship of Kūbiya servant of Išar-bēlī entrance.
Seal of Atata, seal of Mezini, seal of Šarmama, seal of Ninni.

Concerning 21 sacks of wheat (and) 20 of barley, (which) Ninni owes to Aššur-nādā--she will measure it out with my own pot-measure; if she has not measured it out at harvest time she will pay interest in accordance with the regulations of Kane
To Šalim-aḫum from Pūšu-kēn:
Aššur-mālik brought 61 textiles, together with the goods of the transporter, and together with the things which you sent to Ilabrat-bāni.
Thereof, the excise was 3 kutānum textiles.
And you will balance the excise of 1 textile.
The purchases was 6 kutānum textiles and they will repay you 3 shekels silver.
They cleared 52 kutānum textiles, and you will receive 2 1/6 shekels.
Thereof, Aššur-mālik deposited 1 kutānum textile to your account according to your instructions.
Your transporter took 3 of your kutānum textiles and your transporter brings 25 shekels silver its excise added and shipping duty paid.
They cleared the remainder of your textiles, 48 textiles.
For your awītum: 2 talents 18 minas tin, the datum set 13 5/6 minas tin for you.
The feed for 2 donkeys and 1 packer was 3 minas 15 shekels.
1 donkey died and he charged you 17 shekels.
He charged you 7 shekels silver for the hire of the handlers from Ḫaḫḫum to Kanesh.
The losses on hand tin were 12 shekels.
After the 12 minas hand tin diminished, you will balance 5 minas 15 shekels tin to the hand tin.
At an 8 shekel rate, the value in silver is 39 1/3 shekels.
The price of the donkey was 17 shekels and the hire of the handler was 7 shekels and I added what coudl be added and in total you will balance 1 minas 3 1/3 shekels silver.
The 2 1/4 shekels silver which they balance to you were deducted and I balanced 1 mina 1 shekels and 15 grains silver to Aššur-mālik.
To Pūšu-kēn from Dān-Aššur:
My dear father and lord, do not treat me harshly.
Regarding the copper at the palace, until this day they are putting us off.
As for me, an illnes beset me and until now I was stuck (here).
But I am (now) well.
Don't be overly concerned.
I will wait 5 more days, and if the copper of the palace does not come out, I will take my weapon and depart for Purušḫattum.
Aššur-imittī his brother, Zizizi his wife, and Uṣur-ša-Aššur his son repayed us 11 minas 17 shekels refined silver, from the funds of Atata son of Mannum-bālum-Aššur.
As for the silver they will pay, if they do not pay, they will pay 1 mina  (extra) for each mina.
(Month:) Ab-šarrānē.
Eponymate: Enna-Suen son of Iddin-abum.
In the presence of Attaya son of Buziya, Pūšu-kēn son of Šarawa, and Aššur-mutabbil son of Iddin-abum.
From Ḫinnaya to Pūšu-kēn:
We purchased 10 talents tin at a 16 shekel rate and the tin is in your house.
Also, according to your instructions, we borrowed silver.
We purchased textiles and we dispatched Šū-Ištar.
Šū-Laban son of Dān-ilī brought you 5 white garments.
He/I did not inform you at all.
Amur-Aššur son of Sukkallīya brought you 1 white garment.
Al-āḫum brother of Qarwīya brought you 2
I gave to you 1 kutānum-textiles belonging to Šāt-Aššur for your disposal.
There, according to my instructions, convert either a fine

Concerning the matter of the house of Aššur-mālik about which you wrote me, the sons of Aššur-mālik said, "According to the tablet which he wrote, we will clear his wife and clear our instructions. We will send to you with Šū-Ištar son of Dadānum."
My dear brother, heed my instructions.
To Pūšu-kēn from Šubultum:
Ilī-bāni, after he stayed with Uṣur-ša-Aššur, arrived on four trips.
I did not take even 5 shekels silver from his capital fund.
It was not him.
When it was not sufficient, his investor did not redeem for him even a single shekel of silver.
It was not me.
I did not live on a mere 5 shekels silver
My dear father, return his capital fund and draw him near to you.
Take the youth.
Supervise him as your youth.
Do not return his capital fund to his account.
He will spend it off.
Until you see his account, if it is all well and good, let his capital fund return to my debt.

After Pūšu-kēn and I called accounts and Pūšu-kēn deposited 1 mina 42 shekels silver to my account, then separately I indeed left 23 minas refined silver under my seal in the strong room for Pūšu-kēn.
If Erwi-šarrum entered, he took the 23 minas silver.
If the claim is proven, Erwi-šarrum will pay Pūšu-kēn 23 minas refined silver.
To Pūšu-kēn from Aḫu-waqar:
On the day after Šū-Bēlim son of Šalim-Aššur left, Ennam-Aššur brought my loaded donkeys (back?) from the watchpost.
He said, "Give me the silver, the price of the goods which I entrusted to you so that Pūšu-kēn comes and negotiates/discusses with me."

I said, "The silver which he brought to Kaneš came and you and Pūšu-kēn discuss and if the silver returns to the property of Pūšu-kēn, let him take it, and if it returns to your property, you (will) take it."
He said, "Let Pūšu-kēn come and let him discuss with me."
The man holds my fringe.
And he is repeatedly giving me to the guarantors.
My dear father and lord, when you read my tablet, take a strong tablet from the colony office so that I may get up and come.
I must not be detained in my journey!
From Aššur-mālik to Pūšu-kēn, Kuzāziya, and Aššur-idī:
You wrote me.
You said, "The silver of Puzur-Ištar son of Aššur-mālik, which his brother was to pay within 40 days, he will pay all the silver in the city. Have him pay his excise tax and shipping charges."
I questioned Ennamānum and he said, "The silver is deposited for interest."
As for me, I need its interest.
I purchased the houses and I will return my share(?).
Aššur-idī son of Šū-Ḫubur owes (me) 8 minas of silver.
His credit term is one year past due.
Seize him and ...
... to ... to you (sg.) ... silver of ... PN ... of Aššur ...
I paid to Ikūn-pī-(ya?/Aššur?) ..., which ... to him.
Let Zukua go with the silver.
To Pūšu-kēn:
Your house, which we sold to Aššur-ṭāb son of Matāti as a replacement(?), now they have abandoned the house.
Let your message come, concerning whether to (do) this or not.
Request tablets and our yield of Aššur-idī at my departure (at the gate of my journey!) and study them carefully.
Because you did not send the silver, you have dissapointed me.
Now, keep your eye constantly on Aššur-idī.
From Buzutāya to Amur-Šamaš, Aššur-taklāku and Pūšu-kēn:

My dear lords and brothers, on the day that you read this tablet, enter into the strongroom of my house and read my copy (of the tablet?) so that wherever anyone holds a single mina of silver from my outstanding claims, cause it to be given, and don't do me a favor.
As for the son of ...du, (? having sold it for silver?)
When he weighs the silver, make known the textiles.
There are two tablets.
My dear brothers, heed my instructions
As for you (pl.), don't go abroad tomorrow.
Let your message come if Puzur-Suen does not send you the gold.
Now, if he sends you the gold, he will pay the gold on the same day that he sends you the tin.
From Buzutaya to Amur-Šamaš, Aššur-taklāku, and Pūšu-kēn:
The tin and textiles which Suen-nawer and Libbaya drove to you (pl.), both mine and those between us, they converted them all to mine.
I wrote to you (pl.).

I said, "Let Suen-nawer bring 1 talent tin to Kukkuzizzia. And to Suen-nawer, give 10 or 20 textiles to him. And set his prices as though it were a trusted merchant for whom you did not (have a relationship configured by) the dressing of a garment."
Concerning that which you sent to Kukkuzizzia, which you gave to Suen-Nawer, or which you placed on a merchant, my dear brothers, let your message come.
The silver, the textiles to the colony office, if they called for deposits, deposit my share.
Deposit silver which you take from my accounts.
If you do not (have anything to) take anything from my accounts, borrow silver on interest for me.
Let not Pūšu-kēn pay but write my name down.
Both the gold which he sent from Waḫšušana and silver from Ḫuraṣānum and Aššur-damiq is idle!
From Šalim-Aššur to Pūšu-kēn:
When you departed, you said, "Should my representatives request of you either silver or copper for Imdī-ilum, do not refuse them. Give it."
We had extended to Imdī-ilum 5 months time.
(The rate was) about 1 mina silver for 5 (months).
Now when they gave the silver, I was abroad.
They weighed that silver out to Ikūnum.
To your investors we extended 5 months and they put him to shame(?).
(The rate was) for 5 months, 1 1/2 minas silver.
He gave 5 minas tin to us.
Altogether, you owe 2 5/6 minas silver.
After Adad-bāni exhausted your 40 minas silver, may Aššur witness that I weighed 1 1/2 minas to your name and it was at (your) disposal for 5 months.
I am returning from being abroad (and) they are not able to dispatch Adad-bāni, and you are writing here in your tablet (that) mine was on my own responsibility(?).
(You are) like a despicable man from 1 hundred
Were I dead, would that you bear my
May Aššur and the gods of my investors witness that your inverstor who has given you money is not as concerned as am I about your
Now you are writing bitter things to me.
.... you are setting me ....  of my own ... -im, I will not write down your name. ... I received ...., and you wrote me this matter in the tablet.
From Aššur-imittī, Aššur-bāni and Šalim-Aššur to Pūšu-kēn:
We gave 20 minas tin to him.
We gave him both oil and
Altogether we gave 25 minas tin to Šumī-abia.
The ... donkey died and we paid out 16 shekels silver.
Instead of your debt, we raised that which Šumi-abia is carrying to you.
To Aššur-bāni and Šalim-Aššur from Pūšu-kēn:
Unfortunately, Idī-Šamaš has died.
A loss of ten minas (of silver?) or more has hit me on the road.
And 5 textiles are lost.
From its remnant which has arised, 1/2 mina of silver, his be'ulātum, and 3 1/3 minas of tin is owed(?) (who owes who here?).
Witnesses: Šū-Suen [x-x]-mātim, Dān-Aššur.
From his four textiles, which he brought up to me, 3 shekels of silver are its excise.
x+6 shekels (of silver) fall to him from the textiles which the palace took for the tithe.
At a 12 shekel rate, the price of the four textiles is 48 shekels.
Thereof, 9 shekels is the excise.
He deducted it from the tithe and the remainder of his silver is 39 shekels.
Thereof, x minas and 1 5/6 shekels (of silver) is its excise, and his shipping charge, [...], I took.
... 3 shekels (of silver?) the assets (?) ... 4 1/6 shekels ...
To Pūšu-kēn from Lamassī and Aḫaḫa:
Now, we are writing to you for as much grain as can be acquired and for its clearance.
Also the prayer which you prayed for Tašmetum?, urgent do not mašā'um.
As for the goddess, bring the pectorals with you.
Or send them with the first traveller.
To Pūšu-kēn from Kulumāya:
Ikūppīya brought 5 minas silver and 2/3 minas gold under your seal.
Your silver was sold at a rate of 1/3 shekels (silver).
Its silver is 4 minas 53 shekels.
You wrote.

You said, "Kuziziya brings you 15 minas 37 1/2 shekels silver, its excise added. Weigh it out to the price of the houses of Issu-rīk's son and pull out my tablet and put it among my tablets in the storeroom."

Your representatives and Šalim-aḫum opened the package under your seal in front of 5 merchant-class individuals and they took the excise and the cut(?) the remainder of the package and there was 14 minas 37 shekels and 1 minas silver was deducted against your documentation.
There, you must not (disagree?) with the weighing.

Because Ilabrat-bāni issi'd 1 mina silver as losses, and weighed out 16 minas silver to us, and we set witnesses for us for an amount of 17 minas silver and we took it as 17 minas according to the shipment of Ilabrat-bāni, (?) you wrote.
You said, "I will send you 8 minas silver next."
When the maatum caravan u-x-x-ni, we received at the house of the merchant the 7 1/2 minas silver as the equivalent of 8 minas.
Altogether, your silver is 33 minas 24+x shekels.

Thereof, Kulumaya brings 350 kutānum-textiles-they cost 20 1/2 minas silver,14 donkeys - their cost was 3 minas 14 shekels (silver), their feed was 2/3 mina (silver), 1 talent 5 minas hand tin at a rate of 14 shekels - its silver was 4 minas 37 shekels, 5 shekels for sa'itum(?)- 1.5 minas capital payment for 3 packers, 6 shekels for their outfitting, 16 1/2 shekels for the exit tax, 3 shekels losses from the purification, 1 1/2 shekels for the outfitting of Kulumaya, and 10 1/2 minas tin separately
His silver (hire) is 45 shekels.
To Pūšu-kēn from Kurub-Ištar:
Concerning Šalim-Aššur son of Issu-rīk about whom I spoke to you here, Imgua arrived and you did not send anything whatsoever.
Amur-Ištar son of Sukkallīya brought you 10 minas tin.
My aunt(?) brought Akkukum, the packer of Qarwīya, 6 kutānum textiles.
My dear father and lord, do I have another father beside you?
There, inquire of Šalim-Aššur and Wābilanni and send to me as to whether or not they sold it to him, so that at their departure I do not keep opening my mouth.
Concerning the matter of Atata, why do you not inform me?
To Pūšu-kēn and Uṣur-ša-Aššur from Susāya:
Aššur-imittī brings you 15 1/2 minas refined silver under my seal.
To Pūšu-kēn:
My dear father and lord, do not let your eye lift a single shekel of silver.
Do not retain my losses.
I am your son!
I will do you a favor.
I will send the 2 minas 10 shekels silver for the price of donkeys to you with my brother.
My dear father and lord, do not retain my tablet.
To Šū-Kūbum from Pūšu-kēn and Innāya:

10 minas silver, the installment payment from the goods of Pūšu-kēn's transport has been paid, and 10 shekels, interest, turned out to be silver of inferior quality, so 15 shekels was the compensation.
In total it is 10 minas 25 shekels.
Thereof, we gave 10 shekels as the šaddu'ātum and Aššur-mālik brings you 10 minas 15 shekels of silver.
From Pūšu-kēn:
The terms of your merchant(s) related to my
10 minas 15 shekels silver belonging to Šū-Kūbum, its
Witnesses: Puzur-Aššur son of Šū-Laban, Puzur-Aššur son of Šū-Enlil, Dān-Aššur.
To Pūšu-kēn from Šū-Kūbum:
My dear brothers, my share in addition to that of Innāya which they deposited--you yourselves deposit my share from my
Do not pay out anything and so disappoint me.
Sell my merchandise wherever it is profitable and send off the silver to me.
Now, as for the silver owed by Ememe, why have you not sent it to me until this day?
Also, clear the son of Ibnili and send me a message.
Why is it that Nab-Suen said, “Šū-Kūbum took my silver.”
Instead of laying claim in the city, I dropped the matter.
Now, the silver which Kiliya(?) set in the share of Nab-Suen—until Kiliya camethe silver was available, then Kiliya came.
Kiliya said to the representatives of Nab-Suen, “If you make a claim, I will go to the city (assembly).”
Kiliya took the silver.
Now, they sealed Saliya’s tablet. (???)
I didn’t receive anything.
To the merchant from Šū-Kūbum and Ilīya:
To Idī-Aššur, Adad-bāni, Aššur-imittī, Ikuppī-Aššur, Puzur-Ištar and Imdī-ilum, from Pūšu-kēn, Puzur-Tiamtum, and Innaya:
With regard to the matter of Šū-Aššur about which you (pl.) wrote, when we read your tablets, we said, "We will not bring in a stranger."
They said, "We will bring someone in."
We remained stuck in these (positions) 10 days, then they went to the colony and they said, "We will bring in the representative(s) of our father."
... tablets ...
... he will pay.
Also(?), they did not deposit anything apart from one talent of silver from the (assets tied up) in short term credit and those with Anatolians (and) smuggled goods of their merchants.
With regard to the goods which came up from the City, we checked his brothers (or partners), and they deposited 9 1/2 talents tin and 150 textiles.
We said, "Where are the letters which you brought from the City?"
They said, "We sent them to him."
They destroyed the copies.
Regarding the wool that he gathered(?) from here, there are no copies.
We made copies of the certified tablets and they were sealed with our seals at the colony office.
We have released the certified tablets with the names of the (merchants?) to his sons.
... 2 piz[..] 7 house servant(s) and the remainder ...
They said, "... ."
Of the 11 kutānu-textiles, the rest of Kurub-Ištar's textiles, that Ṭāb-ṣill-Aššur wrote a note about--1 kutānu-textile, in Zalpa a donkey was lost,
From Aššur-idī to Ilī-ālum and Aššur-taklāku; to Ilī-ālum:
You know, twice you did this to me; now you have done it a third time!
Did you respect your lord when you did not send me the silver?
Travelers have come here at least twice, but you had acquired nothing and you have not sent me the 10 minas of silver.
For every mina or half mina they prowl around me.
Ask Usur-ša-Aššur there!
Please, send the rest of my silver with the caravan!

With respect to the 40 minas--I take divine Aššur as witness that I shall not make any concessions to you regarding interest, which runs from the month Mahhur-ili, eponymy Iddin-Aššur, the son of Kūbī-idī.
Clear the goods from your own caravan, set out and come here.
Also, Aššur-taklāku must clear his goods, set out and come here --before harvest.
From Aš[šur-idī] to Aššur-nādā and Ilī-ālum:
When you were about to leave I said to you: "When I have cleared myself of obligations, I shall write to you.'"
I have now cleared myself, and the words of the gods are urgent.
Please, the very day you hear this letter you must offer for sale the houses, both of your slave-girls and both of the grinding-girls, and then send me the silver!
Then you must rent a house and settle there.
Further, should there be no purchaser, you must still leave (the house).
Indeed, you must rent a house and settle there!
Please, please, pay heed to the words of the letter!
Sell everything!
If you have not sold (everything)--as the words of the gods are urgent--you will perish!
Do strive to give me every mina of silver and send word to me as soon as possible.
Also, send my servant to the house of ... Bread ... for ... we shall return to you, and Karriya's son who has paid 1 mina of silver.
My god is the owner of the silver.
From Aššur-idī to Aššur-nādā, Ilī-ālum and Aššur-taklāku:
Alulaya's son owes me 12 minas of silver.
Seize him and make him pay the silver.
If he is absent, then write to him by means of one of my  servants to where he is staying, so he can make him pay the silver.
If his term (for repayment) is not up yet, then have him seal the silver in accordance with his contract.
Let him send it to his representatives and to me, so we can purchase goods for him.
To Aššur-nādā and Uṣur-ša-Aššur from Aššur-taklāku; to Uṣur-ša-Aššur:
Why is it that you said" "1 5/6 mina 7 1/2 shekels of silver from the stocks booked in the name of Aššur-taklāku in the colony office will accrue to me."
From Aššur-idī To Aššur-nādā and Aššur-taklāku .
4 1/3 minas 6 shekels of silver owed by Uršiši.
Month of Ḫubur, eponym of Puzur-Niraḫ
From Aššur-idī to Aššur-nādā:
Why have you written me as follows: "Alāhum's son will seize some of your silver"?

To whom do I owe anything, since it was our agreement that Šū-Aššur will place 2 talents of tin under the seal of the City authorities, before you and you will choose one of the two and pay 10 minas of silver promptly.
Moreover, that very tablet Šū-Aššur brought you personally!
Why should he seize any silver?
He is depriving you with words.
Instead of two containers he showed you only one; moreover, that one had been opened!
If indeed I owe anything to his father, then let him write to his father, so that his father can seize me here.
Take what tin you are able to there, and act like a gentleman and give them the silver.
The matter should not be heard there.
From Aššur-idī to Aššur-nādā:
After you came here you have broken your promises five or six times!
From Aššur-idī to Aššur-nādā:
If you are delayed, then divide every single shekel of silver, as much as you carry, into two parts, and send me one half as soon as possible;
then send the rest with the following transport.
While you are delayed I shall make purchases and return that to you, so every single shekel of silver may be  available.
If you are en route, then send me nothing, but bring me the silver personally.
Why do you keep doing things that the gods do not allow, so your sin becomes ever heavier?
Have you forgotten the words of the gods?
Why are the words of the gods not important for you?
Until now you have delayed.
As for me, in whom can I trust?
You must not fraudulently keep sending me silver in such a way that the colony authorities do not collect the transport tariff.
Please, send him as soon as possible; also, let him bring the girl.
If his silver is tied up in Kanes I shall restore it to him.
Send him!
From Aššur-idī to Puzur-Ištar and Asqūdum:

As to the 1 talent 5 minas of tin under seal which Asqūdum is bringing, as soon as you reach Timelkia you must say as follows to Šū-Ištar, the son of Azuda: "Aššur-idī's orders were that you should take at least 1 talent of tin to do him a favour."
Draw up a certified tablet concerning his debt to run for 25 weeks.
If he does not agree with you, then draw it up for 30 or 35 weeks.
Certify his tablet and entrust it to Aššur-nādā.
Also, make him take as many textiles as an investment as you can.
Bring the rest of the textiles to Aššur-nādā.
If you are truly my brothers, take care and do me this favour.
To Asqūdum: If Puzur-Ištar <is absent>, then hand it over personally to him.
Set 3 witnesses for him.
From Aššur-kāšid to Aššur-nādā:
1 talent 5 minas of tin under my seal, plus its wrapping--I gave 4 1/2 minas of tin for their expenses--Aššur-imittī and Bunima-ahum are on their way to you (with this).
Sell to both one textile, votive offerings for divine Ilabrat, and send me their proceeds.
At least one talent of tin ...

From the colony at Waḫšušana to the dātum payers and the collegium at Šalatuwar.
Here, Aššur-... gave us 15 minas washed copper of its copper and 1 shekel silver for/per pirikannu.
The colony issued a verdict:
No one will give anything to the cheif of the stairway.
He will (instead) pay whatever he (was to) give, as part of silver as the cheif of the stairway owes to Ikūnum.
Puzur-Amurrum seized Aguza.
Aguza said: Give me 2 minas 5 shekels refined silver.

He (Puzur-Amurrum) responded: "Ask Iširis my representatives so that they give it to you. If he does not give it to you, take the silver for me at a merchant's house at the rate of 3 shekels per mina per month."
I asked (them) in the presence Puzur-šadūʾē and they did not
According to his word, from the amutum of Ennumaya, I .. at the rate of 3 shekels (per mina) per month.

He said: "Ask my representatives, and if they do not give to him, 3 shekels per mina per month,

I sent 1 mina tin to you from Ḫaḫḫum and its price was 7 1/2 shekels silver.
They purchased straw and I left for the 'narrow track.'

Witnesses: Sukkalīya, Gaziā, Aguzā.
