To Aššur-nādā from IIī-ālum:
In your letter 72 kutānu-textiles were mentioned.
Before we entered (the town) we counted them and there were 71 textiles, 1 textile short.
2 of them were abarniu-textiles.
"He cannot settle.
He should guarantee. Let him lay claim."
Why is it that you wrote as follows: "I shall write you from where I find myself."
If your own journey takes you to Burušhaddum and you exchange our copper for silver there, then I personally shall put your textiles up for sale here.
If you are detained there, then I shall leave your textiles and bring our copper into Burušaddum.
Unless one of us two has entered (there) before the  beginning of spring, we have enjoyed no profit.
27 1/3 minas 5 shekels of refined (silver) Amur-Aššur and Iddin-abum owe to our father.
Have the silver paid and send it to our father.
Should Amur-Aššur say: "Take my share (of the debt)"- do not oblige him!
They are jointly responsible for the silver.
If he pays in accordance with their tablet, then receive it.
If he does not pay you anything, say to him:
"We shall count interest in accordance with your tablet!"
Set witnesses for him, and then write me what he answered you.
The earlier textile shipments, yours as well as mine, which I left for Elamma, are still available.
The later ones have been infected by moths.
From Hinnaya to Aššur-nādā and Dān-Aššur:
If Kulumaya has left and taken any of my tin, then send me word.
Also, instruct my servants to feed the donkeys.
In paying tin you must pay personally.
Also, where there is a chance of smuggling you must deal with my good textile together with your own.
My dear brothers, do me a favour!
From Šū-Ištar to Alāhum and Aššur-nādā:
To Aššur-nādā and Šū-Aššur from Karubua:
As to Amur-šarrassa, I sent him to Wahšušana, and he has just left to go there.
However, he left the donkeys and they have died.
His working capital is 1/2 mina of silver, and interest accrues to him also on 30 minas of copper;
his terms are overdue by 3 months.
For 42 shekels of silver his maid is held as security, but interest still accrues for him.
He furthermore owes me 10 minas of copper.
My dear brothers, confront the colony, have him brought out so he pays the silver in accordance with this letter;
he should pay to you.
Zuzua brings 22 shekels of silver.
Organise the purchase for him that he wants, do not delay but let him come here.
The donkeys from Hurama Zuzua should send.
The memorandum ...
From Imdī-ilum to Aššur-nādā:
I have had it, constantly writing letters!
Your brother Aššur-taklāku here sends a messenger to Burušhaddum, to the great king and he asks favours of the colony, saying:
"I am on my way to the City, do me a favour!"
so, he will cause you to be robbed in the colony, because he says:
"Aššur-nādā keeps a lot of silver, while I am powerless to even save my own life!"
Then he says to the colony:
"Let me produce the tablet showing how much merchandise he keeps, and examine it!"
Since the colony has not shown him any favours  he will go to Burušhaddum.
The very day you hear my letter you must get up together with Ilī-ašrannī and come here,
and given that your brother is not here we must confer about where we may receive a single shekel of silver owed to you, and then make up our minds.
As for your brother, his eyes are dark.
Heaven forbid that after he obtains a decision from the king he will proceed from there to me, lest he cheats you there, removes your working capital and destroys you!
If you do not take care to come, you will be destroyed!
Like En[ ... ] your little brother has cheated you!
To Pūšu-kēn from Ea-šar:
Wawali left (it) to my goods and I myself with take up my weapon and set out and come.
On account of the shipments of Puzur-Aššur and Dān-Aššur I have been delayed until this day.
From Aššur-imittī and Šalim-aḫum to Pūšu-kēn:
Concerning the houses of Ennānum about which you wrote me, "Buy the house."
They asked from us a lot of silver for the house and so we said, "Let's deposit our money together and so suppress the price about a mina."
Šalim-Aššur and Šū-Ḫubur, without consulting us, purchased the houses for you for 16 minas silver.
And they wrote to you.
They said, "We borrowed silver against interest for you."
We did not borrow any silver against interest on your behalf.
Šalim-aḫum paid ten minas silver towards the price of the house out of his own funds.
Make sure to send Šalim-aḫum's silver.
Also, send the remaining balance - 6 minas silver.
Aššur-imittī said, "I gave your silver to Ḫuraṣānum and it's gone, so I didn't pay.  Don't be disappointed."
I gave your silver to Ḫuraṣānum and it's gone, so I didn't pay.  Don't be disappointed.
I gave your silver to Ḫuraṣānum.
It's gone. (?)
I did not pay.
Don't be disappointed.
Amur-Aššur s. Aššur-taklāku owes the merchant 1 talent fine copper.
He will pay nine weeks from the month of Ṣipʾum, eponymate of Išme-Aššur.
If he does not pay (on time), he will add interest at the rate of 1 1/2 minas per talent per month.
Witnesses: Mannu-bālum-Aššur s. Ṣilli-Adad, Aribtua s. Amur-Aššur, Puzur-Aššur s. Šū-Bēlum.
To Aššur-nādā, Šumma-libbi-Aššur and Alulaya from Adad-ṣulūlī:

I had become indebted to Kudātum for 24 talents 10 minas of fine copper, but in Ulama my representatives paid Kudātum in full, and they produced my tablet  concerning my debt and left it with Iddin-Aššur for safe-keeping.
Today Iddin-Aššur refuses to release my tablet, for he says: "They deposited it here in connection with an inheritance."

To prove that they did not deposit it in connection with an inheritance you must there seize 3 affiliated traders (to be witnesses) against Kudātum, and you must say: ''With respect to the 24 talents 10 minas of washed copper that Adad-ṣulūlī owed to you, did Adad-ṣulūlī pay you out Adad-ṣulūlī copper and satisfy you?"
Set witnesses for him and then send me word with his answer as soon as possible.
Alulaya knows the entire business.
Let him inform you there.
From Aššur-bāni and Šalim-Aššur to Pūšu-kēn:
In your letter you wrote, "My hand is placed on the silver."
You said, "This belongs to Puzur-Anna; this belongs to Puzur-Aššur; it is not the property of the father."
In the next (letter) do not write thus.
Do not declare(?) to us the names of the men.
When you send goods and lay your hand, and when you send the silver to the city, declare "the merchant."
Do not declare to us the name of the man.
There, ... your shipping person(?) witnesses (?).
If not man and wife (?)would we be able to .. and take away the silver?
Kalua sold his house to Ušnuman for 33 1/2 shekels of silver.
If Ušnuman makes a claim against Abatum he will pay half a mina of silver.
If a man of Kalua, either his creditor or his brother or the lord of the tuzinnum raises a claim against Ušnuman he will pay half a mina of silver.

From Aššur-idī to Aššur-nādā:

2 talents 10 minas tin under seal, 24 black textiles, 5 kutānum-textiles for my sack, 12 kutānum-textiles, 11 black textiles, 3 'thin' textiles, 10 minas tin, 2 ṣilipkiʾum-textiles belonging to Aššur-nādā, 11 black textiles, 2 takkuštāʾum-textiles, 5 'thin' textiles belonging to the merchant, 8 kutānum-textiles beloning to Šū-Adad, 6 kutānum-textiles belonging to Ilī-ālum 3+ kutānum-textiles from the ikrībū-fund of Aššur, the kutānum-textiles of the ikrībū-funds of Adad and Ilabrat, 1'thin' textile belonging to Ilabrat, 2 kutānum-textiles belonging to Šar-Adad, 1 kutānum-textile belongint to Aššur-taklāku, a? kutānum-textile belonging to Šū-Kūbum--Total 110 textiles, therein 42 kutānum-textiles, 11 takuštāʾum texitles, 11 'thin' textiles together with šilipkēn textiles, 15 minas tin from Aššur-idī, 5 minas 54 shekels tin belonging to Aššur-nādā, 5 minas tin belonging to the merchant, 2 minas 49 shekels tin belonging to Šū-Adad, 27 shekels belonging to Ilī-ālum, in total hand tin in 30 2/3 minas, 6 black donkeys, -- 6 talents 8 minas the awītum-assessment.

Seal of the colony of Kanesh.
The colony at Kanesh rendered a verdict:
The Šū-Suen's investors and the sons of Šū-Suen will seize the three partners on their own authority and they will enter the house of Šū-Suen and read his tablets.
Whoever cannot enter or is not able (to be there?), they will set up witnesses for him so that those will enter.

The colony issued a verdict that Māru the son of Puzur-Ištar son of Attaya and the investors will give (Pūšu-kēn) the tablet stating that 4 minas silver which Puzur-Ištar son of Attaya gave to Pūšu-kēn, and he (Pūšu-kēn) will kill it.
In regard to the one additional mina of silver belonging to Pūšu-kēn which they took--after the taking of the silver Pūšu-kēn will make a statement.

He (?) sealed (?) the seal of the colony of Kanesh and Pūšu-kēn before the dagger of Aššur, 4 minas silver which Puzur-Aššur gave to him for ebuttum, 3 minas silver and 1/3 mina which he gave to him for purchases--the purchases and the ebuttum he( they?) did (?) (Will?), in truthfulness, exhaust.
From this silver there is nothing which I owe.

The following swore (in agreement) in the colony: in place of Māru, Puzur-Ištar, (and) Ennam-Aššur, the sons of Puzur-Ištar--Abu-šalim son of Edinnāya and Ikūn-pīya his brother; in place of Puzur-Ištar--Aḫ-šalim, Aššur-rēʾī, Iliš-tīkal and Nāb-Suen; in place of the investors--Puzur-Ištar.
Seals of Dadaya s. Aššur-imittī, Šū-Hubur s. iddin-abum, Kukulāanum s. Kutaya.
Kukulānum owes Enlil-bāni 5 minas refined silver.
From the 77 pirikannum textiles placed in the account of Enlil-bāni...
He will pay 6 ḫamuštum weeks from the ḫamuštum week of Aššur-imittī,  month Ša sarrātim, eponymate after the one of Ilī-ālim.
If he does not pay (on time), he will add 1 1/2 shekels per mina  per month as interest.
As for the pirikannum textiles, those belonging to Kukkulānum will go to Anatolia, to Waḫšušana.

The silver from their sale, Enlil-bāni will take ithat silver abroad to Kanesh under the name of Kukulānum and if it exceeds (the 5 mians silver) the Kukulānum will take (the excess), and if it falls short, Kukulānum will stand (for the remainder).
Seals of Kukkulānum s. Kutaya, Lā-qēpum s. Puzur-sadūʾē, Šū-Enlil s. Mannum-kī-Aššur.
Enlil-bāni owes Enlil-bāni 1 1/2 minas refined silver.
Month:  Ša Kēnātim.
Eponymate: the one after Ennam-Aššur.
He will pay in four months.
If he does not pay (on time), he will add 1 1/2 shekels per mina (per month) as interest.
Seals of Aḫu-waqar s. Šū-Ištar, Ilī-nādā s. Aššur-nādā, Kulumaya s. Aššur-imittī, Buzāzu s. Pūšu-kēn.
Buzazu owes Enlil-bāni 1 mina refined silver (In addition to 1 mina 1/2 shekel he fulfilled- he declared. the silver).
From the ḫamuštum of liptānum, month Qarrātum, eponymate of Sama, he will add 1 shekel as interest per mina (per month).
Kulumaya is the guarantor.
(The silver) is bound to whichever one among them is solvent.
Seals of Qatātum s. Idī-Ištar, Aššur-rābi s. Lā-qēpum, Nanaya s. Ḫanānum, Puzur-Aššur s. Amur-Aššur.
Puzur-Aššur holds 1 mina refined silver, the beʾulātum loan of Enlil-bāni.
He is held by the silver.
This is a copy of the sealed tablets which have gone abroad.
To Pūšu-kēn from Aššūr-imittī and Puzur-Aššur:
Imgua brings you 12 minas lapis under our seals.
It is worth 6 minas 11 shekels silver.

As for the tithe of the colony office, you said, "When they are sold, give them the silver as tithe. If they do not agree with you, let them assess the stone as broken apart, because it is broken apart."
They will not put a chisel on it.
The stone will go to/with Aḫaya.
If you did not sell it there, send it to Amur-Ištar and Abu-šalim.
Also, inform them that they will asess as broken it at their sale.
Let them send the silver, its revenue to you.
Seals: Lā-qēpum s. Zuzuzānum, Iluwa s. Aššur-šamšī, Aššur-emūqī s. Iddin-Aššur, Iddin-Aššur.
Iddin-Aššur s. Isaliya owes Aḫu-waqar 2 minas 2 1/2 shekels silver.
He will send the silver to the city after Aḫu-waqar.
If Iddin-Aššur does not encounter the silver after (the departure of) Aḫu-waqar, Iddin-Aššur will pay 4 minas 5 shekels silver when Aḫu-waqar returns from the city.
Seals: Iddin-Aššur s. Isaliya, Šū-Ištar s. Aššur-ṭāb s. Aššur-šamšī, Ṣilli-Adad s. Ilī-emūqī.
Iddin-Aššur owes Aḫu-waqar 1 mina 10 shekels refined silver.
He will add 1 1/2 shekels (per mina) per month as interest from the ḫamuštum of Šū-Kūbum and Gazia.
Month: Kanwarta.
Eponymate: Iddin-abum s. Narbitum.
Seals: Iddin-Aššur s. Isaliya, Adad-ellat s. Adad-bāni, Šū-Ištar s. Šuwa, Buzua s. Aššur-ṭāb.
Iddināya s. Isaliya owes the merchant 2/3 minas refined silver.
His brother Aḫu-waqar is guarantor.
He will add 1 shekel silver per month as interest from the ḫamuštum of Aššur-imittī.
Eponymate: Ilī-dān.
Month: Qarrātum.
The amtum maid Aniya is his pledge.
Seals: Adad-ellat s. Adad-bāni, Šū-Ištar s. Šu-Aya, Buzua s. Aššur-ṭāb, Iddin-Aššur s. Isaliya.
Regarding the debt of Iddin-Aššur, Iddin-Aššur owes the merchant 1/2 mina refined sivler.
Aḫu-waqar is the guarantor.
He will add 1/2 shekel per month from the ḫamuštum of Šū-Kūbum and Kurub-Ištar.
Month: Ša sarrātim.
Eponymate: the one after Iddin-abum s. Narbitum.
Concerning the sons of Aššur-šamšī, we received (silver?) from Ennam-Aššur son of Šū-Enlil.
We recieved x talents 33 minas 40 shekels from the merchant of Šalim-aḫum.
Thereof, we gave 31 minas of silver, ½ mina its transport tariff, to Ennam-Aššur son of Šū-Aššur and he carried it.
Witnesses: Zupa, Aššur-taklāku, Ennānum the scribe.
We entrusted to Aššur-mālik 20 minas 50 shekels of silver under our seal, separately 20 shekels which [ … ].
A paid 1 mina 8 1/2 shekels to the man from Niḫriya in the name of Šū-Ištar.
From the ḫamuštum of Inaḫ-ilī ...
Pūšu-kēn balanced 40 shekels silver belonging to Šū-Ḫubur which Aššur-nādā owed.
Wherever he sees him he will seize him and he will pay the silver to Pūšu-kēn.
Seal of Aššur-mālik
(Addressed) to Il-kāšid.
From Aššur-mālik to Il-kāšid:
I received 1 1/2 shekels silver on your behalf from Ennum-Aššur.
For the thirds(?) I gave my word to him.
Do not return to him and do not receive silver from Ennum-Aššur!
Witnesses: Ayyamšil, Ilī-rēʾī, Šaqṣum.
From Aššur-mālik and Šalim-Aššur to Pūšu-kēn and Aššur-idī:
To Pūšu-kēn:
Ilī-mutabbil departed with the caravan.
Also, Adad-bāni and Kašlum departed with the express caravan.
The goods have departed toward you.
4 talents of tin under seals, 20 minas of tin for 'hand-tin', 8 black textiles as wrappings, 10 kutānum-textiles (in) two top-packs, three black donkeys and their gear ...
... if (?) my dear brother ...
When the textiles arrive, sell 5 textiles each to brother and neighbor, so that the they give the proceeds to you.

Now, you buy the remainder of the textiles and give him the silver as immediate proceeds and do me this favor and then dispatch Aššur-idī so that  he asks(?) wherever there is one mina of silver brother and neighbor who promised and raises (the silver?).
Also, clear(?) the youth there.
He must not contract any affliction.
Keep an eye on him.
He must not act inappropriately.
Clear your m.
Who ...
From Šalim-Aššur:
Why from ...  which exist .. 4 1/2 minas ...
From Aššur-mālik and Šalim-Aššur to Pūšu-kēn:
Concerning the price of the textiles of the Akkadians about which you wrote, since you left, no Akkadians have come to the City.
Their land is in great turmoil, and if they arrive before winter and the prices are beneficial to you, we will purchase some for you.
We will even make the purchases with silver from our own funds.
Take heed to send the silver.
From Aššur-mālik:
My dear brother, because you took care to take out every single mina of silver of my outstanding claims, you have opened my eyes.
Also, the 10 minas of silver with Puzur-Ištar son of Aššur-mālik, take care to send it with the first departure.
I read your tablet and my heart was gladdened.
From Šalim-Aššur:
I dispatched the youth with Enna-Suen.
Also, Enna-Suen is bound (?) for your ten textiles which I gave to him.
My dear brother, if you wait, it will cause the youth to be sorrowful.
Let the youth live with you.
Enna Suen is bound to silver for my
We made his tablet for 20 ḫamuštum weeks.
As much as you agreed to ...
To Pūšu-kēn, Ikūppī-Aššur, and Kulumaya from Aššur-mālik:
I wrote to you, "Sell 1 talent of tin and purchase (some) kettles for me."
If you purchased the kettles for me, entrust all the textiles and the kettles to Ilī-wēdāku and let him load the journey to Durḫumit.
Let the tin be deposited in Pūšu-kēn's house.
If you have not yet purchased the kettles, then let the tin - all of it - be deposited in Pūšu-kēn's house.
Until my message arrives, I will look every day toward Purušḫattum.
I will send the silver for the messages with the first traveller.
From Aššur-nādā to Aššur-taklāku and Šišahšušar:
Why is it that you say: "Apart from 20 sacks of wheat and 15 sacks of barley that Kutubiš gave me there is nothing else (here)!"
Where are the 40 minas of sickles (and) the 2 1/2 minas of tin which Ilī-išar and Huluba brought to Šana?
Please, put pressure on Azu and Tutuli as well as Ka'uba with respect to the silver of Haluli, and soak 10 sacks of malt and 10 sacks of beer bread to prepare (beer).
If you want any grain then buy it.
If they are not careful with the outstanding claims, send me word.
Send me some oil.
To Alāhum, Ememe and Šišahšušar (From Aššur-nādā):
Puzur-Aššur is on his way to you with 1/3 mina 1 shekel of silver under my seal.
Buy fire-wood and reeds, and have the oxen haul as much of what is there as they can; Buy malahum and habašatum utensils for the maziru tin.
Please may everything be ready so I can move quickly as soon as I arrive.
If they brought the textiles belonging to Šū-Suen and myself from Uršu, then sell them there and divide the proceeds.
This one was set aside here.
If Kutubiš asks for any silver then give him some.
From Aššur-šamšī to Šū-Anum:
They brought 5 textiles within the package of 15 kutānum textiles and 4 1/2 talents of tin for Aššur-nādā.
1 1/2 shekels for the gear for the donkey.
We gave 5 shekels silver to the driver.
We balanced 2 1/2 shekels silver to Šalim-Aššur s. Memenānum.
We paid 4 shekels silver to the son of Nabu-bāni for the fine copper which you owed.
10 shekels silver were lost from the cleaning procedure.
15 shekels silver, the price of the donkey.
2 shekels silver - the exit tax; 4 minas 11 shekels (hand) tin we gave for the share.
The remainder of the silver was 1 mina 9 shekels.
Amur-ilī brought 1 mina tin.
2/3 minas copper was the exit tax.
Your funds are exhausted.
If you come, bring my silver, Hananum's, and that belonging to the son of Abarzizum.
If you do not come, seal the silver altogether and send it to me.
You brought(?) 1 textile for Ikūnum.
From Hinnaya to Qarwiya and Pūšu-kēn:
Concerning the silver arising from tin which (was with?) Elama and concerning the 10 minas which ... of the merchant...
... silver ... which ... pay out.
(Seal it and) send it here.
To Pūšu-kēn:

(Concerning) the two talents of tin at a rate of 7.5 minas losses added earlier and 4 talents at 10 minas rate losses included which Puzur-Ištar's transport brought to you, my dear brother, let your message come.
From the x talents (x minas) tin which you sent, seal x minas silver and send it here.
To Pūšu-kēn and Aššur-nīšu, specifically to Pūšu-kēn, from Ikūn-pīya:
With six donkeys and 15 talents fine copper--half washed and half ḫaburataum-style, my sons(/young men) were killed in DÍ-ta-tim.
Also, they carried away my copper.
And I cannot recover(?) the donkeys.
Concerning my copper and the blood money of my sons/young men, I am staying in Tuḫpiya.
I hear that I am summoned to court in the city.
In one (more?) month, the merchant will pay out 10 minas copper.
There is no silver.
A shekel falls to my account.
(But) there is no copper.
Should 10 minas (silver) fall into my account, I will purchase donkesys
My dear father and lord, to whom else can I turn?

Give me 4 or 5 donkeys on long terms which you are wont to let out and rustle the donkeys so they arrive in Purušḫattum so that every shekel of silver may arise and the eye of Aššur may (smile on me?)
And if you have no donkeys yourself, take some from a colleague.
To Kulumaya:
Let your message ...
To Pūšu-kēn from Ikuppiya:
On the day I wrote to you your tablet, Šū-Nunu departed.
May your message(?) seize you.
I gave 2 1/3 minas washed copper, and 10 (household utensils) to the account of Elāli.
Give x minas l. that is with you(?) to Iliya.
To Pūšu-kēn from Ilabrat-bāni:
Šū-Nūnu brought you 17 minas silver.
Also, my instructions went to you.
I said, "Have Šū-Nūnu pay 1 minas 6 shekels silver.

Make Puzur-Aššur pay 1 mina 50 shekels silver and the son of Elī-mēšar pay 33 shekels silver so that you purify the dirty (tin?/copper?) and borrow silver on interest for the balance payment of the 20 minas, its excise tax and its shipping charges, doing according to my instructions, and so do me a favor.
But as for you, your instructions did not arrive.
My dear father and lord, take heed to do according to my instructions.
Let it be a favor to me.
Also, regarding my account, let your message come as to how much Puzur-Aššur deposited at the colony office and how much you desposited and so inform me.
Send frequently to Puzur-Ištar son of Agua so that those men may pay to (you?)  the silver.
To Aššur-nādā and Uṣur-ša-Aššur from Ilī-ālum:
13 minas 11 1/2 shekels of silver (and) 1/3 mina 7 shekels of gold under the seals of my representatives Bēlum-bāni brought to you.
2 1/2 minas of refined silver (and) 10 1/6 shekels of
I wrote to you, (saying): "Pay 15 1/2 minas to Pūšu-kēn and give the rest to Aššur-nādā."
You wrote back, (saying): "Come!"
Against god's will they have held me up in Šaladuwar for 8 months; moreover, merchandise worth some 20 minas of silver has been tied down together with me.

So, if indeed it had been invested in copper, I would have experienced losses of 5 minas of silver; not only was there a deficit from here, but then there Šū-Ištar and his associates hold back on the reparations.
Take care and have the silver paid, so I shall not perish on the journey to the City.
He who has no brothers--I am like him!
Inbi-Ištar to Aššur-nšu,
To Pūšu-kēn from Lamassī:
You forgot the roughly 1 1/2 minas silver for the rent of the house of Ilī-malik at the beginning of your journey and you did not write it in your memorandum.
Your representatives took it.
From the 70 sūtum-measures in the possession of Abbāʾim, he measured out 20 sūtum-measures.
He will measure out the rest of the barley and the message will come to you.
Urgent, take care to send the gold, the yeild of my tin (brought by) the lads which you opened, so that I may set my tin to them and not disappoint them.
The gold belonging to Buzāzu which you left, fashion it into ḫittum-objects for Aḫaḫa.
Do not act high-handedly with your representatives.
Dispatch the lad so that he gathers the grain ration.
To Šalim-aḫum from Lā-qēpum and Pūšu-kēn:
Pūšu-kēn brought 8 talents tin and its ..., 32 textiles, therein are 10 kutānum-textiles, 32 minas tin sealed, 2 minas tin separately.
In sum, 34 minas hand tin, 4 kusītum-garments.
Therein, the son of Aššur-mālik took 1 kusītum-garment.
They took 1 mṭt  kusītum-garment as excise of 5 kutanum-textiles for the palace.
... tin which to ...
...we added ... for 10 shekels silver ... kutānum-textiles and we paid back 12 minas silver to your accounts.
We combined 5 shekels silver which (is deducted ?) from the price of 3 kutānum-textiles, to the total of your taphir of Šarra-mātēn.
Of the 5 talents, the awītum-assessement of the transport of Ili-ašranni, (the segment) from Razama to Burallum set to us 6 minas 51 2/3 shekels tin.
From Burallum to Kanesh, 2 minas 57 1/3 shekels per mina obtain.
For 10 talents, your awītum assessment is 6 minas.
29 minas 49 shekels applies.
1/2 minas tin (for) two heads(?) obtain.
The (fee for) fodder of 4 donkeys and their drivers is 2 minas.
The hire of the drivers is 3 minas.
The tašiātum is 2 minas 34 shekels.
The deficiency of the hand tin is 1/2 mina.
We gave to Ili-ašranni ... of his tin ...
We added x shekels to the x shekels silver for the price of the 3 kutānum-textiles for the taphirim of Šarra-mātēn and we exhausted the 11 1/2 shekels silver.
The remainder of the silver of the donkeys is 1/3 minas silver.
We received silver for the 3 minas tin which Ilī-ašranni weighed out.
From Pūšu-kēn to Aššur-taklāku:
I am written down for 24 minas 10 shekels silver in the great tablet in the colony office.

55 shekels together with its interest from the previous ḫamuštum week, 32 1/2 shekels from the following ḫamuštum-week, the price of three kutānum textiles, 45 shekels, 7 1/2 shekels the hire of the donkeys at Wašḫaniya, 15 shekels the hire for the paddock, total 26 minas 45 shekels.
Thereof, your
The šaḫītum of Ennum-Aššur your brother was 6 minas.
You and Nāb-Suen were given 1 1/2 minas for a fine.
Your arrival expenses were 45 shekels.
They did not set the 2 1/3 minas your complete spending (?) of Purušḫattum.
They did not set the 18 shekels of your servants and donkeys.
To Šalim-aḫum from Pūšu-kēn:
Regarding the 30 minas (silver) which Aššur-ṭāb and Uṣur-ša-Aššur owed, 10 shekels were deducted amounts.
I added 1/3 minas silver from my own funds and Šū-Ištar son of Dadānum brings you 30 minas silver under my seal.
You wrote me.
You said, "In addition to this silver, add 10 minas silver and dispatch the boy (Ennam-Aššur) to me.
(As for) the yield of the textiles and the yeild of the 50 minas tin, I will entrust about 1 talent 20 minas silver to Dān-Aššur's transport.
He will arrive in 2 days and I will dispatch him to you.
Also, my complete report will come to you with him.
As for the tin, if (the rate) is 15 shekels or higher, purchase it to the amount of 40 minas silver so that it is deposited until the arrival of Dān-Aššur so that he does not delay there.
Dispatch him to me.
Now, as for my transport, beside the two tablets of Lulu and Aššur-nādā and his son, there is nothing else.
I wrote to your son and I said, "Go with this silver!"
He said to my messenger, "You argue like the son of a dead man."
Before 3 'certified merchants' he refused to go.
What can I say?
In addition to my constantly running around in ... for 5 months ...
From Pūšu-kēn, Aššur-dān and Ennum-Aššur to Ištar-pilaḫ:
Pūšu-kēn gave us the 1 1/2 minas silver which Abatum brought to him and thereof, we weighed out 26 5/6 shekels silver to Iddin-abum for your payment.
We paid 14 shekels silver for the donkey.
We weighed out 6 shekels silver (tibnim) to Ennum-Aššur.
There, let him pay you in full.
The remainder of your silver, 38 1/3 shekels, is with Pūšu-kēn.
Iddin-abum did not give any tin to Ennum-Aššur.
We will take the tin and send it to you with the next (caravan).
To Pūšu-kēn from Puzur-Aššur:
Instead of sending overly wonderful messages and informing me, you continually send me evasions and curses.
As for me, I will not take Iddin-abum to be an heir.
Also, I will not return a single shekel of silver to him.
Because he will give the tablet to a stranger(?) even I my tablet to my representatives, I give to him.
Today you can see for yourself that the youth is not wise.
I have set it up so that your words may go to his representatives may go (išrat!).
He will not act impudently toward anyone.
I will do so myself.
I wrote to Ikūppī-Aššur.
I took his be
From the silver of Ea-šar that Al-bēlī brought, they want, both for paying the price for purchases and as much as he paid for your share, the silver for the limmum.
I myself gave gold to the limmum.
They made a reckoning with the limmum and they need 3 or 4 minas of silver.
I will pay the silver.
Send silver to your representatives so that they may give it to me.
My dear father and lord, whenever my representatives send you tin or textiles, send them so that they send the silver after you.
Also make sure that Ikūppī-Aššur clears my accounts.
From Buzutaya, Ennum-Bēlum, and Puzur-Aššur to Pūšu-kēn:

After you departed, the colony office held a pouring for 14 textiles per share and in addition to the 7 textiles which you left for Puzur-Aššur, we purchased 21 textiles for 3 minas 16 shekels and we paid with your silver.
We deposited 20 textiles, as your share and the shares of Aḫu-waqar and Amur-Ištar.
They held the pouring for 3 minas each and Puzur-Aššūr wieghed out 6 minas silver to your shares.
The held a pouring for 1 fine textile each and he paid the price of 2 textiles 42 shekels silver.
Later they held a pouring for 13 textiles and as for the 26 textiles, your shares, at a rate of 9 1/2 shekels each, paid 4 minas 7 shekels silver.
He gave to us 1 mina 13 1/2 shekels silver.
Altogether, Puzur-Aššur paid to your name 12 minas 1/2 shekels silver from his own funds.
You are deposited for 20 minas 35 shekels silver in the colony office.
7 minas 45 shekels belong to Aḫu-waqar.
7 minas 47 1/2 shekels belong to Amur-Ištar.
From Šalim-aḫum to Lā-qēpum and Aššur-nādā:
Hannānum son of Ubhākum owes me 9 minas of refined silver here.
He is to pay (in installments of) 3 minas per year.
He is to pay me 3 minas of silver in this month of Kuzalli, year of Aḫ-marši.

Of the merchandise that he will lead to you may 4 minas of tin, the nisḫātu-tax on my tin for the palace, may that be charged to the tin for his expenses; should there be any balance, he should deduct it from the money he owes, and then you and Hannānum must seal the rest and send it to me; then his representatives here may open his tablet and deduct his payment (from his debt).
From Šalim-aḫum to Pūšu-kēn:
2 talents 10 minas under seal, 13 minas hand tin, 13 textiles--wrappings and top pack--1 black donkey.
The wages of the sāridum are paid.
All this Aššur-taklāku brings to you under my seal.
My dear brother and colleague, have I not already written you?
I said, "Take about 1 talent of tin or 10 textiles from my inventory and do me a favor."
My dear brother, now that it is time (for a) favor, do not overvalue every shekels against my tin and textiles.
In addition to the 25 minas silver of Lulu, and the proceeds of my tin and textiles, add the silver and bring it in your transport.

My dear brother, in order that I not be ashamed at the city gate when you arrive, collect every shekel of silver--that which is on terms and the proceeds of my tin and my textiles--so that every shekel of silver will enter my house at your arrival to the benefit of your reputation.
Of the 13 textiles, they should not recognize the dātum of 2 textiles.
Aššur-taklāku bears to you separately 1 heavy textile for travelling from Šāt-Aššur.
In addition to the silver, 30 minas of Aššur-ṭāb and the yeild of textiles for Aššur-mālik's cargo, put up some 10 minas silver yourself and let your silver be disposed for one or two months.
Dispatch Ennam-Aššur.
Sell as much of the goods of Ennam-Aššur's cargo as you are able and take your silver.
If Ennam-Aššur has left, on the day you read my tablet, cause the silver to catch up to him.
Do not disappoint me.
From Šalim-aḫum, Ḫinnaya, Aššur-imittī, Tariš-mātum and Bēlātum to Pūšu-kēn:
According to your instructions, we obtained a tablet of the city and the attorney brings it to you.
There, take care to gather together silver, maids, servants, houses--whatever Šū-Nunu left behind and seal and send to us.
We gave 1/3 mina silver a mina tin to the attorney.
Give to him 1/3 mina silver there so that he is satisfied.
We gave 10 shekels silver and 1 mina tin to Imgua.

According to the tablet of the city: "Concerning the silver of Aššūr-mālik, no one shall make claims on the sons of Aššur-mālik until they have satisfied the debts of the joint-stock fund, the income, the GA-ra-tim, and the šakultum (feasts?)."
It is there.
Show them the tablet.
To Pūšu-kēn from Tariš-mātum and Bēlātum:
Concerning the silver about which you wrote, at the arrival of the silver, we will give the first silver to your representative.
To Pūšu-kēn from Amur-Ištar and Dān-Aššur:
From the 1 talent 12 minas and 39 shekels of tin which the palace took, 343 minas of copper for one talent went out and they credited to us 410(?) minas.
Thereof, there are 144 minas zalam-ma(??).
The remainder is 168 minas --- 1 2/3 minas of silver at a rate of 6 1/2 shekels.
Total: x minas 10 1/2 shekels (of silver).
Thereof, we deposited 15 shekels (of silver) as the shipping charges.
Dān-Aššur brings you the remainder, 1 mina 56 1/3 shekels of silver under our seals.
I will not sell any silver whatsoever to (the palace) until the exhaustion (of the stockpiles) in the palace.
From Šū-Ḫubur to Pūšu-kēn:
Concerning the matter of Puzur-Anna son of Qayatum, here wherever there is a shekel of silver to be taken, it is not there.
There, as much as you are able, make the man stand up and cause him to pay, and give him your word in a bound agreement about the purchases.
If his sealed tablet with his seal here he does not hold, bind him.
Ennum-Aššur son of Šalim-aḫum is going toward you with the caravan.
Here in the house he will marry (my) daughter).
There, honor him on my behalf.
May he not become ill-tempered.
Is not my son-in-law your son-in-law?
Dispatch him very quickly so that he may take away (my) daughter.
If you are my brother,  (Is not my daughter and your daughter?) honor him, and send him off.
From Šū-Ḫubur to Pūšu-kēn:
You wrote, (saying) "Ikūnum's investors have gotten out 2 minas of silver for each mina of gold for their gold (shares)."
You wrote.
Ikūnum's investors have realized 2 minas silver on each mina gold for their gold.
If you judge look on him kindly, then he will give you an additional, (i.e.) three mina rate, instead of two mina rate.
Come to an agreement (with him).
If after the 2 minas he does give up to you an addition, write me so that I may impose his 'thirds' here and bind my silver in the city.

Concerning the 1 talent of tin which Aššur-mālik and Irma-Aššur sold to Lālum in Ḫaḫḫum, I have written to you several times (saying) "Here, I requested silver from the estate of Lālum, and they said, 'Write to wherever you sold him the tin and take your silver there; (but) there is no silver belonging to L
Urgent, take heed to send Aššur-mālik and Irma-Aššur, my witnesses that they entrusted the tin, to the representatives of Lālum there.
Wherever there is a single shekel of silver make them pay so that my silver is not lost.
I deposited 15 minas tin, the ikribū of Aššur, into the sack of Ikūnum.
Make him pay.
To Pūšu-kēn, Innāya, and Kilya the yellow one(?) from Šū-Kūbum:
Why is it that you write to me as if I were marked for death and your full report has not come to me for two years?
Previously you wrote to me.
“We received the silver of Apatanānum and since the terms of your merchants draw close, we will give him for interest. We will say, 'Let us send the silver all at once with Šamaš-tappa’ī.'"
The terms of my merchant turned to me already (?).
Indeed, you did send me the silver of Appatanānum with Kiliya.
(But) you did not send the silver of my merchant!
I hear that my textiles from the
He told me here that they sold the textiles in his presence.
Why did you not send the silver?
My dear brothers, take heed to send a detailed message about my assets(?) on credit, in cash, and in my account by express messenger.
I wrote to you (pl.).
I said, "Dispatch my servants as soon as they arrive."
But you (pl.), squandered Maṣi-bēlī and Išar-lu-ballaṭ.
If you are truly my brothers, dispatch Šamaš-tappāʾī, Mannu-kī-abiya and Ataya to me immediately.
Besides them, there is no one to by grain for me.
If you do not dispatch them to me immediately, you will make as angry as if you had lost a talent of silver of mine.
Send me as much as they balanced me at accountings.
Take care to deposit my share.
Will you take pains to make me fear?
To Imdī-ilum from Uzua:
After I arrived in Kunanamit, and I was far from your breast, may Aššur and Ištar-zat witness that becasue I never recevied heard any of your letters, I (set out) towards you.
I said to myself, " .. so that I may see the eye of my father and lord."
I came down and I gatehred togethre(?) every shekel of silver.
Because I had not heard any of your messages whatsoever, I made my way to the kārum-office.
I am protective of your reputation and wherver I gave a talent for putchases, I am able to raise a 10 shekels rate  in silver.
And I have done many favors
Also, I myself here to every shekels of silver which I made I hwl'd
And i will z'b.
My dear father and lord, who (but I) is your true servant?
I will lose from ...
Also, for years(?) I will make every shekel of silver.
When I heard your tablet and Abu-šalim spoke the instructions which you ..., I sent these tablets five time to you so taht you would not return the instructions.
If you desire, you will indeed approach to your breast and I will see your eye.
The packer of Pūšu-kēn which you cleared from being a sāridum hauler, let me set another name before you.

The package worth 10 minas silver, when you sold it on credit to the merchant, give the package worth 10 mians silver and mine so thatI can give from the top of the package which you sold, 10 talents washed copper from Durḫumit to your representative and I will casue the copper to arrive at Purušḫattum and I wil send the silver as much as it fetches to the city and they may make purchases for my package from your house.

Apart from these matters, make amends with me and I every shekel of silver which is in your possession (when I see) as soon as you are deducted, this 'nabritum'' in Kunanamit I will bru it to you your qiptum and whatever I make I will see.

Why is that, with regard to your tablet concerning the transport of Abu-šalim, which I heard/read, 5 talents washed copper toa reliable merchant who is after her every talent of copper which they will weigh out I gave to you concerning this ... I ate.
If these words should have been evil, I would depart for you.
Indeed, let Ištar-pilaḫ hear so that until he is released there I will not klm my bulatia to you.
After he left, ? 10 talents washed copper I opened for you.
15 talents washed copper I will send to you.
Now let him ... you my debt and sell my goods.
And when I see your eye .....
Truly, I am not your servant!
Let Ištar-pilaḫ come with your young man/son, so that I may depart and see your eye.
Why should your eye ... I keep asking.
I hear that my maḫāúm left with Amur-Ištar.
Dispatch him with Ištar-pilaḫ.
The son of Puzur-... ,,,,
Let your message come to the city, to Puzur-Mus and our ladies.
From Aššur-bāni and Šalim-Aššur to Pūšu-kēn:
Šū-Ḫubur did not want to give us the silver of Qayyātum's son.
He said, "Let him take it there."
So take it there.
As for the silver which you owe to Aššur-imittī, we borrowed (silver) on interest and we paid him.
We borrowed 6 talents of copper for the price of the houses and we paid it out.
Send the silver so that the interest does not become burdensome to you.
Tupezi stood to face the city council and we cleared his obligations(?).
We said, "There inasa (?) your house is spoken(?)"
From Aššur-bāni and Šalim-Aššur to Pūšu-kēn:
Here 'difficulties' (Veenhof) 'procedures'? have arisen concerning the saptinnū and pirikannū textiles and the woollen blankets (?), and many people have been fined.
You also they condemned to pay 10 minas silver.
You may pay in annual installments of 1 mina silver.
We borrowed on your behalf 7 1/2 minas of silver against interest from (the silver) transported by Kulumaya.
Send the silver and its interest.
Urgent, do not deal in
Your house and your servants are well.
The decrees of the City are binding!
Seals: Iddināya s. Idaliya, Iddin-abum s. Aššur-dān, Šū-Laban s. Elāli, Aššur-rēʾī s. Šū-Ištar.
Aššur-rēʾī s. Šū-Ištar owes Aḫu-waqar 2 minas refined silver.
He will pay 11 ḫamuštum weeks from the month of Ṣibʾem.
If he does not pay (on time), he will add 1 1/2 shekels mper mina per month as interest.
Eponymate: Puzur-Niraḫ.
Aššur-rēʾī s. Šū-Ištar owes Aḫu-waqar 2 minas refined silver.
He will pay 11 ḫamuštum weeks from the month of Ṣibʾum.
If he does not pay (on time) he will add 1 1/2 shekels per min per mont h as interest.
Eponymate: Puzur-Niraḫ
Witnesses: Idinaya, Iddin-abum,  Šū-Laban.
Išdu-kēn owes Ilī-dān 1 mina 5 5/6 shekels refined silver.
He will pay 13 ḫamuštum weeks from the ḫamuštum of Qarwiya s. Menānum.
If he does not pay at the fulfillment of the term, he will add 1 1/2 shekels per mina per month.
Witnesses: Aššur-bēl-awātim s. Aššur-mālik, Elāli s. Ikūnum, Puzur-Aššur s. Šū-Anum.
Iddin-Ištar son of Aššur-nādā owes 5 5/6minas of refined silver to Huraṣānum.
He will pay 13 ḫamuštum weeks from the ḫamuštum of Šū-Nunu and Puzur-Aššur.
If he does not pay (on time) he will add interest at the rate 1 1/2 shekel per mina per month.
Month: Te'inātum.
Eponymate: Al-aḫum s. Inaḫ-ilī.
Witnessed by Abu-šalim son of Iddin-Irra, witnessed by Ennam-Aššur son of Karria.
Ikuppiya owes (me) 37 1/2 shekels certified silver from the matter of the sealed tablet.
He will add 1 1/2 shekels per mina per month as interest from the ḫamuštum week of Elama and Kurub-Ištar, month Qarrātum, eponymate of Elāli.
Witnesses: Burqānum s. Kakkabānum, Šū-Ištar s. Šuaya.

As for the 15 shekels silver which Idī-Suen owes to the Anatolians and which Muza in his(?) guarantor, he gave the territories of the followers of the household(?) to Muza and the Anatolians for the 15 shekels silver.
If anyone approaches the Anatolians or Muza concerning the territories, Idī-Suen with clear them.
Witnesses: Ennum-Aššur s. Šalim-Adad, Adīya s. Amur-Ilī.
Ememe and Aššur-ṣulūlī owe Imdī-ilum 31 5/6 minas refined silver.
(He will pay) 23? ḫamuštum weeks from the ḫamuštum of Amur-Šamaš and Ikūnum.
[If he does not pay at full term, he will add 1 1/2 shekels per mina per month as interest.]
If Uṣur-ša-Aššur does not hand over the tablet of his seal, they will pay the silver themselves.
Witnesses: (signs partially erased).
